00:08:29.300 --> 00:08:33.006
They were incredibly effective as enforcers for the Gulf Cartel,

00:08:33.006 --> 00:08:34.894
so much so that at some point, they decided

00:08:34.894 --> 00:08:37.387
to just take over the operations,

00:08:37.387 --> 00:08:41.181
which is why I ask you to never keep tigers as pets,

00:08:41.181 --> 00:08:43.822
because they grow up.

00:08:43.822 --> 00:08:47.518
Because the Zetas organization was founded in treason,

00:08:47.518 --> 00:08:50.454
they lost some of the linkages to the production and distribution

00:08:50.454 --> 00:08:52.661
in the most profitable markets like cocaine,

00:08:52.661 --> 00:08:53.951
but what they did have,

00:08:53.951 --> 00:08:56.411
and this is again based on their military origin,

00:08:56.411 --> 00:08:59.258
was a perfectly structured chain of command

00:08:59.258 --> 00:09:01.883
with a very clear hierarchy

00:09:01.883 --> 00:09:05.947
and a very clear promotion path that allowed them

00:09:05.947 --> 00:09:09.769
to supervise and operate across many, many markets

00:09:09.769 --> 00:09:11.411
very effectively,

00:09:11.411 --> 00:09:15.210
which is the essence of what a chain of command seeks to do.

00:09:15.210 --> 00:09:16.499
And so because they didn't have access

00:09:16.499 --> 00:09:18.834
to the more profitable drug markets,

00:09:18.834 --> 00:09:20.507
this pushed them and gave them the opportunity

00:09:20.507 --> 00:09:24.005
to diversify into other forms of crime.

00:09:24.005 --> 00:09:28.060
That includes kidnapping, prostitution,

00:09:28.060 --> 00:09:30.241
local drug dealing and human trafficking,

00:09:30.241 --> 00:09:34.197
including of migrants that go from the south to the U.S.

00:09:34.197 --> 00:09:38.445
So what they currently run is truly

00:09:38.445 --> 00:09:42.017
and quite literally a franchise business.

00:09:42.017 --> 00:09:45.848
They focus most of their recruiting on the army,

00:09:45.848 --> 00:09:48.925
and they very openly advertise for better salaries,

00:09:48.925 --> 00:09:51.623
better benefits, better promotion paths,

00:09:51.623 --> 00:09:53.271
not to mention much better food,

00:09:53.271 --> 00:09:55.978
than what the army can deliver.

00:09:55.978 --> 00:09:57.847
The way they operate is that

00:09:57.847 --> 00:09:59.752
when they arrive in a locality,

00:09:59.752 --> 00:10:01.503
they let people know that they are there,

00:10:01.503 --> 00:10:04.573
and they go to the most powerful local gang

00:10:04.573 --> 00:10:06.813
and they say, "I offer you

00:10:06.813 --> 00:10:10.002
to be the local representative of the Zeta brand."

00:10:10.002 --> 00:10:11.875
If they agree -- and you don't want to know

00:10:11.875 --> 00:10:13.618
what happens if they don't --

00:10:13.618 --> 00:10:15.305
they train them and they supervise them

00:10:15.305 --> 00:10:18.632
on how to run the most efficient criminal operation

00:10:18.632 --> 00:10:22.133
for that town, in exchange for royalties.

00:10:22.133 --> 00:10:24.039
This kind of business model obviously depends

00:10:24.039 --> 00:10:26.436
entirely on having a very effective brand of fear,

00:10:26.436 --> 00:10:28.809
and so Los Zetas

00:10:28.809 --> 00:10:31.102
carefully stage acts of violence

00:10:31.102 --> 00:10:33.035
that are spectacular in nature,

00:10:33.035 --> 00:10:35.835
especially when they arrive first in a city,

00:10:35.835 --> 00:10:39.069
but again, that's just a brand strategy.

00:10:39.069 --> 00:10:40.968
I'm not saying they're not violent,

00:10:40.968 --> 00:10:42.911
but what I am saying is that even though you will read

00:10:42.911 --> 00:10:44.774
that they are the most violent of all,

00:10:44.774 --> 00:10:47.737
when you count, when you do the body count,

00:10:47.737 --> 00:10:51.509
they're actually all the same.

00:10:51.509 --> 00:10:54.597
In contrast to them, the Knights Templar

00:10:54.597 --> 00:10:56.437
that arose in Michoacán

00:10:56.437 --> 00:10:59.044
emerged in reaction to the incursion

00:10:59.044 --> 00:11:01.579
of the Zetas into the state of Michoacán.

00:11:01.579 --> 00:11:04.496
Michoacán is a geographically strategic state

00:11:04.496 --> 00:11:06.499
because it has one of the largest ports in Mexico,

00:11:06.499 --> 00:11:09.090
and it has very direct routes to the center of Mexico,

00:11:09.090 --> 00:11:12.156
which then gives you direct access to the U.S.

00:11:12.156 --> 00:11:13.695
The Knights Templar realized very quickly

00:11:13.695 --> 00:11:17.203
that they couldn't face the Zetas on violence alone,

00:11:17.203 --> 00:11:19.560
and so they developed a strategy

00:11:19.560 --> 00:11:22.339
as a social enterprise.

00:11:22.339 --> 00:11:25.339
They brand themselves as representative of

00:11:25.339 --> 00:11:27.995
and protecting of the citizens of Michoacán

00:11:27.995 --> 00:11:30.293
against organized crime.

00:11:30.293 --> 00:11:32.024
Their brand of social enterprise means

00:11:32.024 --> 00:11:34.075
that they require a lot of civic engagement,

00:11:34.075 --> 00:11:38.241
so they invest heavily in providing local services,

00:11:38.241 --> 00:11:41.739
like dealing with home violence,

00:11:41.739 --> 00:11:45.515
going after petty criminals, treating addicts,

00:11:45.515 --> 00:11:48.293
and keeping drugs out of the local markets

00:11:48.293 --> 00:11:50.773
where they are,

00:11:50.773 --> 00:11:52.392
and, of course, protecting people

00:11:52.392 --> 00:11:54.883
from other criminal organizations.

00:11:54.883 --> 00:11:57.914
Now, they kill a lot of people too,

00:11:57.914 --> 00:12:00.011
but when they kill them,

00:12:00.026 --> 00:12:02.926
they provide very careful narratives and descriptions

00:12:02.926 --> 00:12:04.178
for why they did them,

00:12:04.178 --> 00:12:08.141
through newspaper insertions, YouTube videos,

00:12:08.141 --> 00:12:10.607
and billboards that explain that the people who were killed

00:12:10.607 --> 00:12:12.935
were killed because they represented a threat

00:12:12.935 --> 00:12:14.791
not to us, as an organization, of course,

00:12:14.791 --> 00:12:16.727
but to you, as citizens.

00:12:16.727 --> 00:12:19.183
And so we're actually here to protect you.

00:12:19.183 --> 00:12:21.747
They, as social enterprises do,

00:12:21.747 --> 00:12:23.247
have created a moral and ethical code

00:12:23.247 --> 00:12:25.616
that they advertise around,

00:12:25.616 --> 00:12:28.754
and they have very strict recruiting practices.

00:12:28.754 --> 00:12:30.577
And here you have the types of explanations

00:12:30.577 --> 00:12:34.518
that they provide for some of their actions.

00:12:34.518 --> 00:12:36.414
They have actually retained access

00:12:36.414 --> 00:12:38.714
to the profitable drug trade,

00:12:38.714 --> 00:12:40.924
but the way they do it is, because they control all of Michoacán,

00:12:40.924 --> 00:12:43.067
and they control the Port of Lázaro Cárdenas,

00:12:43.067 --> 00:12:44.869
they leverage that to, for example,

00:12:44.869 --> 00:12:48.426
trade copper from Michoacán that is legally created

00:12:48.426 --> 00:12:49.826
and legally extracted

00:12:49.826 --> 00:12:51.828
with illegal ephedrine from China

00:12:51.828 --> 00:12:55.252
which is a critical precursor for methamphetamines

00:12:55.252 --> 00:12:57.652
that they produce, and then they have partnerships

00:12:57.652 --> 00:13:00.190
with larger organizations like the Sinaloa Federation

00:13:00.190 --> 00:13:02.880
that place their products in the U.S.

00:13:02.880 --> 00:13:05.551
Finally, the Sinaloa Federation.

00:13:05.551 --> 00:13:07.749
When you read about them, you will often read about them

00:13:07.749 --> 00:13:11.449
with an undertone of reverence and admiration,

00:13:11.449 --> 00:13:13.365
because they are the most integrated

00:13:13.365 --> 00:13:15.653
and the largest of all the Mexican organizations,

00:13:15.653 --> 00:13:19.107
and, many people argue, the world.

00:13:19.107 --> 00:13:22.091
They started as just sort of a transport organization

00:13:22.091 --> 00:13:24.165
that specialized in smuggling between the U.S.

00:13:24.165 --> 00:13:26.290
and the Mexican borders,

00:13:26.290 --> 00:13:27.708
but now they have grown

00:13:27.708 --> 00:13:31.134
into a truly integrated multinational

00:13:31.134 --> 00:13:33.440
that has partnerships in production in the south

00:13:33.440 --> 00:13:36.453
and partnerships in global distribution

00:13:36.453 --> 00:13:38.947
across the planet.

00:13:38.947 --> 00:13:42.277
They have cultivated a brand of professionalism,

00:13:42.277 --> 00:13:45.595
business acumen and innovation.

00:13:45.595 --> 00:13:47.694
They have designed new drug products

00:13:47.694 --> 00:13:49.417
and new drug processes.

00:13:49.417 --> 00:13:51.635
They have designed narco-tunnels

00:13:51.635 --> 00:13:53.176
that go across the border,

00:13:53.176 --> 00:13:54.991
and you can see that these are not

00:13:54.991 --> 00:13:58.939
"The Shawshank Redemption" types.

00:13:58.939 --> 00:14:02.635
They have invented narco-submarines and boats

00:14:02.635 --> 00:14:05.318
that are not detected by radar.

00:14:05.318 --> 00:14:07.881
They have invented drones to transport drugs,

00:14:07.881 --> 00:14:11.167
catapults, you name it.

00:14:11.167 --> 00:14:13.508
One of the leaders of the Sinaloa Federation

00:14:13.508 --> 00:14:15.946
actually made it to the Forbes list.

00:14:15.946 --> 00:14:17.919
[#701 Joaquin Guzman Loera]

00:14:17.919 --> 00:14:20.824
Like any multinational would, they have specialized

00:14:20.824 --> 00:14:23.113
and focused only in the most profitable part of the business,

00:14:23.113 --> 00:14:25.791
which is high-margin drugs like cocaine,

00:14:25.791 --> 00:14:28.076
heroine, methamphetamines.

00:14:28.076 --> 00:14:30.649
Like any traditional Latin American multinational would,

00:14:30.649 --> 00:14:32.390
the way they control their operations

00:14:32.390 --> 00:14:34.172
is through family ties.

00:14:34.172 --> 00:14:36.117
When they're entering a new market, they send

00:14:36.117 --> 00:14:37.838
a family member to supervise it,

00:14:37.838 --> 00:14:40.655
or, if they're partnering with a new organization,

00:14:40.655 --> 00:14:42.075
they create a family tie,

00:14:42.075 --> 00:14:46.541
either through marriages or other types of ties.

00:14:46.541 --> 00:14:48.704
Like any other multinational would,

00:14:48.704 --> 00:14:51.871
they protect their brand by outsourcing

00:14:51.871 --> 00:14:54.039
the more questionable parts of the business model,

00:14:54.039 --> 00:14:56.082
like for example, when they have to engage

00:14:56.082 --> 00:14:58.847
in violence against other criminal organizations,

00:14:58.847 --> 00:15:02.292
they recruit gangs and other smaller players

00:15:02.292 --> 00:15:04.091
to do the dirty work for them,

00:15:04.091 --> 00:15:05.876
and they try to separate their operations

00:15:05.876 --> 00:15:09.511
and their violence and be very discrete about this.

00:15:09.511 --> 00:15:12.007
To further strengthen their brand,

00:15:12.007 --> 00:15:14.900
they actually have professional P.R. firms

00:15:14.900 --> 00:15:17.379
that shape how the press talks about them.

00:15:17.379 --> 00:15:20.930
They have professional videographers on staff.

00:15:20.930 --> 00:15:23.043
They have incredibly productive ties

00:15:23.043 --> 00:15:24.876
with the security organizations

00:15:24.876 --> 00:15:28.288
on both sides of the border.

00:15:28.288 --> 00:15:30.889
And so, differences aside,

00:15:30.889 --> 00:15:34.444
what these three organizations share

00:15:34.444 --> 00:15:38.084
is on the one hand, a very clear understanding

00:15:38.084 --> 00:15:41.168
that institutions cannot be imposed from the top,

00:15:41.168 --> 00:15:44.108
but rather they are built from the bottom up

00:15:44.108 --> 00:15:47.391
one interaction at a time.

00:15:47.391 --> 00:15:49.812
They have created extremely coherent structures

00:15:49.812 --> 00:15:52.646
that they use to show the inconsistencies

00:15:52.646 --> 00:15:56.673
in government policies.

00:15:56.673 --> 00:15:59.160
And so what I want you to remember from this talk

00:15:59.160 --> 00:16:00.693
are three things.

00:16:00.693 --> 00:16:03.749
The first one is that drug violence

00:16:03.749 --> 00:16:05.626
is actually the result

00:16:05.626 --> 00:16:08.877
of a huge market demand

00:16:08.877 --> 00:16:12.527
and an institutional setup that forces

00:16:12.527 --> 00:16:15.653
the servicing of this market to necessitate violence

00:16:15.653 --> 00:16:19.698
to guarantee delivery routes.

00:16:19.698 --> 00:16:21.624
The second thing I want you to remember

00:16:21.624 --> 00:16:23.570
is that these are sophisticated,

00:16:23.570 --> 00:16:26.493
coherent organizations

00:16:26.493 --> 00:16:28.451
that are business organizations,

00:16:28.451 --> 00:16:30.370
and analyzing them and treating them as such

00:16:30.370 --> 00:16:33.759
is probably a much more useful approach.

00:16:33.759 --> 00:16:35.895
The third thing I want you to remember

00:16:35.895 --> 00:16:37.323
is that even though we're more comfortable

00:16:37.323 --> 00:16:39.846
with this idea of "them,"

00:16:39.846 --> 00:16:42.587
a set of bad guys separated from us,

00:16:42.587 --> 00:16:45.564
we are actually accomplices to them,

00:16:45.564 --> 00:16:47.953
either through our direct consumption

00:16:47.953 --> 00:16:52.025
or through our acceptance of the inconsistency

00:16:52.025 --> 00:16:54.293
between our policies of prohibition

00:16:54.293 --> 00:16:57.241
and our actual behavior of tolerance

00:16:57.241 --> 00:17:01.465
or even encouragement of consumption.

00:17:01.465 --> 00:17:05.485
These organizations service, recruit from,

00:17:05.485 --> 00:17:07.813
and operate within our communities,

00:17:07.813 --> 00:17:10.231
so necessarily, they are much more integrated

00:17:10.231 --> 00:17:14.701
within them than we are comfortable acknowledging.

00:17:14.701 --> 00:17:17.566
And so to me the question is not whether

00:17:17.566 --> 00:17:20.847
these dynamics will continue the way they have.

00:17:20.847 --> 00:17:23.612
We see that the nature of this phenomenon

00:17:23.612 --> 00:17:26.080
guarantees that they will.

00:17:26.080 --> 00:17:28.960
The question is whether we are willing to continue

00:17:28.960 --> 00:17:33.566
our support of a failed strategy

00:17:33.566 --> 00:17:39.073
based on our stubborn, blissful, voluntary ignorance

00:17:39.073 --> 00:17:44.034
at the cost of the deaths of thousands of our young.

00:17:44.034 --> 00:17:45.765
Thank you.

00:17:45.765 --> 00:17:50.927
(Applause)

title: What I discovered in New York City  trash
transcript: I was about 10 years old on a camping trip with my dad in the Adirondack Mountains, a wilderness area in the northern part of New York State. It was a beautiful day. The forest was sparkling. The sun made the leaves glow like stained glass, and if it weren't for the path we were following, we could almost pretend we were the first human beings to ever walk that land.We got to our campsite. It was a lean-to on a bluff looking over a crystal, beautiful lake, when I discovered a horror. Behind the lean-to was a dump, maybe 40 feet square with rotting apple cores and balled-up aluminum foil, and a dead sneaker. And I was astonished, I was very angry, and I was deeply confused. The campers who were too lazy to take out what they had brought in, who did they think would clean up after them?That question stayed with me, and it simplified a little. Who cleans up after us? However you configure or wherever you place the us, who cleans up after us in Istanbul? Who cleans up after us in Rio or in Paris or in London? Here in New York, the Department of Sanitation cleans up after us, to the tune of 11,000 tons of garbage and 2,000 tons of recyclables every day. I wanted to get to know them as individuals. I wanted to understand who takes the job. What's it like to wear the uniform and bear that burden?So I started a research project with them. I rode in the trucks and walked the routes and interviewed people in offices and facilities all over the city, and I learned a lot, but I was still an outsider. I needed to go deeper.So I took the job as a sanitation worker. I didn't just ride in the trucks now. I drove the trucks. And I operated the mechanical brooms and I plowed the snow. It was a remarkable privilege and an amazing education.Everyone asks about the smell. It's there, but it's not as prevalent as you think, and on days when it is really bad, you get used to it rather quickly. The weight takes a long time to get used to. I knew people who were several years on the job whose bodies were still adjusting to the burden of bearing on your body tons of trash every week.Then there's the danger. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, sanitation work is one of the 10 most dangerous occupations in the country, and I learned why. You're in and out of traffic all day, and it's zooming around you. It just wants to get past you, so it's often the motorist is not paying attention. That's really bad for the worker. And then the garbage itself is full of hazards that often fly back out of the truck and do terrible harm.I also learned about the relentlessness of trash. When you step off the curb and you see a city from behind a truck, you come to understand that trash is like a force of nature unto itself. It never stops coming. It's also like a form of respiration or circulation. It must always be in motion.And then there's the stigma. You put on the uniform, and you become invisible until someone is upset with you for whatever reason like you've blocked traffic with your truck, or you're taking a break too close to their home, or you're drinking coffee in their diner, and they will come and scorn you, and tell you that they don't want you anywhere near them. I find the stigma especially ironic, because I strongly believe that sanitation workers are the most important labor force on the streets of the city, for three reasons. They are the first guardians of public health. If they're not taking away trash efficiently and effectively every day, it starts to spill out of its containments, and the dangers inherent to it threaten us in very real ways. Diseases we've had in check for decades and centuries burst forth again and start to harm us. The economy needs them. If we can't throw out the old stuff, we have no room for the new stuff, so then the engines of the economy start to sputter when consumption is compromised. I'm not advocating capitalism, I'm just pointing out their relationship. And then there's what I call our average, necessary quotidian velocity. By that I simply mean how fast we're used to moving in the contemporary day and age. We usually don't care for, repair, clean, carry around our coffee cup, our shopping bag, our bottle of water. We use them, we throw them out, we forget about them, because we know there's a workforce on the other side that's going to take it all away.So I want to suggest today a couple of ways to think about sanitation that will perhaps help ameliorate the stigma and bring them into this conversation of how to craft a city that is sustainable and humane. Their work, I think, is kind of liturgical. They're on the streets every day, rhythmically. They wear a uniform in many cities. You know when to expect them. And their work lets us do our work. They are almost a form of reassurance. The flow that they maintain keeps us safe from ourselves, from our own dross, our cast-offs, and that flow must be maintained always no matter what.On the day after September 11 in 2001, I heard the growl of a sanitation truck on the street, and I grabbed my infant son and I ran downstairs and there was a man doing his paper recycling route like he did every Wednesday. And I tried to thank him for doing his work on that day of all days, but I started to cry. And he looked at me, and he just nodded, and he said, "We're going to be okay. We're going to be okay." It was a little while later that I started my research with sanitation, and I met that man again. His name is Paulie, and we worked together many times, and we became good friends.I want to believe that Paulie was right. We are going to be okay. But in our effort to reconfigure how we as a species exist on this planet, we must include and take account of all the costs, including the very real human cost of the labor. And we also would be well informed to reach out to the people who do that work and get their expertise on how do we think about, how do we create systems around sustainability that perhaps take us from curbside recycling, which is a remarkable success across 40 years, across the United States and countries around the world, and lift us up to a broader horizon where we're looking at other forms of waste that could be lessened from manufacturing and industrial sources. Municipal waste, what we think of when we talk about garbage, accounts for three percent of the nation's waste stream. It's a remarkable statistic.So in the flow of your days, in the flow of your lives, next time you see someone whose job is to clean up after you, take a moment to acknowledge them. Take a moment to say thank you.(Applause)

00:01:26.641 --> 00:01:28.213
Here in New York,

00:01:28.213 --> 00:01:30.805
the Department of Sanitation cleans up after us,

00:01:30.805 --> 00:01:33.475
to the tune of 11,000 tons of garbage

00:01:33.475 --> 00:01:37.837
and 2,000 tons of recyclables every day.

00:01:37.837 --> 00:01:40.470
I wanted to get to know them as individuals.

00:01:40.470 --> 00:01:43.316
I wanted to understand who takes the job.

00:01:43.316 --> 00:01:45.835
What's it like to wear the uniform

00:01:45.835 --> 00:01:47.489
and bear that burden?

00:01:47.489 --> 00:01:50.142
So I started a research project with them.

00:01:50.142 --> 00:01:52.681
I rode in the trucks and walked the routes

00:01:52.681 --> 00:01:55.090
and interviewed people in offices and facilities

00:01:55.090 --> 00:01:56.597
all over the city,

00:01:56.597 --> 00:01:58.336
and I learned a lot,

00:01:58.336 --> 00:02:00.685
but I was still an outsider.

00:02:00.685 --> 00:02:02.563
I needed to go deeper.

00:02:02.563 --> 00:02:05.679
So I took the job as a sanitation worker.

00:02:05.679 --> 00:02:08.326
I didn't just ride in the trucks now. I drove the trucks.

00:02:08.326 --> 00:02:11.471
And I operated the mechanical brooms and I plowed the snow.

00:02:11.471 --> 00:02:13.370
It was a remarkable privilege

00:02:13.370 --> 00:02:15.977
and an amazing education.

00:02:15.977 --> 00:02:18.129
Everyone asks about the smell.

00:02:18.129 --> 00:02:21.189
It's there, but it's not as prevalent as you think,

00:02:21.189 --> 00:02:22.703
and on days when it is really bad,

00:02:22.703 --> 00:02:25.379
you get used to it rather quickly.

00:02:25.379 --> 00:02:28.576
The weight takes a long time to get used to.

00:02:28.576 --> 00:02:30.863
I knew people who were several years on the job

00:02:30.863 --> 00:02:33.448
whose bodies were still adjusting to the burden

00:02:33.448 --> 00:02:35.529
of bearing on your body

00:02:35.529 --> 00:02:38.508
tons of trash every week.

00:02:38.508 --> 00:02:40.692
Then there's the danger.

00:02:40.692 --> 00:02:43.164
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics,

00:02:43.164 --> 00:02:45.366
sanitation work is one of the 10 most dangerous

00:02:45.366 --> 00:02:47.258
occupations in the country,

00:02:47.258 --> 00:02:49.009
and I learned why.

00:02:49.009 --> 00:02:50.430
You're in and out of traffic all day,

00:02:50.430 --> 00:02:51.391
and it's zooming around you.

00:02:51.391 --> 00:02:53.275
It just wants to get past you, so it's often

00:02:53.275 --> 00:02:55.325
the motorist is not paying attention.

00:02:55.325 --> 00:02:57.151
That's really bad for the worker.

00:02:57.151 --> 00:02:59.311
And then the garbage itself is full of hazards

00:02:59.311 --> 00:03:01.330
that often fly back out of the truck

00:03:01.330 --> 00:03:03.411
and do terrible harm.

00:03:03.411 --> 00:03:06.226
I also learned about the relentlessness of trash.

00:03:06.226 --> 00:03:07.537
When you step off the curb

00:03:07.537 --> 00:03:10.386
and you see a city from behind a truck,

00:03:10.386 --> 00:03:12.172
you come to understand that trash

00:03:12.172 --> 00:03:14.789
is like a force of nature unto itself.

00:03:14.789 --> 00:03:17.245
It never stops coming.

00:03:17.245 --> 00:03:20.724
It's also like a form of respiration or circulation.

00:03:20.724 --> 00:03:23.769
It must always be in motion.

00:03:23.769 --> 00:03:25.817
And then there's the stigma.

00:03:25.817 --> 00:03:28.733
You put on the uniform, and you become invisible

00:03:28.733 --> 00:03:31.037
until someone is upset with you for whatever reason

00:03:31.037 --> 00:03:33.352
like you've blocked traffic with your truck,

00:03:33.352 --> 00:03:36.003
or you're taking a break too close to their home,

00:03:36.003 --> 00:03:39.117
or you're drinking coffee in their diner,

00:03:39.117 --> 00:03:41.527
and they will come and scorn you,

00:03:41.527 --> 00:03:44.789
and tell you that they don't want you anywhere near them.

00:03:44.789 --> 00:03:47.221
I find the stigma especially ironic,

00:03:47.221 --> 00:03:50.532
because I strongly believe that sanitation workers

00:03:50.532 --> 00:03:52.212
are the most important labor force

00:03:52.212 --> 00:03:55.236
on the streets of the city, for three reasons.

00:03:55.236 --> 00:03:58.018
They are the first guardians of public health.

00:03:58.018 --> 00:04:00.424
If they're not taking away trash

00:04:00.424 --> 00:04:02.698
efficiently and effectively every day,

00:04:02.698 --> 00:04:05.409
it starts to spill out of its containments,

00:04:05.409 --> 00:04:09.135
and the dangers inherent to it threaten us

00:04:09.135 --> 00:04:10.309
in very real ways.

00:04:10.309 --> 00:04:13.280
Diseases we've had in check for decades and centuries

00:04:13.280 --> 00:04:16.186
burst forth again and start to harm us.

00:04:16.186 --> 00:04:17.858
The economy needs them.

00:04:17.858 --> 00:04:20.784
If we can't throw out the old stuff,

00:04:20.784 --> 00:04:22.674
we have no room for the new stuff,

00:04:22.674 --> 00:04:24.743
so then the engines of the economy

00:04:24.743 --> 00:04:27.672
start to sputter when consumption is compromised.

00:04:27.672 --> 00:04:31.736
I'm not advocating capitalism, I'm just pointing out their relationship.

00:04:31.736 --> 00:04:33.724
And then there's what I call

00:04:33.724 --> 00:04:37.936
our average, necessary quotidian velocity.

00:04:37.936 --> 00:04:38.985
By that I simply mean

00:04:38.985 --> 00:04:41.237
how fast we're used to moving

00:04:41.237 --> 00:04:43.369
in the contemporary day and age.

00:04:43.369 --> 00:04:48.713
We usually don't care for, repair, clean, carry around

00:04:48.713 --> 00:04:51.350
our coffee cup, our shopping bag,

00:04:51.350 --> 00:04:52.835
our bottle of water.

00:04:52.835 --> 00:04:55.514
We use them, we throw them out, we forget about them,

00:04:55.514 --> 00:04:57.294
because we know there's a workforce

00:04:57.294 --> 00:05:00.314
on the other side that's going to take it all away.

00:05:00.314 --> 00:05:02.761
So I want to suggest today a couple of ways

00:05:02.761 --> 00:05:07.275
to think about sanitation that will perhaps help

00:05:07.275 --> 00:05:09.749
ameliorate the stigma

00:05:09.749 --> 00:05:11.980
and bring them into this conversation

00:05:11.980 --> 00:05:17.570
of how to craft a city that is sustainable and humane.

00:05:17.570 --> 00:05:21.731
Their work, I think, is kind of liturgical.

00:05:21.731 --> 00:05:24.192
They're on the streets every day, rhythmically.

00:05:24.192 --> 00:05:26.253
They wear a uniform in many cities.

00:05:26.253 --> 00:05:28.122
You know when to expect them.

00:05:28.122 --> 00:05:32.045
And their work lets us do our work.

00:05:32.045 --> 00:05:34.836
They are almost a form of reassurance.

00:05:34.836 --> 00:05:36.573
The flow that they maintain

00:05:36.573 --> 00:05:38.563
keeps us safe from ourselves,

00:05:38.563 --> 00:05:41.200
from our own dross, our cast-offs,

00:05:41.200 --> 00:05:44.458
and that flow must be maintained always

00:05:44.458 --> 00:05:46.091
no matter what.

00:05:46.091 --> 00:05:49.815
On the day after September 11 in 2001,

00:05:49.815 --> 00:05:53.102
I heard the growl of a sanitation truck on the street,

00:05:53.102 --> 00:05:55.414
and I grabbed my infant son and I ran downstairs

00:05:55.414 --> 00:05:58.256
and there was a man doing his paper recycling route

00:05:58.256 --> 00:06:00.438
like he did every Wednesday.

00:06:00.438 --> 00:06:02.858
And I tried to thank him for doing his work

00:06:02.858 --> 00:06:04.983
on that day of all days,

00:06:04.983 --> 00:06:07.584
but I started to cry.

00:06:07.584 --> 00:06:09.268
And he looked at me,

00:06:09.268 --> 00:06:12.692
and he just nodded, and he said,

00:06:12.692 --> 00:06:15.570
"We're going to be okay.

00:06:15.570 --> 00:06:18.211
We're going to be okay."

00:06:18.211 --> 00:06:19.564
It was a little while later that I started

00:06:19.564 --> 00:06:20.944
my research with sanitation,

00:06:20.944 --> 00:06:22.358
and I met that man again.

00:06:22.358 --> 00:06:25.275
His name is Paulie, and we worked together many times,

00:06:25.275 --> 00:06:27.098
and we became good friends.

00:06:27.098 --> 00:06:29.925
I want to believe that Paulie was right.

00:06:29.925 --> 00:06:32.127
We are going to be okay.

00:06:32.127 --> 00:06:34.104
But in our effort to reconfigure

00:06:34.104 --> 00:06:37.145
how we as a species exist on this planet,

00:06:37.145 --> 00:06:40.440
we must include and take account of

00:06:40.440 --> 00:06:44.233
all the costs, including the very real human cost

00:06:44.233 --> 00:06:45.737
of the labor.

00:06:45.737 --> 00:06:48.538
And we also would be well informed

00:06:48.538 --> 00:06:50.756
to reach out to the people who do that work

00:06:50.756 --> 00:06:52.601
and get their expertise

00:06:52.601 --> 00:06:54.354
on how do we think about,

00:06:54.354 --> 00:06:57.604
how do we create systems around sustainability

00:06:57.604 --> 00:07:01.083
that perhaps take us from curbside recycling,

00:07:01.083 --> 00:07:03.668
which is a remarkable success across 40 years,

00:07:03.668 --> 00:07:06.906
across the United States and countries around the world,

00:07:06.906 --> 00:07:09.708
and lift us up to a broader horizon

00:07:09.708 --> 00:07:12.594
where we're looking at other forms of waste

00:07:12.594 --> 00:07:14.079
that could be lessened

00:07:14.079 --> 00:07:16.812
from manufacturing and industrial sources.

00:07:16.812 --> 00:07:20.817
Municipal waste, what we think of when we talk about garbage,

00:07:20.817 --> 00:07:24.815
accounts for three percent of the nation's waste stream.

00:07:24.815 --> 00:07:27.202
It's a remarkable statistic.

00:07:27.202 --> 00:07:29.680
So in the flow of your days,

00:07:29.680 --> 00:07:31.206
in the flow of your lives,

00:07:31.206 --> 00:07:34.234
next time you see someone whose job is

00:07:34.234 --> 00:07:37.377
to clean up after you,

00:07:37.377 --> 00:07:39.866
take a moment to acknowledge them.

00:07:39.866 --> 00:07:44.458
Take a moment to say thank you.

00:07:44.458 --> 00:07:47.812
(Applause)

title: The paralyzed rat that walked
transcript: I am a neuroscientist with a mixed background in physics and medicine. My lab at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology focuses on spinal cord injury, which affects more than 50,000 people around the world every year, with dramatic consequences for affected individuals, whose life literally shatters in a matter of a handful of seconds.And for me, the Man of Steel, Christopher Reeve, has best raised the awareness on the distress of spinal cord injured people. And this is how I started my own personal journey in this field of research, working with the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation.I still remember this decisive moment. It was just at the end of a regular day of work with the foundation. Chris addressed us, the scientists and experts, "You have to be more pragmatic. When leaving your laboratory tomorrow, I want you to stop by the rehabilitation center to watch injured people fighting to take a step, struggling to maintain their trunk. And when you go home, think of what you are going to change in your research on the following day to make their lives better."These words, they stuck with me. This was more than 10 years ago, but ever since, my laboratory has followed the pragmatic approach to recovery after spinal cord injury. And my first step in this direction was to develop a new model of spinal cord injury that would more closely mimic some of the key features of human injury while offering well-controlled experimental conditions. And for this purpose, we placed two hemisections on opposite sides of the body. They completely interrupt the communication between the brain and the spinal cord, thus leading to complete and permanent paralysis of the leg. But, as observed, after most injuries in humans, there is this intervening gap of intact neural tissue through which recovery can occur. But how to make it happen?Well, the classical approach consists of applying intervention that would promote the growth of the severed fiber to the original target. And while this certainly remained the key for a cure, this seemed extraordinarily complicated to me. To reach clinical fruition rapidly, it was obvious: I had to think about the problem differently.It turned out that more than 100 years of research on spinal cord physiology, starting with the Nobel Prize Sherrington, had shown that the spinal cord, below most injuries, contained all the necessary and sufficient neural networks to coordinate locomotion, but because input from the brain is interrupted, they are in a nonfunctional state, like kind of dormant. My idea: We awaken this network.And at the time, I was a post-doctoral fellow in Los Angeles, after completing my Ph.D. in France, where independent thinking is not necessarily promoted. (Laughter) I was afraid to talk to my new boss, but decided to muster up my courage. I knocked at the door of my wonderful advisor, Reggie Edgerton, to share my new idea.He listened to me carefully, and responded with a grin. "Why don't you try?"And I promise to you, this was such an important moment in my career, when I realized that the great leader believed in young people and new ideas.And this was the idea: I'm going to use a simplistic metaphor to explain to you this complicated concept. Imagine that the locomotor system is a car. The engine is the spinal cord. The transmission is interrupted. The engine is turned off. How could we re-engage the engine? First, we have to provide the fuel; second, press the accelerator pedal; third, steer the car. It turned out that there are known neural pathways coming from the brain that play this very function during locomotion. My idea: Replace this missing input to provide the spinal cord with the kind of intervention that the brain would deliver naturally in order to walk.For this, I leveraged 20 years of past research in neuroscience, first to replace the missing fuel with pharmacological agents that prepare the neurons in the spinal cord to fire, and second, to mimic the accelerator pedal with electrical stimulation. So here imagine an electrode implanted on the back of the spinal cord to deliver painless stimulation. It took many years, but eventually we developed an electrochemical neuroprosthesis that transformed the neural network in the spinal cord from dormant to a highly functional state. Immediately, the paralyzed rat can stand. As soon as the treadmill belt starts moving, the animal shows coordinated movement of the leg, but without the brain. Here what I call "the spinal brain" cognitively processes sensory information arising from the moving leg and makes decisions as to how to activate the muscle in order to stand, to walk, to run, and even here, while sprinting, instantly stand if the treadmill stops moving.This was amazing. I was completely fascinated by this locomotion without the brain, but at the same time so frustrated. This locomotion was completely involuntary. The animal had virtually no control over the legs. Clearly, the steering system was missing. And it then became obvious from me that we had to move away from the classical rehabilitation paradigm, stepping on a treadmill, and develop conditions that would encourage the brain to begin voluntary control over the leg.With this in mind, we developed a completely new robotic system to support the rat in any direction of space. Imagine, this is really cool. So imagine the little 200-gram rat attached at the extremity of this 200-kilo robot, but the rat does not feel the robot. The robot is transparent, just like you would hold a young child during the first insecure steps.Let me summarize: The rat received a paralyzing lesion of the spinal cord. The electrochemical neuroprosthesis enabled a highly functional state of the spinal locomotor networks. The robot provided the safe environment to allow the rat to attempt anything to engage the paralyzed legs. And for motivation, we used what I think is the most powerful pharmacology of Switzerland: fine Swiss chocolate.(Laughter)Actually, the first results were very, very, very disappointing. Here is my best physical therapist completely failing to encourage the rat to take a single step, whereas the same rat, five minutes earlier, walked beautifully on the treadmill. We were so frustrated.But you know, one of the most essential qualities of a scientist is perseverance. We insisted. We refined our paradigm, and after several months of training, the otherwise paralyzed rat could stand, and whenever she decided, initiated full weight-bearing locomotion to sprint towards the rewards. This is the first recovery ever observed of voluntary leg movement after an experimental lesion of the spinal cord leading to complete and permanent paralysis.In fact —(Applause)Thank you.In fact, not only could the rat initiate and sustain locomotion on the ground, they could even adjust leg movement, for example, to resist gravity in order to climb a staircase. I can promise you this was such an emotional moment in my laboratory. It took us 10 years of hard work to reach this goal.But the remaining question was, how? I mean, how is it possible? And here, what we found was completely unexpected. This novel training paradigm encouraged the brain to create new connections, some relay circuits that relay information from the brain past the injury and restore cortical control over the locomotor networks below the injury. And here, you can see one such example, where we label the fibers coming from the brain in red. This blue neuron is connected with the locomotor center, and what this constellation of synaptic contacts means is that the brain is reconnected with the locomotor center with only one relay neuron. But the remodeling was not restricted to the lesion area. It occurred throughout the central nervous system, including in the brain stem, where we observed up to 300-percent increase in the density of fibers coming from the brain. We did not aim to repair the spinal cord, yet we were able to promote one of the more extensive remodeling of axonal projections ever observed in the central nervous system of adult mammal after an injury.And there is a very important message hidden behind this discovery. They are the result of a young team of very talented people: physical therapists, neurobiologists, neurosurgeons, engineers of all kinds, who have achieved together what would have been impossible by single individuals. This is truly a trans-disciplinary team. They are working so close to each other that there is horizontal transfer of DNA. We are creating the next generation of M.D.'s and engineers capable of translating discoveries all the way from bench to bedside. And me? I am only the maestro who orchestrated this beautiful symphony.Now, I am sure you are all wondering, aren't you, will this help injured people? Me too, every day. The truth is that we don't know enough yet. This is certainly not a cure for spinal cord injury, but I begin to believe that this may lead to an intervention to improve recovery and people's quality of life.I would like you all to take a moment and dream with me. Imagine a person just suffered a spinal cord injury. After a few weeks of recovery, we will implant a programmable pump to deliver a personalized pharmacological cocktail directly to the spinal cord. At the same time, we will implant an electrode array, a sort of second skin covering the area of the spinal cord controlling leg movement, and this array is attached to an electrical pulse generator that delivers stimulations that are tailored to the person's needs. This defines a personalized electrochemical neuroprosthesis that will enable locomotion during training with a newly designed supporting system. And my hope is that after several months of training, there may be enough remodeling of residual connection to allow locomotion without the robot, maybe even without pharmacology or stimulation. My hope here is to be able to create the personalized condition to boost the plasticity of the brain and the spinal cord. And this is a radically new concept that may apply to other neurological disorders, what I termed "personalized neuroprosthetics," where by sensing and stimulating neural interfaces, I implanted throughout the nervous system, in the brain, in the spinal cord, even in peripheral nerves, based on patient-specific impairments. But not to replace the lost function, no — to help the brain help itself.And I hope this enticed your imagination, because I can promise to you this is not a matter of whether this revolution will occur, but when. And remember, we are only as great as our imagination, as big as our dream.Thank you.(Applause)
