00:03:12.004 --> 00:03:15.172
they are in a nonfunctional state, like kind of dormant.

00:03:15.172 --> 00:03:19.504
My idea: We awaken this network.

00:03:19.504 --> 00:03:23.791
And at the time, I was a post-doctoral fellow in Los Angeles,

00:03:23.791 --> 00:03:26.357
after completing my Ph.D. in France,

00:03:26.357 --> 00:03:28.266
where independent thinking

00:03:28.266 --> 00:03:31.373
is not necessarily promoted.

00:03:31.373 --> 00:03:33.200
(Laughter)

00:03:33.200 --> 00:03:36.953
I was afraid to talk to my new boss,

00:03:36.953 --> 00:03:39.346
but decided to muster up my courage.

00:03:39.346 --> 00:03:42.003
I knocked at the door of my wonderful advisor,

00:03:42.003 --> 00:03:45.994
Reggie Edgerton, to share my new idea.

00:03:45.994 --> 00:03:48.244
He listened to me carefully,

00:03:48.244 --> 00:03:51.185
and responded with a grin.

00:03:51.185 --> 00:03:53.228
"Why don't you try?"

00:03:53.228 --> 00:03:55.353
And I promise to you,

00:03:55.353 --> 00:03:58.708
this was such an important moment in my career,

00:03:58.708 --> 00:04:01.143
when I realized that the great leader

00:04:01.143 --> 00:04:04.136
believed in young people and new ideas.

00:04:04.136 --> 00:04:05.744
And this was the idea:

00:04:05.744 --> 00:04:08.410
I'm going to use a simplistic metaphor

00:04:08.410 --> 00:04:10.536
to explain to you this complicated concept.

00:04:10.536 --> 00:04:15.302
Imagine that the locomotor system is a car.

00:04:15.302 --> 00:04:17.548
The engine is the spinal cord.

00:04:17.548 --> 00:04:20.806
The transmission is interrupted. The engine is turned off.

00:04:20.806 --> 00:04:23.813
How could we re-engage the engine?

00:04:23.813 --> 00:04:26.955
First, we have to provide the fuel;

00:04:26.955 --> 00:04:29.298
second, press the accelerator pedal;

00:04:29.298 --> 00:04:31.236
third, steer the car.

00:04:31.236 --> 00:04:32.998
It turned out that there are known neural pathways

00:04:32.998 --> 00:04:35.952
coming from the brain that play this very function

00:04:35.952 --> 00:04:37.334
during locomotion.

00:04:37.334 --> 00:04:40.049
My idea: Replace this missing input

00:04:40.049 --> 00:04:41.451
to provide the spinal cord

00:04:41.451 --> 00:04:42.847
with the kind of intervention

00:04:42.847 --> 00:04:47.577
that the brain would deliver naturally in order to walk.

00:04:47.577 --> 00:04:52.016
For this, I leveraged 20 years of past research in neuroscience,

00:04:52.016 --> 00:04:54.780
first to replace the missing fuel

00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:56.848
with pharmacological agents

00:04:56.848 --> 00:05:00.328
that prepare the neurons in the spinal cord to fire,

00:05:00.328 --> 00:05:04.383
and second, to mimic the accelerator pedal

00:05:04.383 --> 00:05:05.863
with electrical stimulation.

00:05:05.863 --> 00:05:08.032
So here imagine an electrode

00:05:08.032 --> 00:05:10.438
implanted on the back of the spinal cord

00:05:10.438 --> 00:05:12.700
to deliver painless stimulation.

00:05:12.700 --> 00:05:15.532
It took many years, but eventually we developed

00:05:15.532 --> 00:05:18.089
an electrochemical neuroprosthesis

00:05:18.089 --> 00:05:19.855
that transformed the neural network

00:05:19.855 --> 00:05:24.861
in the spinal cord from dormant to a highly functional state.

00:05:24.861 --> 00:05:31.141
Immediately, the paralyzed rat can stand.

00:05:31.141 --> 00:05:33.468
As soon as the treadmill belt starts moving,

00:05:33.468 --> 00:05:37.274
the animal shows coordinated movement of the leg,

00:05:37.274 --> 00:05:39.252
but without the brain.

00:05:39.252 --> 00:05:41.242
Here what I call "the spinal brain"

00:05:41.242 --> 00:05:44.364
cognitively processes sensory information

00:05:44.364 --> 00:05:46.259
arising from the moving leg

00:05:46.259 --> 00:05:49.954
and makes decisions as to how to activate the muscle

00:05:49.954 --> 00:05:53.344
in order to stand, to walk, to run,

00:05:53.344 --> 00:05:55.456
and even here, while sprinting,

00:05:55.456 --> 00:05:57.753
instantly stand

00:05:57.753 --> 00:06:00.216
if the treadmill stops moving.

00:06:00.216 --> 00:06:01.553
This was amazing.

00:06:01.553 --> 00:06:04.940
I was completely fascinated by this locomotion

00:06:04.940 --> 00:06:07.435
without the brain,

00:06:07.435 --> 00:06:11.090
but at the same time so frustrated.

00:06:11.090 --> 00:06:13.483
This locomotion was completely involuntary.

00:06:13.483 --> 00:06:16.848
The animal had virtually no control over the legs.

00:06:16.848 --> 00:06:20.968
Clearly, the steering system was missing.

00:06:20.968 --> 00:06:22.860
And it then became obvious from me

00:06:22.860 --> 00:06:24.208
that we had to move away

00:06:24.208 --> 00:06:27.580
from the classical rehabilitation paradigm,

00:06:27.580 --> 00:06:29.302
stepping on a treadmill,

00:06:29.302 --> 00:06:32.522
and develop conditions that would encourage

00:06:32.522 --> 00:06:37.755
the brain to begin voluntary control over the leg.

00:06:37.755 --> 00:06:41.140
With this in mind, we developed a completely new

00:06:41.140 --> 00:06:44.370
robotic system to support the rat

00:06:44.370 --> 00:06:46.896
in any direction of space.

00:06:46.896 --> 00:06:49.071
Imagine, this is really cool.

00:06:49.071 --> 00:06:52.902
So imagine the little 200-gram rat

00:06:52.902 --> 00:06:56.603
attached at the extremity of this 200-kilo robot,

00:06:56.603 --> 00:06:59.175
but the rat does not feel the robot.

00:06:59.175 --> 00:07:01.247
The robot is transparent,

00:07:01.247 --> 00:07:03.609
just like you would hold a young child

00:07:03.609 --> 00:07:05.973
during the first insecure steps.

00:07:05.973 --> 00:07:09.527
Let me summarize: The rat received

00:07:09.527 --> 00:07:11.972
a paralyzing lesion of the spinal cord.

00:07:11.972 --> 00:07:14.562
The electrochemical neuroprosthesis enabled

00:07:14.562 --> 00:07:18.769
a highly functional state of the spinal locomotor networks.

00:07:18.769 --> 00:07:22.535
The robot provided the safe environment

00:07:22.535 --> 00:07:24.498
to allow the rat to attempt anything

00:07:24.498 --> 00:07:27.180
to engage the paralyzed legs.

00:07:27.180 --> 00:07:30.005
And for motivation, we used what I think

00:07:30.005 --> 00:07:33.839
is the most powerful pharmacology of Switzerland:

00:07:33.839 --> 00:07:36.146
fine Swiss chocolate.

00:07:36.146 --> 00:07:39.068
(Laughter)

00:07:39.068 --> 00:07:43.631
Actually, the first results were very, very,

00:07:43.631 --> 00:07:46.266
very disappointing.

00:07:46.266 --> 00:07:49.568
Here is my best physical therapist

00:07:56.752 --> 00:07:59.342
completely failing to encourage the rat

00:07:59.342 --> 00:08:01.403
to take a single step,

00:08:01.403 --> 00:08:04.249
whereas the same rat, five minutes earlier,

00:08:04.249 --> 00:08:06.555
walked beautifully on the treadmill.

00:08:06.555 --> 00:08:08.712
We were so frustrated.

00:08:08.712 --> 00:08:11.611
But you know, one of the most essential qualities

00:08:11.611 --> 00:08:14.087
of a scientist is perseverance.

00:08:14.087 --> 00:08:17.503
We insisted. We refined our paradigm,

00:08:17.503 --> 00:08:19.766
and after several months of training,

00:08:19.766 --> 00:08:23.572
the otherwise paralyzed rat could stand,

00:08:23.572 --> 00:08:25.384
and whenever she decided,

00:08:25.384 --> 00:08:27.716
initiated full weight-bearing locomotion

00:08:27.716 --> 00:08:30.966
to sprint towards the rewards.

00:08:30.966 --> 00:08:34.371
This is the first recovery ever observed

00:08:34.371 --> 00:08:36.265
of voluntary leg movement

00:08:36.265 --> 00:08:38.719
after an experimental lesion of the spinal cord

00:08:38.719 --> 00:08:42.180
leading to complete and permanent paralysis.

00:08:42.180 --> 00:08:44.167
In fact --

00:08:44.167 --> 00:08:45.887
(Applause)

00:08:45.887 --> 00:08:50.266
Thank you.

00:08:50.266 --> 00:08:53.360
In fact, not only could the rat initiate

00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:56.037
and sustain locomotion on the ground,

00:08:56.037 --> 00:08:58.318
they could even adjust leg movement,

00:08:58.318 --> 00:09:00.674
for example, to resist gravity

00:09:00.674 --> 00:09:03.298
in order to climb a staircase.

00:09:03.298 --> 00:09:05.248
I can promise you this was

00:09:05.248 --> 00:09:08.357
such an emotional moment in my laboratory.

00:09:08.357 --> 00:09:11.100
It took us 10 years of hard work

00:09:11.100 --> 00:09:13.551
to reach this goal.

00:09:13.551 --> 00:09:16.102
But the remaining question was, how?

00:09:16.102 --> 00:09:17.794
I mean, how is it possible?

00:09:17.794 --> 00:09:19.472
And here, what we found

00:09:19.472 --> 00:09:23.148
was completely unexpected.

00:09:23.148 --> 00:09:27.306
This novel training paradigm

00:09:27.306 --> 00:09:30.977
encouraged the brain to create new connections,

00:09:30.977 --> 00:09:33.879
some relay circuits

00:09:33.879 --> 00:09:36.927
that relay information from the brain

00:09:36.927 --> 00:09:40.083
past the injury and restore cortical control

00:09:40.083 --> 00:09:43.524
over the locomotor networks below the injury.

00:09:43.524 --> 00:09:46.446
And here, you can see one such example,

00:09:46.446 --> 00:09:49.809
where we label the fibers coming from the brain in red.

00:09:49.809 --> 00:09:53.229
This blue neuron is connected with the locomotor center,

00:09:53.229 --> 00:09:55.592
and what this constellation

00:09:55.592 --> 00:09:57.943
of synaptic contacts means

00:09:57.943 --> 00:10:01.742
is that the brain is reconnected with the locomotor center

00:10:01.742 --> 00:10:05.740
with only one relay neuron.

00:10:05.740 --> 00:10:07.671
But the remodeling was not restricted

00:10:07.671 --> 00:10:08.758
to the lesion area.

00:10:08.758 --> 00:10:12.047
It occurred throughout the central nervous system,

00:10:12.047 --> 00:10:14.365
including in the brain stem,

00:10:14.365 --> 00:10:17.627
where we observed up to 300-percent increase

00:10:17.627 --> 00:10:21.386
in the density of fibers coming from the brain.

00:10:21.386 --> 00:10:24.913
We did not aim to repair the spinal cord,

00:10:24.913 --> 00:10:27.510
yet we were able to promote

00:10:27.510 --> 00:10:29.667
one of the more extensive remodeling

00:10:29.667 --> 00:10:32.136
of axonal projections ever observed

00:10:32.136 --> 00:10:34.397
in the central nervous system of adult mammal

00:10:34.397 --> 00:10:36.942
after an injury.

00:10:36.942 --> 00:10:42.011
And there is a very important message

00:10:42.011 --> 00:10:46.454
hidden behind this discovery.

00:10:46.454 --> 00:10:49.676
They are the result of a young team

00:10:49.676 --> 00:10:52.068
of very talented people:

00:10:52.068 --> 00:10:56.526
physical therapists, neurobiologists, neurosurgeons,

00:10:56.526 --> 00:10:58.725
engineers of all kinds,

00:10:58.725 --> 00:11:00.516
who have achieved together

00:11:00.516 --> 00:11:04.159
what would have been impossible by single individuals.

00:11:04.159 --> 00:11:07.242
This is truly a trans-disciplinary team.

00:11:07.242 --> 00:11:09.430
They are working so close to each other

00:11:09.430 --> 00:11:12.621
that there is horizontal transfer of DNA.

00:11:12.621 --> 00:11:14.244
We are creating the next generation

00:11:14.244 --> 00:11:16.485
of M.D.'s and engineers

00:11:16.485 --> 00:11:18.929
capable of translating discoveries all the way

00:11:18.929 --> 00:11:21.601
from bench to bedside.

00:11:21.601 --> 00:11:23.607
And me?

00:11:23.607 --> 00:11:28.154
I am only the maestro who orchestrated this beautiful symphony.

00:11:28.154 --> 00:11:34.957
Now, I am sure you are all wondering, aren't you,

00:11:34.957 --> 00:11:38.721
will this help injured people?

00:11:38.721 --> 00:11:42.613
Me too, every day.

00:11:42.613 --> 00:11:46.026
The truth is that we don't know enough yet.

00:11:46.026 --> 00:11:50.250
This is certainly not a cure for spinal cord injury,

00:11:50.250 --> 00:11:52.984
but I begin to believe that this may lead

00:11:52.984 --> 00:11:55.551
to an intervention to improve recovery

00:11:55.551 --> 00:11:58.738
and people's quality of life.

00:11:58.738 --> 00:12:01.227
I would like you all

00:12:01.227 --> 00:12:04.854
to take a moment and dream with me.

00:12:04.854 --> 00:12:10.749
Imagine a person just suffered a spinal cord injury.

00:12:10.749 --> 00:12:13.904
After a few weeks of recovery,

00:12:13.904 --> 00:12:16.264
we will implant a programmable pump

00:12:16.264 --> 00:12:19.297
to deliver a personalized pharmacological cocktail

00:12:19.297 --> 00:12:21.739
directly to the spinal cord.

00:12:21.739 --> 00:12:25.002
At the same time, we will implant an electrode array,

00:12:25.002 --> 00:12:27.109
a sort of second skin

00:12:27.109 --> 00:12:30.669
covering the area of the spinal cord controlling leg movement,

00:12:30.669 --> 00:12:33.935
and this array is attached to an electrical pulse generator

00:12:33.935 --> 00:12:36.397
that delivers stimulations that are tailored

00:12:36.397 --> 00:12:38.583
to the person's needs.

00:12:38.583 --> 00:12:43.441
This defines a personalized electrochemical neuroprosthesis

00:12:43.441 --> 00:12:46.192
that will enable locomotion

00:12:46.192 --> 00:12:50.239
during training with a newly designed supporting system.

00:12:50.239 --> 00:12:53.522
And my hope is that after several months of training,

00:12:53.522 --> 00:12:55.685
there may be enough remodeling of residual connection

00:12:55.685 --> 00:12:59.354
to allow locomotion without the robot,

00:12:59.354 --> 00:13:03.132
maybe even without pharmacology or stimulation.

00:13:03.132 --> 00:13:05.666
My hope here is to be able to create

00:13:05.666 --> 00:13:07.931
the personalized condition

00:13:07.931 --> 00:13:10.594
to boost the plasticity of the brain

00:13:10.594 --> 00:13:12.125
and the spinal cord.

00:13:12.125 --> 00:13:14.864
And this is a radically new concept

00:13:14.864 --> 00:13:18.157
that may apply to other neurological disorders,

00:13:18.157 --> 00:13:22.695
what I termed "personalized neuroprosthetics,"

00:13:22.695 --> 00:13:25.719
where by sensing and stimulating neural interfaces,

00:13:25.719 --> 00:13:29.433
I implanted throughout the nervous system,

00:13:29.433 --> 00:13:32.774
in the brain, in the spinal cord,

00:13:32.774 --> 00:13:35.530
even in peripheral nerves,

00:13:35.530 --> 00:13:38.697
based on patient-specific impairments.

00:13:38.697 --> 00:13:43.305
But not to replace the lost function, no --

00:13:43.305 --> 00:13:46.496
to help the brain help itself.

00:13:46.496 --> 00:13:49.136
And I hope this enticed your imagination,

00:13:49.136 --> 00:13:51.032
because I can promise to you

00:13:51.032 --> 00:13:54.275
this is not a matter of whether this revolution will occur,

00:13:54.275 --> 00:13:56.067
but when.

00:13:56.067 --> 00:13:58.300
And remember, we are only as great

00:13:58.315 --> 00:14:01.900
as our imagination, as big as our dream.

00:14:01.900 --> 00:14:03.892
Thank you.

00:14:03.892 --> 00:14:07.892
(Applause)

title: How the NSA betrayed the world's trust -- time to act
transcript: The two most likely largest inventions of our generation are the Internet and the mobile phone. They've changed the world. However, largely to our surprise, they also turned out to be the perfect tools for the surveillance state. It turned out that the capability to collect data, information and connections about basically any of us and all of us is exactly what we've been hearing throughout of the summer through revelations and leaks about Western intelligence agencies, mostly U.S. intelligence agencies, watching over the rest of the world.We've heard about these starting with the revelations from June 6. Edward Snowden started leaking information, top secret classified information, from the U.S. intelligence agencies, and we started learning about things like PRISM and XKeyscore and others. And these are examples of the kinds of programs U.S. intelligence agencies are running right now, against the whole rest of the world.And if you look back about the forecasts on surveillance by George Orwell, well it turns out that George Orwell was an optimist. (Laughter) We are right now seeing a much larger scale of tracking of individual citizens than he could have ever imagined.And this here is the infamous NSA data center in Utah. Due to be opened very soon, it will be both a supercomputing center and a data storage center. You could basically imagine it has a large hall filled with hard drives storing data they are collecting. And it's a pretty big building. How big? Well, I can give you the numbers — 140,000 square meters — but that doesn't really tell you very much. Maybe it's better to imagine it as a comparison. You think about the largest IKEA store you've ever been in. This is five times larger. How many hard drives can you fit in an IKEA store? Right? It's pretty big. We estimate that just the electricity bill for running this data center is going to be in the tens of millions of dollars a year. And this kind of wholesale surveillance means that they can collect our data and keep it basically forever, keep it for extended periods of time, keep it for years, keep it for decades. And this opens up completely new kinds of risks to us all. And what this is is that it is wholesale blanket surveillance on everyone.Well, not exactly everyone, because the U.S. intelligence only has a legal right to monitor foreigners. They can monitor foreigners when foreigners' data connections end up in the United States or pass through the United States. And monitoring foreigners doesn't sound too bad until you realize that I'm a foreigner and you're a foreigner. In fact, 96 percent of the planet are foreigners.(Laughter)Right?So it is wholesale blanket surveillance of all of us, all of us who use telecommunications and the Internet.But don't get me wrong: There are actually types of surveillance that are okay. I love freedom, but even I agree that some surveillance is fine. If the law enforcement is trying to find a murderer, or they're trying to catch a drug lord or trying to prevent a school shooting, and they have leads and they have suspects, then it's perfectly fine for them to tap the suspect's phone, and to intercept his Internet communications. I'm not arguing that at all, but that's not what programs like PRISM are about. They are not about doing surveillance on people that they have reason to suspect of some wrongdoings. They're about doing surveillance on people they know are innocent.So the four main arguments supporting surveillance like this, well, the first of all is that whenever you start discussing about these revelations, there will be naysayers trying to minimize the importance of these revelations, saying that we knew all this already, we knew it was happening, there's nothing new here. And that's not true. Don't let anybody tell you that we knew this already, because we did not know this already. Our worst fears might have been something like this, but we didn't know this was happening. Now we know for a fact it's happening. We didn't know about this. We didn't know about PRISM. We didn't know about XKeyscore. We didn't know about Cybertrans. We didn't know about DoubleArrow. We did not know about Skywriter — all these different programs run by U.S. intelligence agencies. But now we do.And we did not know that U.S. intelligence agencies go to extremes such as infiltrating standardization bodies to sabotage encryption algorithms on purpose. And what that means is that you take something which is secure, an encryption algorithm which is so secure that if you use that algorithm to encrypt one file, nobody can decrypt that file. Even if they take every single computer on the planet just to decrypt that one file, it's going to take millions of years. So that's basically perfectly safe, uncrackable. You take something which is that good and then you weaken it on purpose, making all of us less secure as an end result. A real-world equivalent would be that intelligence agencies would force some secret pin code into every single house alarm so they could get into every single house because, you know, bad people might have house alarms, but it will also make all of us less secure as an end result. Backdooring encryption algorithms just boggles the mind. But of course, these intelligence agencies are doing their job. This is what they have been told to do: do signals intelligence, monitor telecommunications, monitor Internet traffic. That's what they're trying to do, and since most, a very big part of the Internet traffic today is encrypted, they're trying to find ways around the encryption. One way is to sabotage encryption algorithms, which is a great example about how U.S. intelligence agencies are running loose. They are completely out of control, and they should be brought back under control.So what do we actually know about the leaks? Everything is based on the files leaked by Mr. Snowden. The very first PRISM slides from the beginning of June detail a collection program where the data is collected from service providers, and they actually go and name the service providers they have access to. They even have a specific date on when the collection of data began for each of the service providers. So for example, they name the collection from Microsoft started on September 11, 2007, for Yahoo on the March 12, 2008, and then others: Google, Facebook, Skype, Apple and so on.And every single one of these companies denies. They all say that this simply isn't true, that they are not giving backdoor access to their data. Yet we have these files. So is one of the parties lying, or is there some other alternative explanation? And one explanation would be that these parties, these service providers, are not cooperating. Instead, they've been hacked. That would explain it. They aren't cooperating. They've been hacked. In this case, they've been hacked by their own government. That might sound outlandish, but we already have cases where this has happened, for example, the case of the Flame malware which we strongly believe was authored by the U.S. government, and which, to spread, subverted the security of the Windows Update network, meaning here, the company was hacked by their own government. And there's more evidence supporting this theory as well. Der Spiegel, from Germany, leaked more information about the operations run by the elite hacker units operating inside these intelligence agencies. Inside NSA, the unit is called TAO, Tailored Access Operations, and inside GCHQ, which is the U.K. equivalent, it's called NAC, Network Analysis Centre. And these recent leaks of these three slides detail an operation run by this GCHQ intelligence agency from the United Kingdom targeting a telecom here in Belgium. And what this really means is that an E.U. country's intelligence agency is breaching the security of a telecom of a fellow E.U. country on purpose, and they discuss it in their slides completely casually, business as usual. Here's the primary target, here's the secondary target, here's the teaming. They probably have a team building on Thursday evening in a pub. They even use cheesy PowerPoint clip art like, you know, "Success," when they gain access to services like this. What the hell?And then there's the argument that okay, yes, this might be going on, but then again, other countries are doing it as well. All countries spy. And maybe that's true. Many countries spy, not all of them, but let's take an example. Let's take, for example, Sweden. I'm speaking of Sweden because Sweden has a little bit of a similar law to the United States. When your data traffic goes through Sweden, their intelligence agency has a legal right by the law to intercept that traffic. All right, how many Swedish decisionmakers and politicians and business leaders use, every day, U.S.-based services, like, you know, run Windows or OSX, or use Facebook or LinkedIn, or store their data in clouds like iCloud or Skydrive or DropBox, or maybe use online services like Amazon web services or sales support? And the answer is, every single Swedish business leader does that every single day. And then we turn it around. How many American leaders use Swedish webmails and cloud services? And the answer is zero. So this is not balanced. It's not balanced by any means, not even close.And when we do have the occasional European success story, even those, then, typically end up being sold to the United States. Like, Skype used to be secure. It used to be end-to-end encrypted. Then it was sold to the United States. Today, it no longer is secure. So once again, we take something which is secure and then we make it less secure on purpose, making all of us less secure as an outcome.And then the argument that the United States is only fighting terrorists. It's the war on terror. You shouldn't worry about it. Well, it's not the war on terror. Yes, part of it is war on terror, and yes, there are terrorists, and they do kill and maim, and we should fight them, but we know through these leaks that they have used the same techniques to listen to phone calls of European leaders, to tap the email of residents of Mexico and Brazil, to read email traffic inside the United Nations Headquarters and E.U. Parliament, and I don't think they are trying to find terrorists from inside the E.U. Parliament, right? It's not the war on terror. Part of it might be, and there are terrorists, but are we really thinking about terrorists as such an existential threat that we are willing to do anything at all to fight them? Are the Americans ready to throw away the Constituion and throw it in the trash just because there are terrorists? And the same thing with the Bill of Rights and all the amendments and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the E.U. conventions on human rights and fundamental freedoms and the press freedom? Do we really think terrorism is such an existential threat, we are ready to do anything at all?But people are scared about terrorists, and then they think that maybe that surveillance is okay because they have nothing to hide. Feel free to survey me if that helps. And whoever tells you that they have nothing to hide simply hasn't thought about this long enough.(Applause)Because we have this thing called privacy, and if you really think that you have nothing to hide, please make sure that's the first thing you tell me, because then I know that I should not trust you with any secrets, because obviously you can't keep a secret. But people are brutally honest with the Internet, and when these leaks started, many people were asking me about this. And I have nothing to hide. I'm not doing anything bad or anything illegal. Yet, I have nothing that I would in particular like to share with an intelligence agency, especially a foreign intelligence agency. And if we indeed need a Big Brother, I would much rather have a domestic Big Brother than a foreign Big Brother. And when the leaks started, the very first thing I tweeted about this was a comment about how, when you've been using search engines, you've been potentially leaking all that to U.S. intelligence. And two minutes later, I got a reply by somebody called Kimberly from the United States challenging me, like, why am I worried about this? What am I sending to worry about this? Am I sending naked pictures or something? And my answer to Kimberly was that what I'm sending is none of your business, and it should be none of your government's business either. Because that's what it's about. It's about privacy. Privacy is nonnegotiable. It should be built in to all the systems we use.(Applause)And one thing we should all understand is that we are brutally honest with search engines. You show me your search history, and I'll find something incriminating or something embarrassing there in five minutes. We are more honest with search engines than we are with our families. Search engines know more about you than your family members know about you. And this is all the kind of information we are giving away, we are giving away to the United States.And surveillance changes history. We know this through examples of corrupt presidents like Nixon. Imagine if he would have had the kind of surveillance tools that are available today. And let me actually quote the president of Brazil, Ms. Dilma Rousseff. She was one of the targets of NSA surveillance. Her email was read, and she spoke at the United Nations Headquarters, and she said, "If there is no right to privacy, there can be no true freedom of expression and opinion, and therefore, there can be no effective democracy."That's what it's about. Privacy is the building block of our democracies. And to quote a fellow security researcher, Marcus Ranum, he said that the United States is right now treating the Internet as it would be treating one of its colonies. So we are back to the age of colonization, and we, the foreign users of the Internet, we should think about Americans as our masters.So Mr. Snowden, he's been blamed for many things. Some are blaming him for causing problems for the U.S. cloud industry and software companies with these revelations — and blaming Snowden for causing problems for the U.S. cloud industry would be the equivalent of blaming Al Gore for causing global warming.(Laughter)(Applause)So, what is there to be done? Should we worry. No, we shouldn't worry. We should be angry, because this is wrong, and it's rude, and it should not be done. But that's not going to really change the situation. What's going to change the situation for the rest of the world is to try to steer away from systems built in the United States. And that's much easier said than done. How do you do that? A single country, any single country in Europe cannot replace and build replacements for the U.S.-made operating systems and cloud services.But maybe you don't have to do it alone. Maybe you can do it together with other countries. The solution is open source. By building together open, free, secure systems, we can go around such surveillance, and then one country doesn't have to solve the problem by itself. It only has to solve one little problem. And to quote a fellow security researcher, Haroon Meer, one country only has to make a small wave, but those small waves together become a tide, and the tide will lift all the boats up at the same time, and the tide we will build with secure, free, open-source systems, will become the tide that will lift all of us up and above the surveillance state.Thank you very much.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.450 --> 00:00:17.084
The two most likely largest inventions

00:00:17.084 --> 00:00:19.331
of our generation

00:00:19.331 --> 00:00:22.524
are the Internet and the mobile phone.

00:00:22.524 --> 00:00:24.659
They've changed the world.

00:00:24.659 --> 00:00:28.174
However, largely to our surprise,

00:00:28.174 --> 00:00:32.572
they also turned out to be the perfect tools

00:00:32.572 --> 00:00:35.722
for the surveillance state.

00:00:35.722 --> 00:00:38.619
It turned out that the capability

00:00:38.619 --> 00:00:42.663
to collect data, information and connections

00:00:42.663 --> 00:00:46.881
about basically any of us and all of us

00:00:46.881 --> 00:00:48.694
is exactly what we've been hearing

00:00:48.694 --> 00:00:53.301
throughout of the summer
through revelations and leaks

00:00:53.301 --> 00:00:56.392
about Western intelligence agencies,

00:00:56.392 --> 00:00:59.418
mostly U.S. intelligence agencies,

00:00:59.418 --> 00:01:02.591
watching over the rest of the world.

00:01:02.591 --> 00:01:05.789
We've heard about these starting with the

00:01:05.789 --> 00:01:09.475
revelations from June 6.

00:01:09.475 --> 00:01:12.544
Edward Snowden started leaking information,

00:01:12.544 --> 00:01:14.848
top secret classified information,

00:01:14.848 --> 00:01:16.315
from the U.S. intelligence agencies,

00:01:16.315 --> 00:01:18.784
and we started learning about things like PRISM

00:01:18.784 --> 00:01:22.051
and XKeyscore and others.

00:01:22.051 --> 00:01:25.156
And these are examples of the kinds of programs

00:01:25.156 --> 00:01:29.435
U.S. intelligence agencies are running right now,

00:01:29.435 --> 00:01:32.951
against the whole rest of the world.

00:01:32.951 --> 00:01:36.659
And if you look back about the forecasts

00:01:36.659 --> 00:01:40.760
on surveillance by George Orwell,

00:01:40.775 --> 00:01:42.893
well it turns out that

00:01:42.893 --> 00:01:45.397
George Orwell was an optimist.

00:01:45.397 --> 00:01:47.877
(Laughter)

00:01:47.877 --> 00:01:50.577
We are right now seeing a much larger scale

00:01:50.577 --> 00:01:52.475
of tracking of individual citizens

00:01:52.475 --> 00:01:56.107
than he could have ever imagined.

00:01:56.107 --> 00:01:59.642
And this here is the infamous

00:01:59.642 --> 00:02:03.486
NSA data center in Utah.

00:02:03.486 --> 00:02:06.642
Due to be opened very soon,

00:02:06.642 --> 00:02:09.433
it will be both a supercomputing center

00:02:09.433 --> 00:02:11.570
and a data storage center.

00:02:11.570 --> 00:02:14.463
You could basically imagine it has a large hall

00:02:14.463 --> 00:02:16.919
filled with hard drives storing data

00:02:16.919 --> 00:02:19.193
they are collecting.

00:02:19.193 --> 00:02:21.350
And it's a pretty big building.

00:02:21.350 --> 00:02:23.201
How big? Well, I can give you the numbers --

00:02:23.201 --> 00:02:25.223
140,000 square meters --

00:02:25.223 --> 00:02:27.829
but that doesn't really tell you very much.

00:02:27.829 --> 00:02:31.005
Maybe it's better to imagine it as a comparison.

00:02:31.005 --> 00:02:33.461
You think about the largest IKEA store

00:02:33.461 --> 00:02:35.208
you've ever been in.

00:02:35.208 --> 00:02:38.677
This is five times larger.

00:02:38.677 --> 00:02:41.753
How many hard drives can you fit in an IKEA store?

00:02:41.753 --> 00:02:43.760
Right? It's pretty big.

00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:46.606
We estimate that just the electricity bill

00:02:46.606 --> 00:02:48.482
for running this data center

00:02:48.482 --> 00:02:51.880
is going to be in the tens of millions of dollars a year.

00:02:51.880 --> 00:02:54.389
And this kind of wholesale surveillance

00:02:54.389 --> 00:02:57.125
means that they can collect our data

00:02:57.125 --> 00:02:59.128
and keep it basically forever,

00:02:59.128 --> 00:03:01.637
keep it for extended periods of time,

00:03:01.637 --> 00:03:04.883
keep it for years, keep it for decades.

00:03:04.883 --> 00:03:08.262
And this opens up completely new kinds of risks

00:03:08.262 --> 00:03:10.208
to us all.

00:03:10.208 --> 00:03:13.836
And what this is is that it is wholesale

00:03:13.836 --> 00:03:18.693
blanket surveillance on everyone.

00:03:18.693 --> 00:03:20.247
Well, not exactly everyone,

00:03:20.247 --> 00:03:24.275
because the U.S. intelligence only has a legal right

00:03:24.275 --> 00:03:26.245
to monitor foreigners.

00:03:26.245 --> 00:03:27.995
They can monitor foreigners

00:03:27.995 --> 00:03:30.805
when foreigners' data connections

00:03:30.805 --> 00:03:34.295
end up in the United States or pass
through the United States.

00:03:34.295 --> 00:03:37.079
And monitoring foreigners doesn't sound too bad

00:03:37.079 --> 00:03:39.446
until you realize

00:03:39.446 --> 00:03:42.447
that I'm a foreigner and you're a foreigner.

00:03:42.447 --> 00:03:46.233
In fact, 96 percent of the planet are foreigners.

00:03:46.233 --> 00:03:47.903
(Laughter)

00:03:47.903 --> 00:03:49.790
Right?

00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:54.239
So it is wholesale blanket surveillance of all of us,

00:03:54.239 --> 00:03:58.341
all of us who use telecommunications and the Internet.

00:03:58.341 --> 00:04:00.232
But don't get me wrong:

00:04:00.232 --> 00:04:05.458
There are actually types
of surveillance that are okay.

00:04:05.458 --> 00:04:08.487
I love freedom, but even I agree

00:04:08.487 --> 00:04:10.766
that some surveillance is fine.

00:04:10.766 --> 00:04:14.669
If the law enforcement is trying to find a murderer,

00:04:14.669 --> 00:04:17.771
or they're trying to catch a drug lord

00:04:17.771 --> 00:04:21.375
or trying to prevent a school shooting,

00:04:21.375 --> 00:04:23.052
and they have leads and they have suspects,

00:04:23.052 --> 00:04:26.769
then it's perfectly fine for them
to tap the suspect's phone,

00:04:26.769 --> 00:04:30.125
and to intercept his Internet communications.

00:04:30.125 --> 00:04:32.063
I'm not arguing that at all,

00:04:32.063 --> 00:04:34.887
but that's not what programs like PRISM are about.

00:04:34.887 --> 00:04:37.772
They are not about doing surveillance on people

00:04:37.772 --> 00:04:40.976
that they have reason
to suspect of some wrongdoings.

00:04:40.976 --> 00:04:42.653
They're about doing surveillance on people

00:04:42.653 --> 00:04:46.413
they know are innocent.

00:04:46.413 --> 00:04:48.658
So the four main arguments

00:04:48.658 --> 00:04:50.810
supporting surveillance like this,

00:04:50.810 --> 00:04:53.045
well, the first of all is that whenever you start

00:04:53.045 --> 00:04:54.940
discussing about these revelations,

00:04:54.940 --> 00:04:57.233
there will be naysayers trying to minimize

00:04:57.233 --> 00:04:59.421
the importance of these revelations, saying that

00:04:59.421 --> 00:05:01.034
we knew all this already,

00:05:01.034 --> 00:05:04.614
we knew it was happening, there's nothing new here.

00:05:04.614 --> 00:05:07.829
And that's not true. Don't let anybody tell you

00:05:07.829 --> 00:05:13.541
that we knew this already,
because we did not know this already.

00:05:13.541 --> 00:05:17.314
Our worst fears might have been something like this,

00:05:17.314 --> 00:05:19.265
but we didn't know this was happening.

00:05:19.265 --> 00:05:22.042
Now we know for a fact it's happening.

00:05:22.042 --> 00:05:24.621
We didn't know about this.
We didn't know about PRISM.

00:05:24.621 --> 00:05:27.527
We didn't know about XKeyscore.
We didn't know about Cybertrans.

00:05:27.527 --> 00:05:29.477
We didn't know about DoubleArrow.

00:05:29.477 --> 00:05:31.625
We did not know about Skywriter --

00:05:31.625 --> 00:05:33.320
all these different programs

00:05:33.320 --> 00:05:36.561
run by U.S. intelligence agencies.

00:05:36.561 --> 00:05:39.590
But now we do.

00:05:39.590 --> 00:05:41.756
And we did not know

00:05:41.756 --> 00:05:44.831
that U.S. intelligence agencies go to extremes

00:05:44.831 --> 00:05:48.668
such as infiltrating standardization bodies

00:05:48.668 --> 00:05:53.416
to sabotage encryption algorithms on purpose.

00:05:53.416 --> 00:05:55.453
And what that means

00:05:55.453 --> 00:05:57.273
is that you take something which is secure,

00:05:57.273 --> 00:05:59.694
an encryption algorithm which is so secure

00:05:59.694 --> 00:06:02.801
that if you use that algorithm to encrypt one file,

00:06:02.801 --> 00:06:04.543
nobody can decrypt that file.

00:06:04.543 --> 00:06:08.956
Even if they take every single computer on the planet just to decrypt that one file,

00:06:08.956 --> 00:06:11.016
it's going to take millions of years.

00:06:11.016 --> 00:06:13.263
So that's basically perfectly safe, uncrackable.

00:06:13.263 --> 00:06:15.337
You take something which is that good

00:06:15.337 --> 00:06:17.821
and then you weaken it on purpose,

00:06:17.821 --> 00:06:23.431
making all of us less secure as an end result.

00:06:23.431 --> 00:06:25.562
A real-world equivalent would be that

00:06:25.562 --> 00:06:28.214
intelligence agencies would force

00:06:28.214 --> 00:06:31.041
some secret pin code into every single house alarm

00:06:31.041 --> 00:06:32.834
so they could get into every single house

00:06:32.834 --> 00:06:35.080
because, you know, bad people
might have house alarms,

00:06:35.080 --> 00:06:37.519
but it will also make all of us

00:06:37.519 --> 00:06:39.748
less secure as an end result.

00:06:39.748 --> 00:06:43.488
Backdooring encryption algorithms

00:06:43.488 --> 00:06:46.584
just boggles the mind.

00:06:46.584 --> 00:06:50.359
But of course, these intelligence agencies
are doing their job.

00:06:50.359 --> 00:06:52.116
This is what they have been told to do:

00:06:52.116 --> 00:06:54.346
do signals intelligence,

00:06:54.346 --> 00:06:56.358
monitor telecommunications,

00:06:56.358 --> 00:06:57.780
monitor Internet traffic.

00:06:57.780 --> 00:06:59.488
That's what they're trying to do,

00:06:59.488 --> 00:07:02.570
and since most, a very big part
of the Internet traffic today is encrypted,

00:07:02.570 --> 00:07:04.527
they're trying to find ways around the encryption.

00:07:04.527 --> 00:07:07.584
One way is to sabotage encryption algorithms,

00:07:07.584 --> 00:07:09.469
which is a great example

00:07:09.469 --> 00:07:11.690
about how U.S. intelligence agencies

00:07:11.690 --> 00:07:13.439
are running loose.

00:07:13.439 --> 00:07:15.280
They are completely out of control,

00:07:15.280 --> 00:07:19.722
and they should be brought back under control.

00:07:21.587 --> 00:07:24.537
So what do we actually know about the leaks?

00:07:24.537 --> 00:07:26.647
Everything is based on the files

00:07:26.647 --> 00:07:29.145
leaked by Mr. Snowden.

00:07:29.145 --> 00:07:31.993
The very first PRISM slides

00:07:31.993 --> 00:07:33.982
from the beginning of June

00:07:33.982 --> 00:07:36.076
detail a collection program where the data

00:07:36.076 --> 00:07:37.862
is collected from service providers,

00:07:37.862 --> 00:07:40.740
and they actually go and name the service providers

00:07:40.740 --> 00:07:42.071
they have access to.

00:07:42.071 --> 00:07:45.013
They even have a specific date

00:07:45.013 --> 00:07:47.677
on when the collection of data began

00:07:47.677 --> 00:07:49.316
for each of the service providers.

00:07:49.316 --> 00:07:51.603
So for example, they name
the collection from Microsoft

00:07:51.603 --> 00:07:55.323
started on September 11, 2007,

00:07:55.323 --> 00:07:58.055
for Yahoo on the March 12, 2008,

00:07:58.055 --> 00:08:01.071
and then others: Google, Facebook,

00:08:01.071 --> 00:08:04.315
Skype, Apple and so on.

00:08:04.315 --> 00:08:07.163
And every single one of these companies denies.

00:08:07.163 --> 00:08:11.558
They all say that this simply isn't true,

00:08:11.558 --> 00:08:16.166
that they are not giving
backdoor access to their data.

00:08:16.166 --> 00:08:20.289
Yet we have these files.

00:08:20.289 --> 00:08:22.610
So is one of the parties lying,

00:08:22.610 --> 00:08:25.933
or is there some other alternative explanation?

00:08:25.933 --> 00:08:28.855
And one explanation would be

00:08:28.855 --> 00:08:31.742
that these parties, these service providers,

00:08:31.742 --> 00:08:33.658
are not cooperating.

00:08:33.658 --> 00:08:36.679
Instead, they've been hacked.

00:08:36.679 --> 00:08:39.896
That would explain it. They aren't cooperating. They've been hacked.

00:08:39.896 --> 00:08:44.074
In this case, they've been hacked
by their own government.

00:08:44.074 --> 00:08:46.495
That might sound outlandish,

00:08:46.495 --> 00:08:48.709
but we already have cases where this has happened,

00:08:48.709 --> 00:08:51.755
for example, the case of the Flame malware

00:08:51.755 --> 00:08:53.788
which we strongly believe was authored

00:08:53.788 --> 00:08:55.685
by the U.S. government,

00:08:55.685 --> 00:08:59.584
and which, to spread, subverted the security

00:08:59.584 --> 00:09:02.470
of the Windows Update network,

00:09:02.470 --> 00:09:06.563
meaning here, the company was hacked

00:09:06.563 --> 00:09:08.921
by their own government.

00:09:08.921 --> 00:09:10.520
And there's more evidence

00:09:10.520 --> 00:09:13.071
supporting this theory as well.

00:09:13.071 --> 00:09:17.076
Der Spiegel, from Germany, leaked more information

00:09:17.076 --> 00:09:21.341
about the operations run by the elite hacker units

00:09:21.341 --> 00:09:24.376
operating inside these intelligence agencies.

00:09:24.376 --> 00:09:27.002
Inside NSA, the unit is called TAO,

00:09:27.002 --> 00:09:28.847
Tailored Access Operations,

00:09:28.847 --> 00:09:32.411
and inside GCHQ, which is the U.K. equivalent,

00:09:32.411 --> 00:09:36.410
it's called NAC, Network Analysis Centre.

00:09:36.410 --> 00:09:40.254
And these recent leaks of these three slides

00:09:40.254 --> 00:09:42.458
detail an operation

00:09:42.458 --> 00:09:45.616
run by this GCHQ intelligence agency

00:09:45.616 --> 00:09:47.425
from the United Kingdom

00:09:47.425 --> 00:09:51.658
targeting a telecom here in Belgium.

00:09:51.658 --> 00:09:53.934
And what this really means

00:09:53.934 --> 00:09:57.822
is that an E.U. country's intelligence agency

00:09:57.822 --> 00:10:00.037
is breaching the security

00:10:00.037 --> 00:10:04.850
of a telecom of a fellow E.U. country on purpose,

00:10:04.850 --> 00:10:08.685
and they discuss it in their slides completely casually,

00:10:08.685 --> 00:10:10.286
business as usual.

00:10:10.286 --> 00:10:11.954
Here's the primary target,

00:10:11.954 --> 00:10:13.332
here's the secondary target,

00:10:13.332 --> 00:10:14.756
here's the teaming.

00:10:14.756 --> 00:10:18.612
They probably have a team building
on Thursday evening in a pub.

00:10:18.612 --> 00:10:21.653
They even use cheesy PowerPoint clip art

00:10:21.653 --> 00:10:23.360
like, you know, "Success,"

00:10:23.360 --> 00:10:26.624
when they gain access to services like this.

00:10:26.624 --> 00:10:29.450
What the hell?

00:10:31.643 --> 00:10:33.476
And then there's the argument

00:10:33.476 --> 00:10:35.136
that okay, yes, this might be going on,

00:10:35.136 --> 00:10:37.773
but then again, other countries are doing it as well.

00:10:37.773 --> 00:10:40.196
All countries spy.

00:10:40.196 --> 00:10:41.934
And maybe that's true.

00:10:41.934 --> 00:10:44.372
Many countries spy, not all of them,
but let's take an example.

00:10:44.372 --> 00:10:46.483
Let's take, for example, Sweden.

00:10:46.483 --> 00:10:47.859
I'm speaking of Sweden because Sweden

00:10:47.859 --> 00:10:50.138
has a little bit of a similar law to the United States.

00:10:50.138 --> 00:10:52.261
When your data traffic goes through Sweden,

00:10:52.261 --> 00:10:55.071
their intelligence agency has a legal right by the law

00:10:55.071 --> 00:10:57.072
to intercept that traffic.

00:10:57.072 --> 00:11:00.277
All right, how many Swedish decisionmakers

00:11:00.277 --> 00:11:03.149
and politicians and business leaders

00:11:03.149 --> 00:11:06.222
use, every day, U.S.-based services,

00:11:06.222 --> 00:11:09.490
like, you know, run Windows or OSX,

00:11:09.490 --> 00:11:11.700
or use Facebook or LinkedIn,

00:11:11.700 --> 00:11:15.100
or store their data in clouds like iCloud

00:11:15.100 --> 00:11:18.994
or Skydrive or DropBox,

00:11:18.994 --> 00:11:23.297
or maybe use online services like
Amazon web services or sales support?

00:11:23.297 --> 00:11:27.254
And the answer is, every single Swedish
business leader does that every single day.

00:11:27.254 --> 00:11:28.853
And then we turn it around.

00:11:28.853 --> 00:11:30.758
How many American leaders

00:11:30.758 --> 00:11:35.051
use Swedish webmails and cloud services?

00:11:35.051 --> 00:11:37.091
And the answer is zero.

00:11:37.091 --> 00:11:39.360
So this is not balanced.

00:11:39.360 --> 00:11:43.985
It's not balanced by any means, not even close.

00:11:43.985 --> 00:11:46.426
And when we do have the occasional

00:11:46.426 --> 00:11:48.427
European success story,

00:11:48.427 --> 00:11:51.993
even those, then, typically end up being sold
to the United States.

00:11:51.993 --> 00:11:54.257
Like, Skype used to be secure.

00:11:54.257 --> 00:11:56.990
It used to be end-to-end encrypted.

00:11:56.990 --> 00:11:59.031
Then it was sold to the United States.

00:11:59.031 --> 00:12:01.680
Today, it no longer is secure.

00:12:01.680 --> 00:12:04.901
So once again, we take something which is secure

00:12:04.901 --> 00:12:06.771
and then we make it less secure on purpose,

00:12:06.771 --> 00:12:11.255
making all of us less secure as an outcome.

00:12:12.813 --> 00:12:15.060
And then the argument that the United States

00:12:15.060 --> 00:12:17.078
is only fighting terrorists.

00:12:17.078 --> 00:12:18.244
It's the war on terror.

00:12:18.244 --> 00:12:20.791
You shouldn't worry about it.

00:12:20.791 --> 00:12:23.021
Well, it's not the war on terror.

00:12:23.021 --> 00:12:25.194
Yes, part of it is war on terror, and yes,

00:12:25.194 --> 00:12:28.170
there are terrorists, and they do kill and maim,

00:12:28.170 --> 00:12:29.721
and we should fight them,

00:12:29.721 --> 00:12:31.327
but we know through these leaks

00:12:31.327 --> 00:12:33.909
that they have used the same techniques

00:12:33.909 --> 00:12:37.245
to listen to phone calls of European leaders,

00:12:37.245 --> 00:12:40.700
to tap the email of residents of Mexico and Brazil,

00:12:40.700 --> 00:12:45.506
to read email traffic inside the United Nations Headquarters and E.U. Parliament,

00:12:45.506 --> 00:12:48.660
and I don't think they are trying to find terrorists

00:12:48.660 --> 00:12:51.678
from inside the E.U. Parliament, right?

00:12:51.678 --> 00:12:53.626
It's not the war on terror.

00:12:53.626 --> 00:12:57.768
Part of it might be, and there are terrorists,

00:12:57.768 --> 00:13:00.195
but are we really thinking about terrorists

00:13:00.195 --> 00:13:02.364
as such an existential threat

00:13:02.364 --> 00:13:06.040
that we are willing to do anything at all to fight them?

00:13:06.040 --> 00:13:09.531
Are the Americans ready
to throw away the Constituion

00:13:09.531 --> 00:13:13.772
and throw it in the trash
just because there are terrorists?

00:13:13.772 --> 00:13:16.296
And the same thing with the Bill of Rights
and all the amendments

00:13:16.296 --> 00:13:18.613
and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights

00:13:18.613 --> 00:13:23.764
and the E.U. conventions on human rights
and fundamental freedoms

00:13:23.764 --> 00:13:25.281
and the press freedom?

00:13:25.281 --> 00:13:29.096
Do we really think terrorism
is such an existential threat,

00:13:29.096 --> 00:13:32.222
we are ready to do anything at all?

00:13:34.448 --> 00:13:37.112
But people are scared about terrorists,

00:13:37.112 --> 00:13:39.526
and then they think that
maybe that surveillance is okay

00:13:39.526 --> 00:13:41.570
because they have nothing to hide.

00:13:41.570 --> 00:13:44.277
Feel free to survey me if that helps.

00:13:44.277 --> 00:13:47.165
And whoever tells you that they have nothing to hide

00:13:47.165 --> 00:13:51.878
simply hasn't thought about this long enough.

00:13:54.478 --> 00:14:00.343
(Applause)

00:14:00.343 --> 00:14:03.115
Because we have this thing called privacy,

00:14:03.115 --> 00:14:05.460
and if you really think that you have nothing to hide,

00:14:05.460 --> 00:14:07.676
please make sure that's the first thing you tell me,

00:14:07.676 --> 00:14:09.226
because then I know

00:14:09.226 --> 00:14:10.866
that I should not trust you with any secrets,

00:14:10.866 --> 00:14:14.164
because obviously you can't keep a secret.

00:14:17.023 --> 00:14:20.852
But people are brutally honest with the Internet,

00:14:20.852 --> 00:14:23.548
and when these leaks started,

00:14:23.548 --> 00:14:25.426
many people were asking me about this.

00:14:25.426 --> 00:14:27.000
And I have nothing to hide.

00:14:27.000 --> 00:14:30.290
I'm not doing anything bad or anything illegal.

00:14:30.290 --> 00:14:33.075
Yet, I have nothing that I would in particular

00:14:33.075 --> 00:14:35.868
like to share with an intelligence agency,

00:14:35.868 --> 00:14:40.005
especially a foreign intelligence agency.

00:14:40.005 --> 00:14:42.860
And if we indeed need a Big Brother,

00:14:42.860 --> 00:14:46.338
I would much rather have a domestic Big Brother

00:14:46.338 --> 00:14:49.498
than a foreign Big Brother.

00:14:49.503 --> 00:14:54.562
And when the leaks started,
the very first thing I tweeted about this

00:14:54.562 --> 00:14:56.636
was a comment about how,

00:14:56.636 --> 00:14:58.324
when you've been using search engines,

00:14:58.324 --> 00:15:01.973
you've been potentially leaking all that
to U.S. intelligence.

00:15:01.973 --> 00:15:03.945
And two minutes later, I got a reply

00:15:03.945 --> 00:15:06.281
by somebody called Kimberly from the United States

00:15:06.281 --> 00:15:08.448
challenging me, like, why am I worried about this?

00:15:08.461 --> 00:15:12.493
What am I sending to worry about this?
Am I sending naked pictures or something?

00:15:12.493 --> 00:15:14.461
And my answer to Kimberly was

00:15:14.461 --> 00:15:17.490
that what I'm sending is none of your business,

00:15:17.490 --> 00:15:21.755
and it should be none
of your government's business either.

00:15:21.755 --> 00:15:24.007
Because that's what it's about. It's about privacy.

00:15:24.007 --> 00:15:25.921
Privacy is nonnegotiable.

00:15:25.921 --> 00:15:29.881
It should be built in to all the systems we use.

00:15:31.926 --> 00:15:35.504
(Applause)

00:15:38.788 --> 00:15:41.407
And one thing we should all understand

00:15:41.407 --> 00:15:46.006
is that we are brutally honest with search engines.

00:15:46.006 --> 00:15:48.757
You show me your search history,

00:15:48.757 --> 00:15:51.123
and I'll find something incriminating

00:15:51.123 --> 00:15:54.560
or something embarrassing there in five minutes.

00:15:54.560 --> 00:15:56.348
We are more honest with search engines

00:15:56.348 --> 00:15:58.110
than we are with our families.

00:15:58.110 --> 00:16:00.201
Search engines know more about you

00:16:00.201 --> 00:16:02.967
than your family members know about you.

00:16:02.967 --> 00:16:06.055
And this is all the kind
of information we are giving away,

00:16:06.055 --> 00:16:10.430
we are giving away to the United States.

00:16:10.430 --> 00:16:12.908
And surveillance changes history.

00:16:12.908 --> 00:16:16.117
We know this through examples
of corrupt presidents like Nixon.

00:16:16.117 --> 00:16:20.589
Imagine if he would have had the kind
of surveillance tools that are available today.

00:16:20.589 --> 00:16:22.898
And let me actually quote

00:16:22.898 --> 00:16:26.031
the president of Brazil, Ms. Dilma Rousseff.

00:16:26.031 --> 00:16:29.317
She was one of the targets of NSA surveillance.

00:16:29.317 --> 00:16:31.593
Her email was read, and she spoke

00:16:31.593 --> 00:16:34.616
at the United Nations Headquarters, and she said,

00:16:34.616 --> 00:16:36.629
"If there is no right to privacy,

00:16:36.629 --> 00:16:39.456
there can be no true freedom
of expression and opinion,

00:16:39.456 --> 00:16:44.567
and therefore, there can be no effective democracy."

00:16:44.567 --> 00:16:46.912
That's what it's about.

00:16:46.912 --> 00:16:50.780
Privacy is the building block of our democracies.

00:16:52.569 --> 00:16:56.034
And to quote a fellow security researcher, Marcus Ranum,

00:16:56.034 --> 00:16:59.861
he said that the United States
is right now treating the Internet

00:16:59.861 --> 00:17:02.954
as it would be treating one of its colonies.

00:17:02.954 --> 00:17:05.519
So we are back to the age of colonization,

00:17:05.519 --> 00:17:08.581
and we, the foreign users of the Internet,

00:17:08.581 --> 00:17:12.286
we should think about Americans as our masters.

00:17:14.963 --> 00:17:18.938
So Mr. Snowden, he's been blamed for many things.

00:17:18.938 --> 00:17:21.592
Some are blaming him for causing problems

00:17:21.592 --> 00:17:24.783
for the U.S. cloud industry
and software companies with these revelations --

00:17:24.783 --> 00:17:29.079
and blaming Snowden for causing problems
for the U.S. cloud industry

00:17:29.079 --> 00:17:31.538
would be the equivalent of blaming Al Gore

00:17:31.538 --> 00:17:33.855
for causing global warming.

00:17:33.855 --> 00:17:36.109
(Laughter)

00:17:36.109 --> 00:17:41.180
(Applause)

00:17:43.811 --> 00:17:50.019
So, what is there to be done?

00:17:50.019 --> 00:17:51.799
Should we worry. No, we shouldn't worry.

00:17:51.799 --> 00:17:54.235
We should be angry, because this is wrong,

00:17:54.235 --> 00:17:56.974
and it's rude, and it should not be done.

00:17:56.974 --> 00:17:59.242
But that's not going to really change the situation.

00:17:59.242 --> 00:18:02.463
What's going to change the situation
for the rest of the world

00:18:02.463 --> 00:18:04.745
is to try to steer away

00:18:04.745 --> 00:18:07.378
from systems built in the United States.

00:18:07.378 --> 00:18:10.008
And that's much easier said than done.

00:18:10.008 --> 00:18:11.717
How do you do that?

00:18:11.717 --> 00:18:13.516
A single country, any single country in Europe

00:18:13.516 --> 00:18:16.309
cannot replace and build replacements

00:18:16.309 --> 00:18:19.071
for the U.S.-made operating systems
and cloud services.

00:18:19.071 --> 00:18:20.964
But maybe you don't have to do it alone.

00:18:20.964 --> 00:18:22.733
Maybe you can do it together with other countries.

00:18:22.733 --> 00:18:26.229
The solution is open source.

00:18:26.229 --> 00:18:31.842
By building together open, free, secure systems,

00:18:31.842 --> 00:18:34.950
we can go around such surveillance,

00:18:34.950 --> 00:18:38.173
and then one country doesn't have
to solve the problem by itself.

00:18:38.173 --> 00:18:40.645
It only has to solve one little problem.

00:18:40.645 --> 00:18:46.168
And to quote a fellow security researcher, Haroon Meer,

00:18:46.168 --> 00:18:49.137
one country only has to make a small wave,

00:18:49.137 --> 00:18:52.604
but those small waves together become a tide,

00:18:52.604 --> 00:18:56.224
and the tide will lift all the boats up at the same time,

00:18:56.224 --> 00:18:57.875
and the tide we will build

00:18:57.875 --> 00:19:01.316
with secure, free, open-source systems,

00:19:01.316 --> 00:19:03.715
will become the tide that will lift all of us

00:19:03.715 --> 00:19:09.297
up and above the surveillance state.

00:19:09.297 --> 00:19:11.409
Thank you very much.

00:19:11.409 --> 00:19:13.807
(Applause)

title: The magic of Fibonacci numbers
transcript: So why do we learn mathematics? Essentially, for three reasons: calculation, application, and last, and unfortunately least in terms of the time we give it, inspiration.Mathematics is the science of patterns, and we study it to learn how to think logically, critically and creatively, but too much of the mathematics that we learn in school is not effectively motivated, and when our students ask, "Why are we learning this?" then they often hear that they'll need it in an upcoming math class or on a future test. But wouldn't it be great if every once in a while we did mathematics simply because it was fun or beautiful or because it excited the mind? Now, I know many people have not had the opportunity to see how this can happen, so let me give you a quick example with my favorite collection of numbers, the Fibonacci numbers. (Applause)Yeah! I already have Fibonacci fans here. That's great.Now these numbers can be appreciated in many different ways. From the standpoint of calculation, they're as easy to understand as one plus one, which is two. Then one plus two is three, two plus three is five, three plus five is eight, and so on. Indeed, the person we call Fibonacci was actually named Leonardo of Pisa, and these numbers appear in his book "Liber Abaci," which taught the Western world the methods of arithmetic that we use today. In terms of applications, Fibonacci numbers appear in nature surprisingly often. The number of petals on a flower is typically a Fibonacci number, or the number of spirals on a sunflower or a pineapple tends to be a Fibonacci number as well.In fact, there are many more applications of Fibonacci numbers, but what I find most inspirational about them are the beautiful number patterns they display. Let me show you one of my favorites. Suppose you like to square numbers, and frankly, who doesn't? (Laughter)Let's look at the squares of the first few Fibonacci numbers. So one squared is one, two squared is four, three squared is nine, five squared is 25, and so on. Now, it's no surprise that when you add consecutive Fibonacci numbers, you get the next Fibonacci number. Right? That's how they're created. But you wouldn't expect anything special to happen when you add the squares together. But check this out. One plus one gives us two, and one plus four gives us five. And four plus nine is 13, nine plus 25 is 34, and yes, the pattern continues.In fact, here's another one. Suppose you wanted to look at adding the squares of the first few Fibonacci numbers. Let's see what we get there. So one plus one plus four is six. Add nine to that, we get 15. Add 25, we get 40. Add 64, we get 104. Now look at those numbers. Those are not Fibonacci numbers, but if you look at them closely, you'll see the Fibonacci numbers buried inside of them.Do you see it? I'll show it to you. Six is two times three, 15 is three times five, 40 is five times eight, two, three, five, eight, who do we appreciate?(Laughter)Fibonacci! Of course.Now, as much fun as it is to discover these patterns, it's even more satisfying to understand why they are true. Let's look at that last equation. Why should the squares of one, one, two, three, five and eight add up to eight times 13? I'll show you by drawing a simple picture. We'll start with a one-by-one square and next to that put another one-by-one square. Together, they form a one-by-two rectangle. Beneath that, I'll put a two-by-two square, and next to that, a three-by-three square, beneath that, a five-by-five square, and then an eight-by-eight square, creating one giant rectangle, right?Now let me ask you a simple question: what is the area of the rectangle? Well, on the one hand, it's the sum of the areas of the squares inside it, right? Just as we created it. It's one squared plus one squared plus two squared plus three squared plus five squared plus eight squared. Right? That's the area. On the other hand, because it's a rectangle, the area is equal to its height times its base, and the height is clearly eight, and the base is five plus eight, which is the next Fibonacci number, 13. Right? So the area is also eight times 13. Since we've correctly calculated the area two different ways, they have to be the same number, and that's why the squares of one, one, two, three, five and eight add up to eight times 13.Now, if we continue this process, we'll generate rectangles of the form 13 by 21, 21 by 34, and so on.Now check this out. If you divide 13 by eight, you get 1.625. And if you divide the larger number by the smaller number, then these ratios get closer and closer to about 1.618, known to many people as the Golden Ratio, a number which has fascinated mathematicians, scientists and artists for centuries.Now, I show all this to you because, like so much of mathematics, there's a beautiful side to it that I fear does not get enough attention in our schools. We spend lots of time learning about calculation, but let's not forget about application, including, perhaps, the most important application of all, learning how to think.If I could summarize this in one sentence, it would be this: Mathematics is not just solving for x, it's also figuring out why.Thank you very much.(Applause)
