X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:13.004 --> 00:00:15.523
One billion people in the world today

00:00:15.523 --> 00:00:17.803
do not have access to all-season roads.

00:00:17.803 --> 00:00:19.508
One billion people.

00:00:19.508 --> 00:00:21.679
One seventh of the Earth's population

00:00:21.679 --> 00:00:24.988
are totally cut off for some part of the year.

00:00:24.988 --> 00:00:27.316
We cannot get medicine to them reliably,

00:00:27.316 --> 00:00:29.662
they cannot get critical supplies,

00:00:29.662 --> 00:00:31.651
and they cannot get their goods to market

00:00:31.651 --> 00:00:35.541
in order to create a sustainable income.

00:00:35.541 --> 00:00:37.685
In sub-Saharan Africa, for instance,

00:00:37.685 --> 00:00:41.598
85 percent of roads are unusable in the wet season.

00:00:41.598 --> 00:00:43.617
Investments are being made,

00:00:43.617 --> 00:00:45.162
but at the current level,

00:00:45.162 --> 00:00:46.559
it's estimated it's going to take them

00:00:46.559 --> 00:00:49.665
50 years to catch up.

00:00:49.665 --> 00:00:51.959
In the U.S. alone, there's more than four million

00:00:51.959 --> 00:00:55.090
miles of roads, very expensive to build,

00:00:55.090 --> 00:00:58.461
very expensive to maintain infrastructure,

00:00:58.461 --> 00:01:00.730
with a huge ecological footprint,

00:01:00.730 --> 00:01:04.402
and yet, very often, congested.

00:01:04.402 --> 00:01:06.784
So we saw this and we thought,

00:01:06.784 --> 00:01:08.267
can there be a better way?

00:01:08.267 --> 00:01:11.722
Can we create a system using today's
most advanced technologies

00:01:11.722 --> 00:01:14.842
that can allow this part of the world to leapfrog

00:01:14.842 --> 00:01:17.197
in the same way they've done with mobile telephones

00:01:17.197 --> 00:01:19.072
in the last 10 years?

00:01:19.072 --> 00:01:22.017
Many of those nations have excellent telecommunications today

00:01:22.017 --> 00:01:24.994
without ever putting copper lines in the ground.

00:01:24.994 --> 00:01:28.344
Could we do the same for transportation?

00:01:28.344 --> 00:01:30.659
Imagine this scenario.

00:01:30.659 --> 00:01:33.817
Imagine you are in a maternity ward in Mali,

00:01:33.817 --> 00:01:37.047
and have a newborn in need of urgent medication.

00:01:37.047 --> 00:01:39.279
What would you do today?

00:01:39.279 --> 00:01:41.676
Well, you would place a request via mobile phone,

00:01:41.676 --> 00:01:44.540
and someone would get the request immediately.

00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:46.533
That's the part that works.

00:01:46.533 --> 00:01:48.570
The medication may take days to arrive, though,

00:01:48.570 --> 00:01:49.980
because of bad roads.

00:01:49.980 --> 00:01:52.336
That's the part that's broken.

00:01:52.336 --> 00:01:54.853
We believe we can deliver it within hours

00:01:54.853 --> 00:01:57.434
with an electric autonomous flying vehicle

00:01:57.434 --> 00:01:58.839
such as this.

00:01:58.839 --> 00:02:01.724
This can transport a small payload
today, about two kilograms,

00:02:01.724 --> 00:02:04.358
over a short distance, about 10 kilometers,

00:02:04.358 --> 00:02:06.713
but it's part of a wider network that may cover

00:02:06.713 --> 00:02:10.673
the entire country, maybe even the entire continent.

00:02:10.673 --> 00:02:15.011
It's an ultra-flexible, automated logistics network.

00:02:15.011 --> 00:02:17.946
It's a network for a transportation of matter.

00:02:17.946 --> 00:02:19.723
We call it Matternet.

00:02:19.723 --> 00:02:21.237
We use three key technologies.

00:02:21.237 --> 00:02:23.872
The first is electric autonomous flying vehicles.

00:02:23.872 --> 00:02:26.583
The second is automated ground stations

00:02:26.583 --> 00:02:28.562
that the vehicles fly in and out of

00:02:28.562 --> 00:02:30.820
to swap batteries and fly farther,

00:02:30.820 --> 00:02:32.562
or pick up or deliver loads.

00:02:32.562 --> 00:02:34.293
And the third is the operating system

00:02:34.293 --> 00:02:37.036
that manages the whole network.

00:02:37.036 --> 00:02:40.375
Let's look at each one of those
technologies in a bit more detail.

00:02:40.375 --> 00:02:42.620
First of all, the UAVs.

00:02:42.620 --> 00:02:44.704
Eventually, we're going to be
using all sorts of vehicles

00:02:44.704 --> 00:02:47.158
for different payload capacities and different ranges.

00:02:47.158 --> 00:02:49.414
Today, we're using small quads.

00:02:49.414 --> 00:02:51.757
These are able to transport two kilograms

00:02:51.757 --> 00:02:54.570
over 10 kilometers in just about 15 minutes.

00:02:54.570 --> 00:02:57.096
Compare this with trying to trespass a bad road

00:02:57.096 --> 00:02:58.510
in the developing world,

00:02:58.510 --> 00:03:00.730
or even being stuck in traffic

00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:02.775
in a developed world country.

00:03:02.775 --> 00:03:04.485
These fly autonomously.

00:03:04.485 --> 00:03:06.041
This is the key to the technology.

00:03:06.041 --> 00:03:08.401
So they use GPS and other sensors on board

00:03:08.401 --> 00:03:12.095
to navigate between ground stations.

00:03:12.095 --> 00:03:14.520
Every vehicle is equipped with an automatic

00:03:14.520 --> 00:03:17.558
payload and battery exchange mechanism,

00:03:17.558 --> 00:03:19.964
so these vehicles navigate to those ground stations,

00:03:19.964 --> 00:03:22.080
they dock, swap a battery automatically,

00:03:22.080 --> 00:03:23.784
and go out again.

00:03:23.784 --> 00:03:26.540
The ground stations are located on safe locations

00:03:26.540 --> 00:03:28.102
on the ground.

00:03:28.102 --> 00:03:30.101
They secure the most vulnerable part of the mission,

00:03:30.101 --> 00:03:31.955
which is the landing.

00:03:31.955 --> 00:03:34.047
They are at known locations on the ground,

00:03:34.047 --> 00:03:35.967
so the paths between them are also known,

00:03:35.967 --> 00:03:38.705
which is very important from a reliability perspective

00:03:38.705 --> 00:03:40.256
from the whole network.

00:03:40.256 --> 00:03:43.080
Apart from fulfilling the energy
requirements of the vehicles,

00:03:43.080 --> 00:03:45.452
eventually they're going to be becoming

00:03:45.452 --> 00:03:48.152
commercial hubs where people can take out loads

00:03:48.152 --> 00:03:51.215
or put loads into the network.

00:03:51.215 --> 00:03:53.438
The last component is the operating system

00:03:53.438 --> 00:03:55.332
that manages the whole network.

00:03:55.332 --> 00:03:58.073
It monitors weather data from all the ground stations

00:03:58.073 --> 00:04:01.414
and optimizes the routes of
the vehicles through the system

00:04:01.414 --> 00:04:04.005
to avoid adverse weather conditions,

00:04:04.005 --> 00:04:06.008
avoid other risk factors,

00:04:06.008 --> 00:04:07.728
and optimize the use of the resources

00:04:07.728 --> 00:04:09.626
throughout the network.

00:04:09.626 --> 00:04:11.268
I want to show you what one of those flights

00:04:11.268 --> 00:04:13.036
looks like.

00:04:13.036 --> 00:04:16.978
Here we are flying in Haiti last summer,

00:04:16.978 --> 00:04:19.421
where we've done our first field trials.

00:04:19.421 --> 00:04:21.565
We're modeling here a medical delivery

00:04:21.565 --> 00:04:26.405
in a camp we set up after the 2010 earthquake.

00:04:26.405 --> 00:04:28.956
People there love this.

00:04:28.956 --> 00:04:31.085
And I want to show you

00:04:31.085 --> 00:04:35.961
what one of those vehicles looks like up close.

00:04:35.961 --> 00:04:37.969
So this is a $3,000 vehicle.

00:04:37.969 --> 00:04:41.986
Costs are coming down very rapidly.

00:04:41.986 --> 00:04:45.161
We use this in all sorts of weather conditions,

00:04:45.161 --> 00:04:46.956
very hot and very cold climates,

00:04:46.956 --> 00:04:53.054
very strong winds. They're very sturdy vehicles.

00:04:53.054 --> 00:04:57.073
Imagine if your life depended on this package,

00:04:57.073 --> 00:04:58.517
somewhere in Africa

00:04:58.517 --> 00:05:02.780
or in New York City, after Sandy.

00:05:02.780 --> 00:05:06.086
The next big question is, what's the cost?

00:05:06.086 --> 00:05:09.896
Well, it turns out that the cost to transport

00:05:09.896 --> 00:05:13.855
two kilograms over 10 kilometers with this vehicle

00:05:13.855 --> 00:05:17.228
is just 24 cents.

00:05:17.228 --> 00:05:22.300
(Applause)

00:05:22.300 --> 00:05:25.044
And it's counterintuitive, but the cost of energy

00:05:25.044 --> 00:05:27.033
expended for the flight is only two cents

00:05:27.033 --> 00:05:28.371
of a dollar today,

00:05:28.371 --> 00:05:30.504
and we're just at the beginning of this.

00:05:30.504 --> 00:05:33.106
When we saw this, we felt that this is something

00:05:33.106 --> 00:05:36.105
that can have significant impact in the world.

00:05:36.105 --> 00:05:38.523
So we said, okay, how much does it cost

00:05:38.523 --> 00:05:40.591
to set up a network somewhere in the world?

00:05:40.591 --> 00:05:42.621
And we looked at setting up a network in Lesotho

00:05:42.621 --> 00:05:45.662
for transportation of HIV/AIDS samples.

00:05:45.662 --> 00:05:48.069
The problem there is how do you take them

00:05:48.069 --> 00:05:50.298
from clinics where they're being collected

00:05:50.298 --> 00:05:53.318
to hospitals where they're being analyzed?

00:05:53.318 --> 00:05:55.460
And we said, what if we wanted to cover an area

00:05:55.460 --> 00:05:58.117
spanning around 140 square kilometers?

00:05:58.117 --> 00:06:01.591
That's roughly one and a half times
the size of Manhattan.

00:06:01.591 --> 00:06:03.758
Well it turns out that the cost to do that there

00:06:03.758 --> 00:06:06.733
would be less than a million dollars.

00:06:06.733 --> 00:06:09.964
Compare this to normal infrastructure investments.

00:06:09.964 --> 00:06:13.121
We think this can be -- this is the power

00:06:13.121 --> 00:06:15.840
of a new paradigm.

00:06:15.840 --> 00:06:18.323
So here we are: a new idea

00:06:18.323 --> 00:06:20.193
about a network for transportation

00:06:20.193 --> 00:06:22.839
that is based on the ideas of the Internet.

00:06:22.839 --> 00:06:25.068
It's decentralized, it's peer-to-peer,

00:06:25.068 --> 00:06:27.771
it's bidirectional, highly adaptable,

00:06:27.771 --> 00:06:30.281
with very low infrastructure investment,

00:06:30.281 --> 00:06:34.414
very low ecological footprint.

00:06:34.414 --> 00:06:36.698
If it is a new paradigm, though,

00:06:36.698 --> 00:06:38.844
there must be other uses for it.

00:06:38.844 --> 00:06:41.010
It can be used perhaps in other places in the world.

00:06:41.010 --> 00:06:45.188
So let's look at the other end of the spectrum:

00:06:45.188 --> 00:06:47.193
our cities and megacities.

00:06:47.193 --> 00:06:50.065
Half of the Earth's population lives in cities today.

00:06:50.065 --> 00:06:52.785
Half a billion of us live in megacities.

00:06:52.785 --> 00:06:55.465
We are living through an amazing urbanization trend.

00:06:55.465 --> 00:06:57.438
China alone is adding a megacity

00:06:57.438 --> 00:07:00.545
the size of New York City every two years.

00:07:00.545 --> 00:07:03.198
These are places that do have road infrastructure,

00:07:03.198 --> 00:07:05.512
but it's very inefficient.

00:07:05.512 --> 00:07:07.644
Congestion is a huge problem.

00:07:07.644 --> 00:07:09.584
So we think it makes sense in those places

00:07:09.584 --> 00:07:11.954
to set up a network of transportation

00:07:11.954 --> 00:07:14.120
that is a new layer that sits between the road

00:07:14.120 --> 00:07:15.391
and the Internet,

00:07:15.391 --> 00:07:18.297
initially for lightweight, urgent stuff,

00:07:18.297 --> 00:07:20.346
and over time, we would hope to develop this

00:07:20.346 --> 00:07:22.338
into a new mode of transportation

00:07:22.338 --> 00:07:25.790
that is truly a modern solution to a very old problem.

00:07:25.790 --> 00:07:27.344
It's ultimately scalable

00:07:27.344 --> 00:07:30.202
with a very small ecological footprint,

00:07:30.202 --> 00:07:33.178
operating in the background 24/7,

00:07:33.178 --> 00:07:35.524
just like the Internet.

00:07:35.524 --> 00:07:37.946
So when we started this

00:07:37.946 --> 00:07:40.948
a couple of years ago now,

00:07:40.948 --> 00:07:43.292
we've had a lot of people come up to us who said,

00:07:43.292 --> 00:07:46.124
"This is a very interesting but crazy idea,

00:07:46.124 --> 00:07:47.958
and certainly not something that you should

00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:50.672
engage with anytime soon."

00:07:50.672 --> 00:07:52.815
And of course, we're talking about drones, right,

00:07:52.815 --> 00:07:56.517
a technology that's not only unpopular in the West

00:07:56.517 --> 00:07:58.465
but one that has become a very, very unpleasant

00:07:58.465 --> 00:08:01.330
fact of life for many living in poor countries,

00:08:01.330 --> 00:08:04.141
especially those engaged in conflict.

00:08:04.141 --> 00:08:08.675
So why are we doing this?

00:08:08.675 --> 00:08:11.459
Well, we chose to do this one

00:08:11.459 --> 00:08:13.245
not because it's easy,

00:08:13.245 --> 00:08:16.080
but because it can have amazing impact.

00:08:16.080 --> 00:08:18.905
Imagine one billion people being connected

00:08:18.905 --> 00:08:21.300
to physical goods in the same way

00:08:21.300 --> 00:08:24.324
that mobile telecommunications connected them

00:08:24.324 --> 00:08:26.416
to information.

00:08:26.416 --> 00:08:30.156
Imagine if the next big network we built in the world

00:08:30.156 --> 00:08:33.919
was a network for the transportation of matter.

00:08:33.919 --> 00:08:36.321
In the developing world, we would hope

00:08:36.321 --> 00:08:39.026
to reach millions of people with better vaccines,

00:08:39.026 --> 00:08:40.910
reach them with better medication.

00:08:40.910 --> 00:08:42.768
It would give us an unfair advantage against battling

00:08:42.768 --> 00:08:46.760
HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and other epidemics.

00:08:46.760 --> 00:08:48.456
Over time, we would hope it would become

00:08:48.456 --> 00:08:50.630
a new platform for economic transactions,

00:08:50.630 --> 00:08:53.091
lifting millions of people out of poverty.

00:08:53.091 --> 00:08:55.301
In the developed world and the emerging world,

00:08:55.301 --> 00:08:56.769
we would hope it would become a new mode

00:08:56.769 --> 00:09:00.490
of transportation that could help make our cities

00:09:00.490 --> 00:09:02.343
more livable.

00:09:02.343 --> 00:09:05.686
So for those that still believe
that this is science fiction,

00:09:05.686 --> 00:09:08.501
I firmly say to you that it is not.

00:09:08.501 --> 00:09:10.170
We do need to engage, though,

00:09:10.170 --> 00:09:13.238
in social fiction to make it happen.

00:09:13.238 --> 00:09:15.405
Thank you.

00:09:15.405 --> 00:09:19.405
(Applause)

title: How your "working memory" makes sense of the world
transcript: So yesterday, I was out in the street in front of this building, and I was walking down the sidewalk, and I had company, several of us, and we were all abiding by the rules of walking down sidewalks. We're not talking each other. We're facing forward. We're moving. When the person in front of me slows down. And so I'm watching him, and he slows down, and finally he stops. Well, that wasn't fast enough for me, so I put on my turn signal, and I walked around him, and as I walked, I looked to see what he was doing, and he was doing this. He was texting, and he couldn't text and walk at the same time. Now we could approach this from a working memory perspective or from a multitasking perspective. We're going to do working memory today.Now, working memory is that part of our consciousness that we are aware of at any given time of day. You're going it right now. It's not something we can turn off. If you turn it off, that's called a coma, okay? So right now, you're doing just fine.Now working memory has four basic components. It allows us to store some immediate experiences and a little bit of knowledge. It allows us to reach back into our long-term memory and pull some of that in as we need it, mixes it, processes it in light of whatever our current goal is. Now the current goal isn't something like, I want to be president or the best surfer in the world. It's more mundane. I'd like that cookie, or I need to figure out how to get into my hotel room. Now working memory capacity is our ability to leverage that, our ability to take what we know and what we can hang onto and leverage it in ways that allow us to satisfy our current goal.Now working memory capacity has a fairly long history, and it's associated with a lot of positive effects. People with high working memory capacity tend to be good storytellers. They tend to solve and do well on standardized tests, however important that is. They're able to have high levels of writing ability. They're also able to reason at high levels.So what we're going to do here is play a little bit with some of that. So I'm going to ask you to perform a couple tasks, and we're going to take your  working memory out for a ride. You up for that? Okay.I'm going to give you five words, and I just want you to hang on to them. Don't write them down. Just hang on to them. Five words. While you're hanging on to them, I'm going to ask you to answer three questions. I want to see what happens with those words. So here's the words: tree, highway, mirror, Saturn and electrode. So far so good? Okay. What I want you to do is I want you to tell me what the answer is to 23 times eight. Just shout it out. (Mumbling) (Laughter) In fact it's — (Mumbling) — exactly. (Laughter) All right. I want you to take out your left hand and I want you to go, "One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, 10." It's a neurological test, just in case you were wondering. All right, now what I want you to do is to recite the last five letters of the English alphabet backwards. You should have started with Z. (Laughter)All right. How many people here are still pretty sure you've got all five words? Okay. Typically we end up with about less than half, right, which is normal. There will be a range. Some people can hang on to five. Some people can hang on to 10. Some will be down to two or three.What we know is this is really important to the way we function, right? And it's going to be really important here at TED because you're going to be exposed to so many different ideas.Now the problem that we have is that life comes at us, and it comes at us very quickly, and what we need to do is to take that amorphous flow of experience and somehow extract meaning from it with a working memory that's about the size of a pea. Now don't get me wrong, working memory is awesome. Working memory allows us to investigate our current experience as we move forward. It allows us to make sense of the world around us. But it does have certain limits.Now working memory is great for allowing us to communicate. We can have a conversation, and I can build a narrative around that so I know where we've been and where we're going and how to contribute to this conversation. It allows us to problem-solve, critical think. We can be in the middle of a meeting, listen to somebody's presentation, evaluate it, decide whether or not we like it, ask follow-up questions. All of that occurs within working memory. It also allows us to go to the store and allows us to get milk and eggs and cheese when what we're really looking for is Red Bull and bacon. (Laughter) Gotta make sure we're getting what we're looking for. Now, a central issue with working memory is that it's limited. It's limited in capacity, limited in duration, limited in focus. We tend to remember about four things. Okay? It used to be seven, but with functional MRIs, apparently it's four, and we were overachieving. Now we can remember those four things for about 10 to 20 seconds unless we do something with it, unless we process it, unless we apply it to something, unless we talk to somebody about it.When we think about working memory, we have to realize that this limited capacity has lots of different impacts on us. Have you ever walked from one room to another and then forgotten why you're there? You do know the solution to that, right? You go back to that original room. (Laughter) Have you ever forgotten your keys? You ever forgotten your car? You ever forgotten your kids? Have you ever been involved in a conversation, and you realize that the conversation to your left is actually more interesting? (Laughter) So you're nodding and you're smiling, but you're really paying attention to this one over here, until you hear that last word go up, and you realize, you've been asked a question. (Laughter) And you're really hoping the answer is no, because that's what you're about to say. All of that talks about working memory, what we can do and what we can't do. We need to realize that working memory has a limited capacity, and that working memory capacity itself is how we negotiate that. We negotiate that through strategies.So what I want to do is talk a little bit about a couple of strategies here, and these will be really important because you are now in an information target-rich environment for the next several days. Now the first part of this that we need to think about and we need to process our existence, our life, immediately and repeatedly. We need to process what's going on the moment it happens, not 10 minutes later, not a week later, at the moment. So we need to think about, well, do I agree with him? What's missing? What would I like to know? Do I agree with the assumptions? How can I apply this in my life? It's a way of processing what's going on so that we can use it later. Now we also need to repeat it. We need to practice. So we need to think about it here. In between, we want to talk to people about it. We're going to write it down, and when you get home, pull out those notes and think about them and end up practicing over time. Practice for some reason became a very negative thing. It's very positive.The next thing is, we need to think elaboratively and we need to think illustratively. Oftentimes, we think that we have to relate new knowledge to prior knowledge. What we want to do is spin that around. We want to take all of our existence and wrap it around that new knowledge and make all of these connections and it becomes more meaningful. We also want to use imagery. We are built for images. We need to take advantage of that. Think about things in images, write things down that way. If you read a book, pull things up. I just got through reading "The Great Gatsby," and I have a perfect idea of what he looks like in my head, so my own version.The last one is organization and support. We are meaning-making machines. It's what we do. We try to make meaning out of everything that happens to us. Organization helps, so we need to structure what we're doing in ways that make sense. If we are providing knowledge and experience, we need to structure that.And the last one is support. We all started as novices. Everything we do is an approximation of sophistication. We should expect it to change over time. We have to support that. The support may come in asking people questions, giving them a sheet of paper that has an organizational chart on it or has some guiding images, but we need to support it.Now, the final piece of this, the take-home message from a working memory capacity standpoint is this: what we process, we learn. If we're not processing life, we're not living it. Live life. Thank you.(Applause)
