We're not talking each other. We're facing forward.

00:00:28.468 --> 00:00:29.891
We're moving.

00:00:29.891 --> 00:00:33.154
When the person in front of me slows down.

00:00:33.154 --> 00:00:35.144
And so I'm watching him, and he slows down,

00:00:35.144 --> 00:00:36.741
and finally he stops.

00:00:36.741 --> 00:00:38.826
Well, that wasn't fast enough for me,

00:00:38.826 --> 00:00:42.505
so I put on my turn signal, and I walked around him,

00:00:42.505 --> 00:00:45.238
and as I walked, I looked to see what he was doing,

00:00:45.238 --> 00:00:47.801
and he was doing this.

00:00:47.806 --> 00:00:49.750
He was texting,

00:00:49.750 --> 00:00:51.772
and he couldn't text and walk at the same time.

00:00:51.772 --> 00:00:53.581
Now we could approach this

00:00:53.581 --> 00:00:55.473
from a working memory perspective

00:00:55.473 --> 00:00:57.458
or from a multitasking perspective.

00:00:57.458 --> 00:00:59.987
We're going to do working memory today.

00:00:59.987 --> 00:01:02.127
Now, working memory

00:01:02.127 --> 00:01:05.275
is that part of our consciousness that we are

00:01:05.275 --> 00:01:07.729
aware of at any given time of day.

00:01:07.729 --> 00:01:09.371
You're going it right now.

00:01:09.371 --> 00:01:11.025
It's not something we can turn off.

00:01:11.025 --> 00:01:14.476
If you turn it off, that's called a coma, okay?

00:01:14.476 --> 00:01:17.579
So right now, you're doing just fine.

00:01:17.579 --> 00:01:19.935
Now working memory has four basic components.

00:01:19.935 --> 00:01:22.532
It allows us to store some immediate experiences

00:01:22.532 --> 00:01:24.148
and a little bit of knowledge.

00:01:24.148 --> 00:01:27.517
It allows us to reach back
into our long-term memory

00:01:27.517 --> 00:01:29.367
and pull some of that in as we need it,

00:01:29.367 --> 00:01:31.567
mixes it, processes it

00:01:31.567 --> 00:01:33.861
in light of whatever our current goal is.

00:01:33.861 --> 00:01:35.375
Now the current goal isn't something like,

00:01:35.375 --> 00:01:37.657
I want to be president or the best surfer in the world.

00:01:37.657 --> 00:01:40.460
It's more mundane. I'd like that cookie,

00:01:40.460 --> 00:01:43.062
or I need to figure out how to get into my hotel room.

00:01:43.062 --> 00:01:45.242
Now working memory capacity

00:01:45.242 --> 00:01:47.848
is our ability to leverage that,

00:01:47.848 --> 00:01:50.643
our ability to take what we know

00:01:50.643 --> 00:01:51.919
and what we can hang onto

00:01:51.919 --> 00:01:55.518
and leverage it in ways that allow us to satisfy

00:01:55.518 --> 00:01:57.268
our current goal.

00:01:57.268 --> 00:01:59.052
Now working memory capacity

00:01:59.052 --> 00:02:01.105
has a fairly long history,

00:02:01.105 --> 00:02:03.304
and it's associated with a lot of positive effects.

00:02:03.304 --> 00:02:05.692
People with high working memory capacity

00:02:05.692 --> 00:02:07.936
tend to be good storytellers.

00:02:07.936 --> 00:02:11.913
They tend to solve and do well
on standardized tests,

00:02:11.913 --> 00:02:14.258
however important that is.

00:02:14.258 --> 00:02:18.041
They're able to have high levels of writing ability.

00:02:18.041 --> 00:02:20.915
They're also able to reason at high levels.

00:02:20.915 --> 00:02:23.833
So what we're going to do here
is play a little bit with some of that.

00:02:23.833 --> 00:02:26.383
So I'm going to ask you to perform a couple tasks,

00:02:26.383 --> 00:02:29.462
and we're going to take your 
working memory out for a ride.

00:02:29.462 --> 00:02:32.059
You up for that? Okay.

00:02:32.059 --> 00:02:34.257
I'm going to give you five words,

00:02:34.257 --> 00:02:36.050
and I just want you to hang on to them.

00:02:36.050 --> 00:02:37.918
Don't write them down. Just hang on to them.

00:02:37.918 --> 00:02:39.330
Five words.

00:02:39.330 --> 00:02:42.533
While you're hanging on to them,
I'm going to ask you to answer three questions.

00:02:42.533 --> 00:02:44.438
I want to see what happens with those words.

00:02:44.438 --> 00:02:46.285
So here's the words:

00:02:46.285 --> 00:02:49.573
tree,

00:02:49.573 --> 00:02:52.508
highway,

00:02:52.508 --> 00:02:54.886
mirror,

00:02:54.886 --> 00:02:57.018
Saturn

00:02:57.018 --> 00:02:59.437
and electrode.

00:02:59.437 --> 00:03:01.021
So far so good?

00:03:01.021 --> 00:03:02.875
Okay. What I want you to do

00:03:02.875 --> 00:03:06.222
is I want you to tell me what the answer is

00:03:06.222 --> 00:03:08.544
to 23 times eight.

00:03:08.544 --> 00:03:11.258
Just shout it out.

00:03:12.724 --> 00:03:16.426
(Mumbling) (Laughter)

00:03:16.426 --> 00:03:18.847
In fact it's -- (Mumbling) -- exactly. (Laughter)

00:03:18.847 --> 00:03:22.074
All right. I want you to take out your left hand

00:03:22.074 --> 00:03:24.754
and I want you to go, "One, two, three, four, five,

00:03:24.754 --> 00:03:26.957
six, seven, eight, nine, 10."

00:03:26.957 --> 00:03:29.653
It's a neurological test,
just in case you were wondering.

00:03:29.653 --> 00:03:31.518
All right, now what I want you to do

00:03:31.518 --> 00:03:33.743
is to recite the last five letters

00:03:33.743 --> 00:03:36.612
of the English alphabet backwards.

00:03:38.595 --> 00:03:40.497
You should have started with Z.

00:03:40.497 --> 00:03:43.788
(Laughter)

00:03:43.788 --> 00:03:45.875
All right. How many people here are still pretty sure

00:03:45.875 --> 00:03:48.326
you've got all five words?

00:03:48.326 --> 00:03:51.507
Okay. Typically we end up with about less than half,

00:03:51.507 --> 00:03:53.582
right, which is normal. There will be a range.

00:03:53.582 --> 00:03:55.138
Some people can hang on to five.

00:03:55.138 --> 00:03:56.422
Some people can hang on to 10.

00:03:56.422 --> 00:03:58.727
Some will be down to two or three.

00:03:58.727 --> 00:04:02.131
What we know is this is really important
to the way we function, right?

00:04:02.131 --> 00:04:04.079
And it's going to be really important here at TED

00:04:04.079 --> 00:04:07.115
because you're going to be exposed
to so many different ideas.

00:04:07.115 --> 00:04:09.322
Now the problem that we have

00:04:09.322 --> 00:04:11.034
is that life comes at us,

00:04:11.034 --> 00:04:13.151
and it comes at us very quickly,

00:04:13.151 --> 00:04:17.064
and what we need to do is to take that amorphous

00:04:17.064 --> 00:04:18.842
flow of experience and somehow

00:04:18.842 --> 00:04:20.349
extract meaning from it

00:04:20.349 --> 00:04:21.648
with a working memory

00:04:21.648 --> 00:04:23.917
that's about the size of a pea.

00:04:23.917 --> 00:04:26.464
Now don't get me wrong,
working memory is awesome.

00:04:26.464 --> 00:04:28.579
Working memory allows us

00:04:28.579 --> 00:04:30.951
to investigate our current experience

00:04:30.951 --> 00:04:32.446
as we move forward.

00:04:32.446 --> 00:04:35.614
It allows us to make sense of the world around us.

00:04:35.614 --> 00:04:37.533
But it does have certain limits.

00:04:37.533 --> 00:04:41.376
Now working memory is great
for allowing us to communicate.

00:04:41.376 --> 00:04:42.848
We can have a conversation,

00:04:42.848 --> 00:04:45.535
and I can build a narrative around that

00:04:45.535 --> 00:04:47.265
so I know where we've been and where we're going

00:04:47.265 --> 00:04:49.353
and how to contribute to this conversation.

00:04:49.353 --> 00:04:51.590
It allows us to problem-solve, critical think.

00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:53.394
We can be in the middle of a meeting,

00:04:53.394 --> 00:04:55.897
listen to somebody's presentation, evaluate it,

00:04:55.897 --> 00:04:57.539
decide whether or not we like it,

00:04:57.539 --> 00:04:58.797
ask follow-up questions.

00:04:58.797 --> 00:05:02.167
All of that occurs within working memory.

00:05:02.167 --> 00:05:04.014
It also allows us to go to the store

00:05:04.014 --> 00:05:07.668
and allows us to get milk and eggs and cheese

00:05:07.668 --> 00:05:09.439
when what we're really looking for

00:05:09.439 --> 00:05:12.276
is Red Bull and bacon. (Laughter)

00:05:12.276 --> 00:05:14.998
Gotta make sure we're getting what we're looking for.

00:05:14.998 --> 00:05:18.335
Now, a central issue with working memory

00:05:18.335 --> 00:05:19.732
is that it's limited.

00:05:19.732 --> 00:05:21.928
It's limited in capacity, limited in duration,

00:05:21.928 --> 00:05:23.538
limited in focus.

00:05:23.538 --> 00:05:26.273
We tend to remember about four things.

00:05:26.273 --> 00:05:28.170
Okay? It used to be seven,

00:05:28.170 --> 00:05:30.194
but with functional MRIs, apparently it's four,

00:05:30.194 --> 00:05:32.737
and we were overachieving.

00:05:32.737 --> 00:05:34.710
Now we can remember those four things

00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:36.573
for about 10 to 20 seconds

00:05:36.573 --> 00:05:38.300
unless we do something with it,

00:05:38.300 --> 00:05:40.813
unless we process it,
unless we apply it to something,

00:05:40.813 --> 00:05:44.458
unless we talk to somebody about it.

00:05:44.458 --> 00:05:47.700
When we think about working memory,

00:05:47.700 --> 00:05:51.004
we have to realize that this limited capacity

00:05:51.004 --> 00:05:53.499
has lots of different impacts on us.

00:05:53.499 --> 00:05:56.524
Have you ever walked from one room to another

00:05:56.524 --> 00:05:59.535
and then forgotten why you're there?

00:05:59.535 --> 00:06:01.704
You do know the solution to that, right?

00:06:01.704 --> 00:06:04.050
You go back to that original room. (Laughter)

00:06:04.050 --> 00:06:07.987
Have you ever forgotten your keys?

00:06:07.987 --> 00:06:10.516
You ever forgotten your car?

00:06:10.516 --> 00:06:13.487
You ever forgotten your kids?

00:06:13.487 --> 00:06:15.676
Have you ever been involved in a conversation,

00:06:15.676 --> 00:06:17.620
and you realize that the conversation to your left

00:06:17.620 --> 00:06:20.454
is actually more interesting? (Laughter)

00:06:20.454 --> 00:06:22.078
So you're nodding and you're smiling,

00:06:22.078 --> 00:06:24.466
but you're really paying attention
to this one over here,

00:06:24.466 --> 00:06:26.766
until you hear that last word go up,

00:06:26.766 --> 00:06:28.426
and you realize,

00:06:28.426 --> 00:06:31.380
you've been asked a question. (Laughter)

00:06:31.380 --> 00:06:33.327
And you're really hoping the answer is no,

00:06:33.327 --> 00:06:36.546
because that's what you're about to say.

00:06:36.546 --> 00:06:39.022
All of that talks about working memory,

00:06:39.022 --> 00:06:41.280
what we can do and what we can't do.

00:06:41.280 --> 00:06:42.817
We need to realize that working memory

00:06:42.817 --> 00:06:44.216
has a limited capacity,

00:06:44.216 --> 00:06:47.735
and that working memory capacity itself
is how we negotiate that.

00:06:47.735 --> 00:06:49.906
We negotiate that through strategies.

00:06:49.906 --> 00:06:52.227
So what I want to do is talk a little bit
about a couple of strategies here,

00:06:52.227 --> 00:06:53.502
and these will be really important

00:06:53.502 --> 00:06:57.257
because you are now in an
information target-rich environment

00:06:57.257 --> 00:06:59.377
for the next several days.

00:06:59.377 --> 00:07:02.281
Now the first part of this that we need to think about

00:07:02.281 --> 00:07:05.048
and we need to process our existence, our life,

00:07:05.048 --> 00:07:06.763
immediately and repeatedly.

00:07:06.763 --> 00:07:09.204
We need to process what's going on

00:07:09.204 --> 00:07:12.118
the moment it happens, not 10 minutes later,

00:07:12.118 --> 00:07:14.387
not a week later, at the moment.

00:07:14.387 --> 00:07:18.120
So we need to think about, well,
do I agree with him?

00:07:18.120 --> 00:07:20.900
What's missing? What would I like to know?

00:07:20.900 --> 00:07:23.122
Do I agree with the assumptions?

00:07:23.122 --> 00:07:24.932
How can I apply this in my life?

00:07:24.932 --> 00:07:26.912
It's a way of processing what's going on

00:07:26.912 --> 00:07:28.679
so that we can use it later.

00:07:28.679 --> 00:07:31.639
Now we also need to repeat it. We need to practice.

00:07:31.639 --> 00:07:34.051
So we need to think about it here.

00:07:34.051 --> 00:07:36.846
In between, we want to talk to people about it.

00:07:36.846 --> 00:07:39.069
We're going to write it down,
and when you get home,

00:07:39.069 --> 00:07:41.029
pull out those notes and think about them

00:07:41.029 --> 00:07:43.418
and end up practicing over time.

00:07:43.418 --> 00:07:45.969
Practice for some reason
became a very negative thing.

00:07:45.969 --> 00:07:47.421
It's very positive.

00:07:47.421 --> 00:07:50.471
The next thing is, we need to think elaboratively

00:07:50.471 --> 00:07:52.811
and we need to think illustratively.

00:07:52.811 --> 00:07:56.265
Oftentimes, we think that we have to relate
new knowledge to prior knowledge.

00:07:56.265 --> 00:07:58.195
What we want to do is spin that around.

00:07:58.195 --> 00:07:59.952
We want to take all of our existence

00:07:59.952 --> 00:08:01.705
and wrap it around that new knowledge

00:08:01.705 --> 00:08:05.153
and make all of these connections
and it becomes more meaningful.

00:08:05.153 --> 00:08:08.947
We also want to use imagery.
We are built for images.

00:08:08.947 --> 00:08:10.805
We need to take advantage of that.

00:08:10.805 --> 00:08:12.315
Think about things in images,

00:08:12.315 --> 00:08:14.664
write things down that way.

00:08:14.664 --> 00:08:16.226
If you read a book, pull things up.

00:08:16.226 --> 00:08:18.279
I just got through reading "The Great Gatsby,"

00:08:18.279 --> 00:08:21.378
and I have a perfect idea of what he looks like

00:08:21.378 --> 00:08:24.376
in my head, so my own version.

00:08:24.376 --> 00:08:26.379
The last one is organization and support.

00:08:26.379 --> 00:08:28.948
We are meaning-making machines. It's what we do.

00:08:28.948 --> 00:08:32.089
We try to make meaning out of
everything that happens to us.

00:08:32.089 --> 00:08:34.379
Organization helps, so we need to structure

00:08:34.379 --> 00:08:35.958
what we're doing in ways that make sense.

00:08:35.958 --> 00:08:38.544
If we are providing knowledge and experience,

00:08:38.544 --> 00:08:40.029
we need to structure that.

00:08:40.029 --> 00:08:42.528
And the last one is support.

00:08:42.528 --> 00:08:44.250
We all started as novices.

00:08:44.250 --> 00:08:47.291
Everything we do is an
approximation of sophistication.

00:08:47.291 --> 00:08:50.228
We should expect it to change over time.
We have to support that.

00:08:50.228 --> 00:08:52.884
The support may come in asking people questions,

00:08:52.884 --> 00:08:56.382
giving them a sheet of paper that has
an organizational chart on it

00:08:56.387 --> 00:08:58.935
or has some guiding images,

00:08:58.935 --> 00:09:00.835
but we need to support it.

00:09:00.835 --> 00:09:06.126
Now, the final piece of this, the take-home message

00:09:06.126 --> 00:09:09.052
from a working memory capacity standpoint is this:

00:09:09.052 --> 00:09:11.983
what we process, we learn.

00:09:11.983 --> 00:09:16.784
If we're not processing life, we're not living it.

00:09:16.784 --> 00:09:18.676
Live life. Thank you.

00:09:18.676 --> 00:09:22.861
(Applause)

title: How societies can grow old better
transcript: To give me an idea of how many of you here may find what I'm about to tell you of practical value, let me ask you please to raise your hands: Who here is either over 65 years old or hopes to live past age 65 or has parents or grandparents who did live or have lived past 65, raise your hands please. (Laughter)Okay. You are the people to whom my talk will be of practical value. (Laughter) The rest of you won't find my talk personally relevant, but I think that you will still find the subject fascinating.I'm going to talk about growing older in traditional societies. This subject constitutes just one chapter of my latest book, which compares traditional, small, tribal societies with our large, modern societies, with respect to many topics such as bringing up children, growing older, health, dealing with danger, settling disputes, religion and speaking more than one language.Those tribal societies, which constituted all human societies for most of human history, are far more diverse than are our modern, recent, big societies. All big societies that have governments, and where most people are strangers to each other, are inevitably similar to each other and different from tribal societies. Tribes constitute thousands of natural experiments in how to run a human society. They constitute experiments from which we ourselves may be able to learn. Tribal societies shouldn't be scorned as primitive and miserable, but also they shouldn't be romanticized as happy and peaceful. When we learn of tribal practices, some of them will horrify us, but there are other tribal practices which, when we hear about them, we may admire and envy and wonder whether we could adopt those practices ourselves.Most old people in the U.S. end up living separately from their children and from most of their friends of their earlier years, and often they live in separate retirements homes for the elderly, whereas in traditional societies, older people instead live out their lives among their children, their other relatives, and their lifelong friends. Nevertheless, the treatment of the elderly varies enormously among traditional societies, from much worse to much better than in our modern societies.At the worst extreme, many traditional societies get rid of their elderly in one of four increasingly direct ways: by neglecting their elderly and not feeding or cleaning them until they die, or by abandoning them when the group moves, or by encouraging older people to commit suicide, or by killing older people. In which tribal societies do children abandon or kill their parents? It happens mainly under two conditions. One is in nomadic, hunter-gather societies that often shift camp and that are physically incapable of transporting old people who can't walk when the able-bodied younger people already have to carry their young children and all their physical possessions. The other condition is in societies living in marginal or fluctuating environments, such as the Arctic or deserts, where there are periodic food shortages, and occasionally there just isn't enough food to keep everyone alive. Whatever food is available has to be reserved for able-bodied adults and for children. To us Americans, it sounds horrible to think of abandoning or killing your own sick wife or husband or elderly mother or father, but what could those traditional societies do differently? They face a cruel situation of no choice. Their old people had to do it to their own parents, and the old people know what now is going to happen to them.At the opposite extreme in treatment of the elderly, the happy extreme, are the New Guinea farming societies where I've been doing my fieldwork  for the past 50 years, and most other sedentary traditional societies around the world. In those societies, older people are cared for. They are fed. They remain valuable. And they continue to live in the same hut or else in a nearby hut near their children, relatives and lifelong friends.There are two main sets of reasons for this variation among societies in their treatment of old people. The variation depends especially on the usefulness of old people and on the society's values.First, as regards usefulness, older people continue to perform useful services. One use of older people in traditional societies is that they often are still effective at producing food. Another traditional usefulness of older people is that they are capable of babysitting their grandchildren, thereby freeing up their own adult children, the parents of those grandchildren, to go hunting and gathering food for the grandchildren. Still another traditional value of older people is in making tools, weapons, baskets, pots and textiles. In fact, they're usually the people who are best at it. Older people usually are the leaders of traditional societies, and the people most knowledgeable about politics, medicine, religion, songs and dances.Finally, older people in traditional societies have a huge significance that would never occur to us in our modern, literate societies, where our sources of information are books and the Internet. In contrast, in traditional societies without writing, older people are the repositories of information. It's their knowledge that spells the difference between survival and death for their whole society in a time of crisis caused by rare events for which only the oldest people alive have had experience. Those, then, are the ways in which older people are useful in traditional societies. Their usefulness varies and contributes to variation in the society's treatment of the elderly.The other set of reasons for variation in the treatment of the elderly is the society's cultural values. For example, there's particular emphasis on respect for the elderly in East Asia, associated with Confucius' doctrine of filial piety, which means obedience, respect and support for elderly parents. Cultural values that emphasize respect for older people contrast with the low status of the elderly in the U.S. Older Americans are at a big disadvantage in job applications. They're at a big disadvantage in hospitals. Our hospitals have an explicit policy called age-based allocation of healthcare resources. That sinister expression means that if hospital resources are limited, for example if only one donor heart becomes available for transplant, or if a surgeon has time to operate on only a certain number of patients, American hospitals have an explicit policy of giving preference to younger patients over older patients on the grounds that younger patients are considered more valuable to society because they have more years of life ahead of them, even though the younger patients have fewer years of valuable life experience behind them. There are several reasons for this low status of the elderly in the U.S. One is our Protestant work ethic which places high value on work, so older people who are no longer working aren't respected. Another reason is our American emphasis on the virtues of self-reliance and independence, so we instinctively look down on older people who are no longer self-reliant and independent. Still a third reason is our American cult of youth, which shows up even in our advertisements. Ads for Coca-Cola and beer always depict smiling young people, even though old as well as young people buy and drink Coca-Cola and beer. Just think, what's the last time you saw a Coke or beer ad depicting smiling people 85 years old? Never. Instead, the only American ads featuring white-haired old people are ads for retirement homes and pension planning.Well, what has changed in the status of the elderly today compared to their status in traditional societies? There have been a few changes for the better and more changes for the worse. Big changes for the better include the fact that today we enjoy much longer lives, much better health in our old age, and much better recreational opportunities. Another change for the better is that we now have specialized retirement facilities and programs to take care of old people. Changes for the worse begin with the cruel reality that we now have more old people and fewer young people than at any time in the past. That means that all those old people are more of a burden on the few young people, and that each old person has less individual value. Another big change for the worse in the status of the elderly is the breaking of social ties with age, because older people, their children, and their friends, all move and scatter independently of each other many times during their lives. We Americans move on the average every five years. Hence our older people are likely to end up living distant from their children and the friends of their youth. Yet another change for the worse in the status of the elderly is formal retirement from the workforce, carrying with it a loss of work friendships and a loss of the self-esteem associated with work. Perhaps the biggest change for the worse is that our elderly are objectively less useful than in traditional societies. Widespread literacy means that they are no longer useful as repositories of knowledge. When we want some information, we look it up in a book or we Google it instead of finding some old person to ask. The slow pace of technological change in traditional societies means that what someone learns there as a child is still useful when that person is old, but the rapid pace of technological change today means that what we learn as children is no longer useful 60 years later. And conversely, we older people are not fluent in the technologies essential for surviving in modern society. For example, as a 15-year-old, I was considered outstandingly good at multiplying numbers because I had memorized the multiplication tables and I know how to use logarithms and I'm quick at manipulating a slide rule. Today, though, those skills are utterly useless because any idiot can now multiply eight-digit numbers accurately and instantly with a pocket calculator. Conversely, I at age 75 am incompetent at skills essential for everyday life. My family's first TV set in 1948 had only three knobs that I quickly mastered: an on-off switch, a volume knob, and a channel selector knob. Today, just to watch a program on the TV set in my own house, I have to operate a 41-button TV remote that utterly defeats me. I have to telephone my 25-year-old sons and ask them to talk me through it while I try to push those wretched 41 buttons.What can we do to improve the lives of the elderly in the U.S., and to make better use of their value? That's a huge problem. In my remaining four minutes today, I can offer just a few suggestions. One value of older people is that they are increasingly useful as grandparents for offering high-quality childcare to their grandchildren, if they choose to do it, as more young women enter the workforce and as fewer young parents of either gender stay home as full-time caretakers of their children. Compared to the usual alternatives of paid babysitters and day care centers, grandparents offer superior, motivated, experienced child care. They've already gained experience from raising their own children. They usually love their grandchildren, and are eager to spend time with them. Unlike other caregivers, grandparents don't quit their job because they found another job with higher pay looking after another baby. A second value of older people is paradoxically related to their loss of value as a result of changing world conditions and technology. At the same time, older people have gained in value today precisely because of their unique experience of living conditions that have now become rare because of rapid change, but that could come back. For example, only Americans now in their 70s or older today can remember the experience of living through a great depression, the experience of living through a world war, and agonizing whether or not dropping atomic bombs would be more horrible than the likely consequences of not dropping atomic bombs. Most of our current voters and politicians have no personal experience of any of those things, but millions of older Americans do. Unfortunately, all of those terrible situations could come back. Even if they don't come back, we have to be able to plan for them on the basis of the experience of what they were like. Older people have that experience. Younger people don't.The remaining value of older people that I'll mention involves recognizing that while there are many things that older people can no longer do, there are other things that they can do better than younger people. A challenge for society is  to make use of those things that older people are better at doing. Some abilities, of course, decrease with age. Those include abilities at tasks requiring physical strength and stamina, ambition, and the power of novel reasoning in a circumscribed situation, such as figuring out the structure of DNA, best left to scientists under the age of 30. Conversely, valuable attributes that increase with age include experience, understanding of people and human relationships, ability to help other people without your own ego getting in the way, and interdisciplinary thinking about large databases, such as economics and comparative history, best left to scholars over the age of 60. Hence older people are much better than younger people at supervising, administering, advising, strategizing, teaching, synthesizing, and devising long-term plans. I've seen this value of older people with so many of my friends in their 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s, who are still active as investment managers, farmers, lawyers and doctors. In short, many traditional societies make better use of their elderly and give their elderly more satisfying lives than we do in modern, big societies.Paradoxically nowadays, when we have more elderly people than ever before, living healthier lives and with better medical care than ever before, old age is in some respects more miserable than ever before. The lives of the elderly are widely recognized as constituting a disaster area of modern American society. We can surely do better by learning from the lives of the elderly in traditional societies. But what's true of the lives of the elderly in traditional societies is true of many other features of traditional societies as well. Of course, I'm not advocating that we all give up agriculture and metal tools and return to a hunter-gatherer lifestyle. There are many obvious respects in which our lives today are far happier than those in small, traditional societies. To mention just a few examples, our lives are longer, materially much richer, and less plagued by violence than are the lives of people in traditional societies. But there are also things to be admired about people in traditional societies, and perhaps to be learned from them. Their lives are usually socially much richer than our lives, although materially poorer. Their children are more self-confident, more independent, and more socially skilled than are our children. They think more realistically about dangers than we do. They almost never die of diabetes, heart disease, stroke, and the other noncommunicable diseases that will be the causes of death of almost all of us in this room today. Features of the modern lifestyle predispose us to those diseases, and features of the traditional lifestyle protect us against them.Those are just some examples of what we can learn from traditional societies. I hope that you will find it as fascinating to read about traditional societies as I found it to live in those societies.Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.703 --> 00:00:14.932
To give me an idea of how many of you here

00:00:14.932 --> 00:00:17.054
may find what I'm about to tell you

00:00:17.054 --> 00:00:18.679
of practical value,

00:00:18.679 --> 00:00:21.368
let me ask you please to raise your hands:

00:00:21.368 --> 00:00:24.935
Who here is either over 65 years old

00:00:24.935 --> 00:00:28.704
or hopes to live past age 65

00:00:28.704 --> 00:00:31.649
or has parents or grandparents who did live

00:00:31.649 --> 00:00:33.616
or have lived past 65,

00:00:33.616 --> 00:00:36.201
raise your hands please. (Laughter)

00:00:36.201 --> 00:00:38.355
Okay. You are the people to whom my talk

00:00:38.355 --> 00:00:40.789
will be of practical value. (Laughter)

00:00:40.789 --> 00:00:42.446
The rest of you

00:00:42.446 --> 00:00:44.234
won't find my talk personally relevant,

00:00:44.234 --> 00:00:46.148
but I think that you will still find the subject

00:00:46.148 --> 00:00:47.795
fascinating.

00:00:47.795 --> 00:00:49.427
I'm going to talk about growing older

00:00:49.427 --> 00:00:51.846
in traditional societies.

00:00:51.846 --> 00:00:54.592
This subject constitutes just one chapter

00:00:54.592 --> 00:00:57.183
of my latest book, which compares

00:00:57.183 --> 00:01:00.400
traditional, small, tribal societies

00:01:00.400 --> 00:01:02.950
with our large, modern societies,

00:01:02.950 --> 00:01:04.575
with respect to many topics

00:01:04.575 --> 00:01:06.434
such as bringing up children,

00:01:06.434 --> 00:01:10.355
growing older, health, dealing with danger,

00:01:10.355 --> 00:01:12.700
settling disputes, religion

00:01:12.700 --> 00:01:15.491
and speaking more than one language.

00:01:15.491 --> 00:01:18.048
Those tribal societies, which constituted

00:01:18.048 --> 00:01:21.033
all human societies for most of human history,

00:01:21.033 --> 00:01:24.327
are far more diverse than are our modern,

00:01:24.327 --> 00:01:26.494
recent, big societies.

00:01:26.494 --> 00:01:28.857
All big societies that have governments,

00:01:28.857 --> 00:01:31.123
and where most people are strangers to each other,

00:01:31.123 --> 00:01:33.471
are inevitably similar to each other

00:01:33.471 --> 00:01:36.319
and different from tribal societies.

00:01:36.319 --> 00:01:39.630
Tribes constitute thousands of natural experiments

00:01:39.630 --> 00:01:42.179
in how to run a human society.

00:01:42.179 --> 00:01:44.986
They constitute experiments from which we ourselves

00:01:44.986 --> 00:01:47.388
may be able to learn.

00:01:47.388 --> 00:01:49.408
Tribal societies shouldn't be scorned

00:01:49.408 --> 00:01:51.144
as primitive and miserable,

00:01:51.144 --> 00:01:53.515
but also they shouldn't be romanticized

00:01:53.515 --> 00:01:55.732
as happy and peaceful.

00:01:55.732 --> 00:01:57.991
When we learn of tribal practices,

00:01:57.991 --> 00:01:59.765
some of them will horrify us,

00:01:59.765 --> 00:02:02.315
but there are other tribal practices which,

00:02:02.315 --> 00:02:03.664
when we hear about them,

00:02:03.664 --> 00:02:05.611
we may admire and envy

00:02:05.611 --> 00:02:07.835
and wonder whether we could adopt those practices

00:02:07.835 --> 00:02:10.532
ourselves.

00:02:10.532 --> 00:02:13.619
Most old people in the U.S. end up living

00:02:13.619 --> 00:02:15.606
separately from their children

00:02:15.606 --> 00:02:17.112
and from most of their friends

00:02:17.112 --> 00:02:18.804
of their earlier years,

00:02:18.804 --> 00:02:22.658
and often they live in separate
retirements homes for the elderly,

00:02:22.658 --> 00:02:24.866
whereas in traditional societies,

00:02:24.866 --> 00:02:27.700
older people instead live out their lives

00:02:27.700 --> 00:02:29.866
among their children, their other relatives,

00:02:29.866 --> 00:02:32.263
and their lifelong friends.

00:02:32.263 --> 00:02:34.432
Nevertheless, the treatment of the elderly

00:02:34.432 --> 00:02:37.597
varies enormously among traditional societies,

00:02:37.597 --> 00:02:39.778
from much worse to much better

00:02:39.778 --> 00:02:42.736
than in our modern societies.

00:02:42.736 --> 00:02:45.533
At the worst extreme, many traditional societies

00:02:45.533 --> 00:02:47.346
get rid of their elderly

00:02:47.346 --> 00:02:50.877
in one of four increasingly direct ways:

00:02:50.877 --> 00:02:52.540
by neglecting their elderly

00:02:52.540 --> 00:02:55.969
and not feeding or cleaning them until they die,

00:02:55.969 --> 00:02:59.023
or by abandoning them when the group moves,

00:02:59.023 --> 00:03:02.162
or by encouraging older people to commit suicide,

00:03:02.162 --> 00:03:05.207
or by killing older people.

00:03:05.207 --> 00:03:07.956
In which tribal societies do children

00:03:07.956 --> 00:03:10.342
abandon or kill their parents?

00:03:10.342 --> 00:03:13.366
It happens mainly under two conditions.

00:03:13.366 --> 00:03:16.346
One is in nomadic, hunter-gather societies

00:03:16.346 --> 00:03:18.069
that often shift camp

00:03:18.069 --> 00:03:20.248
and that are physically incapable

00:03:20.248 --> 00:03:23.371
of transporting old people who can't walk

00:03:23.371 --> 00:03:25.931
when the able-bodied younger people already

00:03:25.931 --> 00:03:27.866
have to carry their young children

00:03:27.866 --> 00:03:30.684
and all their physical possessions.

00:03:30.684 --> 00:03:32.848
The other condition is in societies

00:03:32.848 --> 00:03:36.158
living in marginal or fluctuating environments,

00:03:36.158 --> 00:03:38.491
such as the Arctic or deserts,

00:03:38.491 --> 00:03:41.075
where there are periodic food shortages,

00:03:41.075 --> 00:03:43.004
and occasionally there just isn't enough food

00:03:43.004 --> 00:03:45.484
to keep everyone alive.

00:03:45.484 --> 00:03:47.908
Whatever food is available has to be reserved

00:03:47.908 --> 00:03:52.233
for able-bodied adults and for children.

00:03:52.233 --> 00:03:55.133
To us Americans, it sounds horrible

00:03:55.133 --> 00:03:57.366
to think of abandoning or killing

00:03:57.366 --> 00:03:59.547
your own sick wife or husband

00:03:59.547 --> 00:04:01.846
or elderly mother or father,

00:04:01.846 --> 00:04:05.605
but what could those traditional societies

00:04:05.605 --> 00:04:07.088
do differently?

00:04:07.088 --> 00:04:10.908
They face a cruel situation of no choice.

00:04:10.908 --> 00:04:13.903
Their old people had to do it to their own parents,

00:04:13.903 --> 00:04:15.191
and the old people know

00:04:15.191 --> 00:04:18.342
what now is going to happen to them.

00:04:18.342 --> 00:04:20.156
At the opposite extreme

00:04:20.156 --> 00:04:22.835
in treatment of the elderly, the happy extreme,

00:04:22.835 --> 00:04:24.822
are the New Guinea farming societies

00:04:24.822 --> 00:04:27.819
where I've been doing my fieldwork 
for the past 50 years,

00:04:27.819 --> 00:04:31.066
and most other sedentary traditional societies

00:04:31.066 --> 00:04:33.152
around the world.

00:04:33.152 --> 00:04:36.100
In those societies, older people are cared for.

00:04:36.100 --> 00:04:38.450
They are fed. They remain valuable.

00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:40.638
And they continue to live in the same hut

00:04:40.638 --> 00:04:43.325
or else in a nearby hut near their children,

00:04:43.325 --> 00:04:47.224
relatives and lifelong friends.

00:04:47.224 --> 00:04:49.656
There are two main sets of reasons for this variation

00:04:49.656 --> 00:04:52.011
among societies in their treatment

00:04:52.011 --> 00:04:53.408
of old people.

00:04:53.408 --> 00:04:55.045
The variation depends especially

00:04:55.045 --> 00:04:57.315
on the usefulness of old people

00:04:57.315 --> 00:05:00.028
and on the society's values.

00:05:00.028 --> 00:05:02.351
First, as regards usefulness,

00:05:02.351 --> 00:05:05.806
older people continue to perform useful services.

00:05:05.806 --> 00:05:08.491
One use of older people in traditional societies

00:05:08.491 --> 00:05:10.491
is that they often are still effective

00:05:10.491 --> 00:05:12.904
at producing food.

00:05:12.904 --> 00:05:15.317
Another traditional usefulness of older people

00:05:15.317 --> 00:05:18.596
is that they are capable of babysitting

00:05:18.596 --> 00:05:20.290
their grandchildren,

00:05:20.290 --> 00:05:22.960
thereby freeing up their own adult children,

00:05:22.960 --> 00:05:24.831
the parents of those grandchildren,

00:05:24.831 --> 00:05:28.304
to go hunting and gathering
food for the grandchildren.

00:05:28.304 --> 00:05:30.509
Still another traditional value of older people

00:05:30.509 --> 00:05:33.429
is in making tools, weapons, baskets,

00:05:33.429 --> 00:05:35.386
pots and textiles.

00:05:35.386 --> 00:05:38.635
In fact, they're usually the people who are best at it.

00:05:38.635 --> 00:05:41.403
Older people usually are the leaders

00:05:41.403 --> 00:05:43.252
of traditional societies,

00:05:43.252 --> 00:05:46.511
and the people most knowledgeable about politics,

00:05:46.511 --> 00:05:50.510
medicine, religion, songs and dances.

00:05:50.510 --> 00:05:52.962
Finally, older people in traditional societies

00:05:52.962 --> 00:05:56.889
have a huge significance that would never occur

00:05:56.889 --> 00:06:00.565
to us in our modern, literate societies,

00:06:00.565 --> 00:06:02.980
where our sources of information are books

00:06:02.980 --> 00:06:04.664
and the Internet.

00:06:04.664 --> 00:06:08.087
In contrast, in traditional societies without writing,

00:06:08.087 --> 00:06:11.773
older people are the repositories of information.

00:06:11.773 --> 00:06:14.338
It's their knowledge that spells the difference

00:06:14.338 --> 00:06:18.088
between survival and death for their whole society

00:06:18.088 --> 00:06:21.346
in a time of crisis caused by rare events

00:06:21.346 --> 00:06:23.941
for which only the oldest people alive

00:06:23.941 --> 00:06:26.230
have had experience.

00:06:26.230 --> 00:06:28.700
Those, then, are the ways in which older people

00:06:28.700 --> 00:06:31.603
are useful in traditional societies.

00:06:31.603 --> 00:06:34.165
Their usefulness varies and contributes

00:06:34.165 --> 00:06:36.783
to variation in the society's treatment

00:06:36.783 --> 00:06:38.783
of the elderly.

00:06:38.783 --> 00:06:40.602
The other set of reasons for variation

00:06:40.602 --> 00:06:42.477
in the treatment of the elderly is

00:06:42.477 --> 00:06:45.712
the society's cultural values.

00:06:45.712 --> 00:06:47.738
For example, there's particular emphasis

00:06:47.738 --> 00:06:50.947
on respect for the elderly in East Asia,

00:06:50.947 --> 00:06:53.858
associated with Confucius' doctrine

00:06:53.858 --> 00:06:57.408
of filial piety, which means obedience,

00:06:57.408 --> 00:07:01.502
respect and support for elderly parents.

00:07:01.502 --> 00:07:05.215
Cultural values that emphasize
respect for older people

00:07:05.215 --> 00:07:08.032
contrast with the low status of the elderly

00:07:08.032 --> 00:07:10.194
in the U.S.

00:07:10.194 --> 00:07:12.752
Older Americans are at a big disadvantage

00:07:12.752 --> 00:07:14.865
in job applications.

00:07:14.865 --> 00:07:17.400
They're at a big disadvantage in hospitals.

00:07:17.400 --> 00:07:20.023
Our hospitals have an explicit policy

00:07:20.023 --> 00:07:24.990
called age-based allocation of healthcare resources.

00:07:24.990 --> 00:07:27.763
That sinister expression means that

00:07:27.763 --> 00:07:29.969
if hospital resources are limited,

00:07:29.969 --> 00:07:32.019
for example if only one donor heart

00:07:32.019 --> 00:07:34.317
becomes available for transplant,

00:07:34.317 --> 00:07:36.419
or if a surgeon has time to operate

00:07:36.419 --> 00:07:38.930
on only a certain number of patients,

00:07:38.930 --> 00:07:41.880
American hospitals have an explicit policy

00:07:41.880 --> 00:07:44.200
of giving preference to younger patients

00:07:44.200 --> 00:07:45.680
over older patients

00:07:45.680 --> 00:07:48.924
on the grounds that younger patients are considered

00:07:48.924 --> 00:07:50.741
more valuable to society

00:07:50.741 --> 00:07:53.386
because they have more years of life ahead of them,

00:07:53.386 --> 00:07:56.046
even though the younger patients have fewer years

00:07:56.046 --> 00:08:00.028
of valuable life experience behind them.

00:08:00.028 --> 00:08:02.256
There are several reasons for this low status

00:08:02.256 --> 00:08:04.598
of the elderly in the U.S.

00:08:04.598 --> 00:08:07.783
One is our Protestant work ethic

00:08:07.783 --> 00:08:10.096
which places high value on work,

00:08:10.096 --> 00:08:12.319
so older people who are no longer working

00:08:12.319 --> 00:08:14.302
aren't respected.

00:08:14.302 --> 00:08:17.159
Another reason is our American emphasis

00:08:17.159 --> 00:08:20.542
on the virtues of self-reliance and independence,

00:08:20.542 --> 00:08:23.611
so we instinctively look down on older people

00:08:23.611 --> 00:08:27.208
who are no longer self-reliant and independent.

00:08:27.208 --> 00:08:31.309
Still a third reason is our American cult of youth,

00:08:31.309 --> 00:08:34.117
which shows up even in our advertisements.

00:08:34.117 --> 00:08:37.381
Ads for Coca-Cola and beer always depict

00:08:37.381 --> 00:08:38.936
smiling young people,

00:08:38.936 --> 00:08:40.906
even though old as well as young people

00:08:40.906 --> 00:08:43.228
buy and drink Coca-Cola and beer.

00:08:43.228 --> 00:08:45.231
Just think, what's the last time you saw

00:08:45.231 --> 00:08:47.908
a Coke or beer ad depicting smiling people

00:08:47.908 --> 00:08:50.857
85 years old? Never.

00:08:50.857 --> 00:08:52.663
Instead, the only American ads

00:08:52.663 --> 00:08:54.669
featuring white-haired old people

00:08:54.669 --> 00:08:58.534
are ads for retirement homes and pension planning.

00:08:58.534 --> 00:09:00.584
Well, what has changed in the status

00:09:00.584 --> 00:09:02.567
of the elderly today

00:09:02.567 --> 00:09:05.956
compared to their status in traditional societies?

00:09:05.956 --> 00:09:07.826
There have been a few changes for the better

00:09:07.826 --> 00:09:10.031
and more changes for the worse.

00:09:10.031 --> 00:09:11.632
Big changes for the better

00:09:11.632 --> 00:09:13.783
include the fact that today we enjoy

00:09:13.783 --> 00:09:15.767
much longer lives,

00:09:15.767 --> 00:09:18.061
much better health in our old age,

00:09:18.061 --> 00:09:21.699
and much better recreational opportunities.

00:09:21.699 --> 00:09:23.969
Another change for the better is that we now have

00:09:23.969 --> 00:09:26.809
specialized retirement facilities

00:09:26.809 --> 00:09:30.160
and programs to take care of old people.

00:09:30.160 --> 00:09:33.028
Changes for the worse begin with the cruel reality

00:09:33.028 --> 00:09:34.717
that we now have

00:09:34.717 --> 00:09:37.291
more old people and fewer young people

00:09:37.291 --> 00:09:39.975
than at any time in the past.

00:09:39.975 --> 00:09:41.726
That means that all those old people

00:09:41.726 --> 00:09:44.151
are more of a burden on the few young people,

00:09:44.151 --> 00:09:48.637
and that each old person has less individual value.

00:09:48.637 --> 00:09:51.821
Another big change for the worse
in the status of the elderly

00:09:51.821 --> 00:09:54.498
is the breaking of social ties with age,

00:09:54.498 --> 00:09:56.342
because older people, their children,

00:09:56.342 --> 00:09:57.658
and their friends,

00:09:57.658 --> 00:10:00.508
all move and scatter independently of each other

00:10:00.508 --> 00:10:02.762
many times during their lives.

00:10:02.762 --> 00:10:04.575
We Americans move on the average

00:10:04.575 --> 00:10:06.528
every five years.

00:10:06.528 --> 00:10:08.559
Hence our older people are likely

00:10:08.559 --> 00:10:10.866
to end up living distant from their children

00:10:10.866 --> 00:10:13.669
and the friends of their youth.

00:10:13.669 --> 00:10:16.831
Yet another change for the worse
in the status of the elderly

00:10:16.831 --> 00:10:20.561
is formal retirement from the workforce,

00:10:20.561 --> 00:10:23.311
carrying with it a loss of work friendships

00:10:23.311 --> 00:10:27.451
and a loss of the self-esteem associated with work.

00:10:27.451 --> 00:10:29.936
Perhaps the biggest change for the worse

00:10:29.936 --> 00:10:32.809
is that our elderly are objectively

00:10:32.809 --> 00:10:35.971
less useful than in traditional societies.

00:10:35.971 --> 00:10:38.934
Widespread literacy means that they are no longer

00:10:38.934 --> 00:10:41.565
useful as repositories of knowledge.

00:10:41.565 --> 00:10:43.508
When we want some information,

00:10:43.508 --> 00:10:45.769
we look it up in a book or we Google it

00:10:45.769 --> 00:10:49.239
instead of finding some old person to ask.

00:10:49.239 --> 00:10:51.326
The slow pace of technological change

00:10:51.326 --> 00:10:53.148
in traditional societies

00:10:53.148 --> 00:10:55.998
means that what someone learns there as a child

00:10:55.998 --> 00:10:58.657
is still useful when that person is old,

00:10:58.657 --> 00:11:02.260
but the rapid pace of technological change today

00:11:02.260 --> 00:11:04.327
means that what we learn as children

00:11:04.327 --> 00:11:07.217
is no longer useful 60 years later.

00:11:07.217 --> 00:11:09.596
And conversely, we older people are not fluent

00:11:09.596 --> 00:11:12.630
in the technologies essential for surviving

00:11:12.630 --> 00:11:14.601
in modern society.

00:11:14.601 --> 00:11:16.774
For example, as a 15-year-old,

00:11:16.774 --> 00:11:20.364
I was considered outstandingly
good at multiplying numbers

00:11:20.364 --> 00:11:23.559
because I had memorized the multiplication tables

00:11:23.559 --> 00:11:25.704
and I know how to use logarithms

00:11:25.704 --> 00:11:28.567
and I'm quick at manipulating a slide rule.

00:11:28.567 --> 00:11:31.653
Today, though, those skills are utterly useless

00:11:31.653 --> 00:11:34.024
because any idiot

00:11:34.024 --> 00:11:36.382
can now multiply eight-digit numbers

00:11:36.382 --> 00:11:39.569
accurately and instantly with a pocket calculator.

00:11:39.569 --> 00:11:41.739
Conversely, I at age 75

00:11:41.739 --> 00:11:44.403
am incompetent at skills

00:11:44.403 --> 00:11:46.857
essential for everyday life.

00:11:46.857 --> 00:11:49.641
My family's first TV set in 1948

00:11:49.641 --> 00:11:52.694
had only three knobs that I quickly mastered:

00:11:52.694 --> 00:11:55.444
an on-off switch, a volume knob,

00:11:55.444 --> 00:11:57.665
and a channel selector knob.

00:11:57.665 --> 00:11:59.753
Today, just to watch a program

00:11:59.753 --> 00:12:02.209
on the TV set in my own house,

00:12:02.209 --> 00:12:05.926
I have to operate a 41-button TV remote

00:12:05.926 --> 00:12:07.908
that utterly defeats me.

00:12:07.908 --> 00:12:10.922
I have to telephone my 25-year-old sons

00:12:10.922 --> 00:12:13.119
and ask them to talk me through it

00:12:13.119 --> 00:12:18.116
while I try to push those wretched 41 buttons.

00:12:18.116 --> 00:12:20.763
What can we do to improve the lives of the elderly

00:12:20.763 --> 00:12:24.217
in the U.S., and to make better use of their value?

00:12:24.217 --> 00:12:25.991
That's a huge problem.

00:12:25.991 --> 00:12:28.462
In my remaining four minutes today,

00:12:28.462 --> 00:12:31.039
I can offer just a few suggestions.

00:12:31.039 --> 00:12:32.961
One value of older people is that they are

00:12:32.961 --> 00:12:36.405
increasingly useful as grandparents

00:12:36.405 --> 00:12:38.912
for offering high-quality childcare

00:12:38.912 --> 00:12:41.565
to their grandchildren, if they choose to do it,

00:12:41.565 --> 00:12:44.414
as more young women enter the workforce

00:12:44.414 --> 00:12:46.748
and as fewer young parents of either gender

00:12:46.748 --> 00:12:50.408
stay home as full-time caretakers of their children.

00:12:50.408 --> 00:12:52.444
Compared to the usual alternatives

00:12:52.444 --> 00:12:56.042
of paid babysitters and day care centers,

00:12:56.042 --> 00:12:59.169
grandparents offer superior, motivated,

00:12:59.169 --> 00:13:01.857
experienced child care.

00:13:01.857 --> 00:13:05.123
They've already gained experience
from raising their own children.

00:13:05.123 --> 00:13:07.467
They usually love their grandchildren,

00:13:07.467 --> 00:13:10.132
and are eager to spend time with them.

00:13:10.132 --> 00:13:12.033
Unlike other caregivers,

00:13:12.033 --> 00:13:14.930
grandparents don't quit their job

00:13:14.930 --> 00:13:17.366
because they found another job with higher pay

00:13:17.366 --> 00:13:20.879
looking after another baby.

00:13:20.879 --> 00:13:23.283
A second value of older people is paradoxically

00:13:23.283 --> 00:13:25.944
related to their loss of value

00:13:25.944 --> 00:13:30.017
as a result of changing world
conditions and technology.

00:13:30.017 --> 00:13:32.053
At the same time, older people have gained

00:13:32.053 --> 00:13:34.364
in value today precisely because

00:13:34.364 --> 00:13:37.473
of their unique experience of living conditions

00:13:37.473 --> 00:13:39.192
that have now become rare

00:13:39.192 --> 00:13:42.502
because of rapid change, but that could come back.

00:13:42.502 --> 00:13:45.456
For example, only Americans now in their 70s

00:13:45.456 --> 00:13:47.716
or older today can remember

00:13:47.716 --> 00:13:51.044
the experience of living through a great depression,

00:13:51.044 --> 00:13:53.682
the experience of living through a world war,

00:13:53.682 --> 00:13:56.228
and agonizing whether or not

00:13:56.228 --> 00:13:59.265
dropping atomic bombs would be more horrible

00:13:59.265 --> 00:14:03.378
than the likely consequences
of not dropping atomic bombs.

00:14:03.378 --> 00:14:05.654
Most of our current voters and politicians

00:14:05.654 --> 00:14:08.386
have no personal experience of any of those things,

00:14:08.386 --> 00:14:11.081
but millions of older Americans do.

00:14:11.081 --> 00:14:13.732
Unfortunately, all of those terrible situations

00:14:13.732 --> 00:14:15.119
could come back.

00:14:15.119 --> 00:14:16.425
Even if they don't come back,

00:14:16.425 --> 00:14:18.617
we have to be able to plan for them

00:14:18.617 --> 00:14:21.428
on the basis of the experience of what they were like.

00:14:21.428 --> 00:14:23.262
Older people have that experience.

00:14:23.262 --> 00:14:25.315
Younger people don't.

00:14:25.315 --> 00:14:26.835
The remaining value of older people

00:14:26.835 --> 00:14:29.278
that I'll mention involves recognizing that

00:14:29.278 --> 00:14:31.858
while there are many things that older people

00:14:31.858 --> 00:14:33.464
can no longer do,

00:14:33.464 --> 00:14:34.953
there are other things that they can do

00:14:34.953 --> 00:14:37.048
better than younger people.

00:14:37.048 --> 00:14:39.944
A challenge for society is 
to make use of those things

00:14:39.944 --> 00:14:42.416
that older people are better at doing.

00:14:42.416 --> 00:14:45.665
Some abilities, of course, decrease with age.

00:14:45.665 --> 00:14:48.303
Those include abilities at tasks

00:14:48.303 --> 00:14:51.874
requiring physical strength and stamina,

00:14:51.874 --> 00:14:54.998
ambition, and the power of novel reasoning

00:14:54.998 --> 00:14:57.423
in a circumscribed situation,

00:14:57.423 --> 00:15:00.011
such as figuring out the structure of DNA,

00:15:00.011 --> 00:15:03.912
best left to scientists under the age of 30.

00:15:03.912 --> 00:15:05.561
Conversely, valuable attributes

00:15:05.561 --> 00:15:09.107
that increase with age include experience,

00:15:09.107 --> 00:15:12.120
understanding of people and human relationships,

00:15:12.120 --> 00:15:14.411
ability to help other people

00:15:14.411 --> 00:15:16.839
without your own ego getting in the way,

00:15:16.839 --> 00:15:20.364
and interdisciplinary thinking about large databases,

00:15:20.364 --> 00:15:23.189
such as economics and comparative history,

00:15:23.189 --> 00:15:26.403
best left to scholars over the age of 60.

00:15:26.403 --> 00:15:28.875
Hence older people are
much better than younger people

00:15:28.875 --> 00:15:32.846
at supervising, administering, advising,

00:15:32.846 --> 00:15:36.328
strategizing, teaching, synthesizing,

00:15:36.328 --> 00:15:39.034
and devising long-term plans.

00:15:39.034 --> 00:15:41.054
I've seen this value of older people

00:15:41.054 --> 00:15:43.626
with so many of my friends in their 60s,

00:15:43.626 --> 00:15:45.616
70s, 80s and 90s,

00:15:45.616 --> 00:15:48.901
who are still active as investment managers,

00:15:48.901 --> 00:15:51.914
farmers, lawyers and doctors.

00:15:51.914 --> 00:15:54.044
In short, many traditional societies

00:15:54.044 --> 00:15:56.157
make better use of their elderly

00:15:56.157 --> 00:15:59.267
and give their elderly more satisfying lives

00:15:59.267 --> 00:16:02.117
than we do in modern, big societies.

00:16:02.117 --> 00:16:03.982
Paradoxically nowadays,

00:16:03.982 --> 00:16:06.908
when we have more elderly people than ever before,

00:16:06.908 --> 00:16:09.629
living healthier lives and with better medical care

00:16:09.629 --> 00:16:11.115
than ever before,

00:16:11.115 --> 00:16:13.822
old age is in some respects more miserable

00:16:13.822 --> 00:16:15.589
than ever before.

00:16:15.589 --> 00:16:18.011
The lives of the elderly are widely recognized

00:16:18.011 --> 00:16:20.778
as constituting a disaster area

00:16:20.778 --> 00:16:23.311
of modern American society.

00:16:23.311 --> 00:16:24.992
We can surely do better by learning

00:16:24.992 --> 00:16:26.867
from the lives of the elderly

00:16:26.867 --> 00:16:28.879
in traditional societies.

00:16:28.879 --> 00:16:30.821
But what's true of the lives of the elderly

00:16:30.821 --> 00:16:32.285
in traditional societies

00:16:32.285 --> 00:16:33.980
is true of many other features

00:16:33.980 --> 00:16:36.574
of traditional societies as well.

00:16:36.574 --> 00:16:39.163
Of course, I'm not advocating that we all give up

00:16:39.163 --> 00:16:41.278
agriculture and metal tools

00:16:41.278 --> 00:16:44.362
and return to a hunter-gatherer lifestyle.

00:16:44.362 --> 00:16:45.906
There are many obvious respects

00:16:45.906 --> 00:16:48.385
in which our lives today are far happier

00:16:48.385 --> 00:16:51.447
than those in small, traditional societies.

00:16:51.447 --> 00:16:53.153
To mention just a few examples,

00:16:53.153 --> 00:16:56.123
our lives are longer, materially much richer,

00:16:56.123 --> 00:16:58.406
and less plagued by violence

00:16:58.406 --> 00:17:01.634
than are the lives of people in traditional societies.

00:17:01.634 --> 00:17:04.162
But there are also things to be admired

00:17:04.162 --> 00:17:06.304
about people in traditional societies,

00:17:06.304 --> 00:17:08.623
and perhaps to be learned from them.

00:17:08.623 --> 00:17:11.214
Their lives are usually socially much richer

00:17:11.214 --> 00:17:12.806
than our lives,

00:17:12.806 --> 00:17:15.098
although materially poorer.

00:17:15.098 --> 00:17:18.050
Their children are more self-confident,

00:17:18.050 --> 00:17:20.644
more independent, and more socially skilled

00:17:20.644 --> 00:17:22.980
than are our children.

00:17:22.980 --> 00:17:26.723
They think more realistically
about dangers than we do.

00:17:26.723 --> 00:17:30.252
They almost never die of diabetes, heart disease,

00:17:30.252 --> 00:17:33.486
stroke, and the other noncommunicable diseases

00:17:33.486 --> 00:17:35.998
that will be the causes of death of almost

00:17:35.998 --> 00:17:39.084
all of us in this room today.

00:17:39.084 --> 00:17:43.094
Features of the modern lifestyle
predispose us to those diseases,

00:17:43.094 --> 00:17:45.328
and features of the traditional lifestyle

00:17:45.328 --> 00:17:47.835
protect us against them.

00:17:47.835 --> 00:17:49.994
Those are just some examples of what we can learn

00:17:49.994 --> 00:17:52.282
from traditional societies.

00:17:52.282 --> 00:17:54.169
I hope that you will find it as fascinating

00:17:54.169 --> 00:17:56.578
to read about traditional societies

00:17:56.578 --> 00:17:59.281
as I found it to live in those societies.

00:17:59.281 --> 00:18:01.461
Thank you.

00:18:01.461 --> 00:18:05.908
(Applause)

title: What is so special about the human brain?
transcript: What is so special about the human brain? Why is it that we study other animals instead of them studying us? What does a human brain have or do that no other brain does? When I became interested in these questions about 10 years ago, scientists thought they knew what different brains were made of. Though it was based on very little evidence, many scientists thought that all mammalian brains, including the human brain, were made in the same way, with a number of neurons that was always proportional to the size of the brain. This means that two brains of the same size, like these two, with a respectable 400 grams, should have similar numbers of neurons. Now, if neurons are the functional information processing units of the brain, then the owners of these two brains should have similar cognitive abilities. And yet, one is a chimp, and the other is a cow. Now maybe cows have a really rich internal mental life and are so smart that they choose not to let us realize it, but we eat them. I think most people will agree that chimps are capable of much more complex, elaborate and flexible behaviors than cows are. So this is a first indication that the "all brains are made the same way" scenario is not quite right.But let's play along. If all brains were made the same way and you were to compare animals with brains of different sizes, larger brains should always have more neurons than smaller brains, and the larger the brain, the more cognitively able its owner should be. So the largest brain around should also be the most cognitively able. And here comes the bad news: Our brain, not the largest one around. It seems quite vexing. Our brain weighs between 1.2 and 1.5 kilos, but elephant brains weigh between four and five kilos, and whale brains can weigh up to nine kilos, which is why scientists used to resort to saying that our brain must be special to explain our cognitive abilities. It must be really extraordinary, an exception to the rule. Theirs may be bigger, but ours is better, and it could be better, for example, in that it seems larger than it should be, with a much larger cerebral cortex than we should have for the size of our bodies. So that would give us extra cortex to do more interesting things than just operating the body. That's because the size of the brain usually follows the size of the body. So the main reason for saying that our brain is larger than it should be actually comes from comparing ourselves to great apes. Gorillas can be two to three times larger than we are, so their brains should also be larger than ours, but instead it's the other way around. Our brain is three times larger than a gorilla brain.The human brain also seems special in the amount of energy that it uses. Although it weighs only two percent of the body, it alone uses 25 percent of all the energy that your body requires to run per day. That's 500 calories out of a total of 2,000 calories, just to keep your brain working.So the human brain is larger than it should be, it uses much more energy than it should, so it's special. And this is where the story started to bother me. In biology, we look for rules that apply to all animals and to life in general, so why should the rules of evolution apply to everybody else but not to us? Maybe the problem was with the basic assumption that all brains are made in the same way. Maybe two brains of a similar size can actually be made of very different numbers of neurons. Maybe a very large brain does not necessarily have more neurons than a more modest-sized brain. Maybe the human brain  actually has the most neurons of any brain, regardless of its size, especially in the cerebral cortex. So this to me became the important question to answer: how many neurons does the human brain have, and how does that compare to other animals?Now, you may have heard or read somewhere that we have 100 billion neurons, so 10 years ago, I asked my colleagues if they knew where this number came from. But nobody did. I've been digging through the literature for the original reference for that number, and I could never find it. It seems that nobody had actually ever counted the number of neurons in the human brain, or in any other brain for that matter.So I came up with my own way to count cells in the brain, and it essentially consists of dissolving that brain into soup. It works like this: You take a brain, or parts of that brain, and you dissolve it in detergent, which destroys the cell membranes but keeps the cell nuclei intact, so you end up with a suspension of free nuclei that looks like this, like a clear soup. This soup contains all the nuclei that once were a mouse brain. Now, the beauty of a soup is that because it is soup, you can agitate it and make those nuclei be distributed homogeneously in the liquid, so that now by looking under the microscope at just four or five samples of this homogeneous solution, you can count nuclei, and therefore tell how many cells that brain had. It's simple, it's straightforward, and it's really fast. So we've used that method to count neurons in dozens of different species so far, and it turns out that all brains are not made the same way. Take rodents and primates, for instance: In larger rodent brains, the average size of the neuron increases, so the brain inflates very rapidly and gains size much faster than it gains neurons. But primate brains gain neurons without the average neuron becoming any larger, which is a very economical way to add neurons to your brain. The result is that a primate brain will always have more neurons than a rodent brain of the same size, and the larger the brain, the larger this difference will be. Well, what about our brain then? We found that we have, on average, 86 billion neurons, 16 billion of which are in the cerebral cortex, and if you consider that the cerebral cortex is the seat of functions like awareness and logical and abstract reasoning, and that 16 billion is the most neurons that any cortex has, I think this is the simplest explanation for our remarkable cognitive abilities. But just as important is what the 86 billion neurons mean. Because we found that the relationship between the size of the brain and its number of neurons could be described mathematically, we could calculate what a human brain would look like if it was made like a rodent brain. So, a rodent brain with 86 billion neurons would weigh 36 kilos. That's not possible. A brain that huge would be crushed by its own weight, and this impossible brain would go in the body of 89 tons. I don't think it looks like us.So this brings us to a very important conclusion already, which is that we are not rodents. The human brain is not a large rat brain. Compared to a rat, we might seem special, yes, but that's not a fair comparison to make, given that we know that we are not rodents. We are primates, so the correct comparison is to other primates. And there, if you do the math, you find that a generic primate with 86 billion neurons would have a brain of about 1.2 kilos, which seems just right, in a body of some 66 kilos, which in my case is exactly right, which brings us to a very unsurprising but still incredibly important conclusion: I am a primate. And all of you are primates.And so was Darwin. I love to think that Darwin would have really appreciated this. His brain, like ours, was made in the image of other primate brains.So the human brain may be remarkable, yes, but it is not special in its number of neurons. It is just a large primate brain. I think that's a very humbling and sobering thought that should remind us of our place in nature.Why does it cost so much energy, then? Well, other people have figured out how much energy the human brain and that of other species costs, and now that we knew how many neurons each brain was made of, we could do the math. And it turns out that both human and other brains cost about the same, an average of six calories  per billion neurons per day. So the total energetic cost of a brain is a simple, linear function of its number of neurons, and it turns out that the human brain costs just as much energy as you would expect. So the reason why the human brain costs so much energy is simply because it has a huge number of neurons, and because we are primates with many more neurons for a given body size than any other animal, the relative cost of our brain is large, but just because we're primates, not because we're special.Last question, then: how did we come by this remarkable number of neurons, and in particular, if great apes are larger than we are, why don't they have a larger brain  than we do, with more neurons? When we realized how much expensive it is to have a lot of neurons in the brain, I figured, maybe there's a simple reason. They just can't afford the energy for both a large body  and a large number of neurons. So we did the math. We calculated on the one hand how much energy a primate gets per day from eating raw foods, and on the other hand, how much energy a body of a certain size costs and how much energy a brain of a certain number of neurons costs, and we looked for the combinations of body size and number of brain neurons that a primate could afford if it ate a certain number of hours per day.And what we found is that because neurons are so expensive, there is a tradeoff between body size and number of neurons. So a primate that eats eight hours per day can afford at most 53 billion neurons, but then its body cannot be any bigger than 25 kilos. To weigh any more than that, it has to give up neurons. So it's either a large body or a large number of neurons. When you eat like a primate, you can't afford both.One way out of this metabolic limitation would be to spend even more hours per day eating, but that gets dangerous, and past a certain point, it's just not possible. Gorillas and orangutans, for instance, afford about 30 billion neurons by spending eight and a half hours per day eating, and that seems to be about as much as they can do. Nine hours of feeding per day seems to be the practical limit for a primate.What about us? With our 86 billion neurons and 60 to 70 kilos of body mass, we should have to spend over nine hours per day every single day feeding, which is just not feasible. If we ate like a primate, we should not be here.How did we get here, then? Well, if our brain costs just as much energy as it should, and if we can't spend every waking hour of the day feeding, then the only alternative, really, is to somehow get more energy out of the same foods. And remarkably, that matches exactly what our ancestors are believed to have invented one and a half million years ago, when they invented cooking. To cook is to use fire to pre-digest foods outside of your body. Cooked foods are softer, so they're easier to chew and to turn completely into mush in your mouth, so that allows them to be completely digested and absorbed in your gut, which makes them yield much more energy in much less time. So cooking frees time for us to do much more interesting things with our day and with our neurons than just thinking about food, looking for food, and gobbling down food all day long.So because of cooking, what once was a major liability, this large, dangerously expensive brain with a lot of neurons, could now become a major asset, now that we could both afford  the energy for a lot of neurons and the time to do interesting things with them. So I think this explains why the human brain grew to become so large so fast in evolution, all of the while remaining just a primate brain. With this large brain now affordable by cooking, we went rapidly from raw foods to culture, agriculture, civilization, grocery stores, electricity, refrigerators, all of those things that nowadays allow us to get all the energy we need for the whole day in a single sitting at your favorite fast food joint. So what once was a solution now became the problem, and ironically, we look for the solution in raw food.So what is the human advantage? What is it that we have that no other animal has? My answer is that we have the largest number of neurons in the cerebral cortex, and I think that's the simplest explanation for our remarkable cognitive abilities. And what is it that we do that no other animal does, and which I believe was fundamental to allow us to reach that large, largest number of neurons in the cortex? In two words, we cook. No other animal cooks its food. Only humans do. And I think that's how we got to become human.Studying the human brain changed  the way I think about food. I now look at my kitchen, and I bow to it, and I thank my ancestors for coming up with the invention that probably made us humans. Thank you very much. (Applause)
