00:01:24.857 --> 00:01:28.756
that all of my peers were men and women, 
all the people above me were all men,

00:01:28.756 --> 00:01:29.854
but that would change,

00:01:29.854 --> 00:01:34.387
because your generation had done such 
an amazing job fighting for equality,

00:01:34.387 --> 00:01:37.999
equality was now ours for the taking. And it wasn't.

00:01:37.999 --> 00:01:41.334
Because year after year, I was one of fewer and fewer,

00:01:41.334 --> 00:01:43.286
and now, often the only woman in a room.

00:01:43.286 --> 00:01:45.376
And I talked to a bunch of people about,

00:01:45.376 --> 00:01:48.797
should I give a speech at TEDWomen 
about women, and they said, oh no, no.

00:01:48.797 --> 00:01:53.991
It will end your business career. You 
cannot be a serious business executive

00:01:53.991 --> 00:01:57.429
and speak about being a woman. 
You'll never be taken seriously again.

00:01:57.429 --> 00:02:02.304
But fortunately, there were the few, the proud -- like you -- who told me I should give the speech,

00:02:02.304 --> 00:02:04.960
and I asked myself the question 
Mark Zuckerberg might --

00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:06.798
the founder of Facebook and my boss --

00:02:06.798 --> 00:02:11.377
asks all of us, which is, what 
would I do if I wasn't afraid?

00:02:11.377 --> 00:02:15.185
And the answer to what would I do if I wasn't 
afraid is I would get on the TED stage,

00:02:15.199 --> 00:02:22.704
and talk about women, and leadership. 
And I did, and survived. (Applause)

00:02:22.704 --> 00:02:26.539
PM: I would say, not only survived. 
I'm thinking of that moment, Sheryl,

00:02:26.539 --> 00:02:30.872
when you and I were standing backstage 
together, and you turned to me,

00:02:30.872 --> 00:02:32.610
and you told me a story.

00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:36.489
And I said -- very last minute -- you know, 
you really should share that story.

00:02:36.489 --> 00:02:38.239
SS: Oh, yeah.
PM: What was that story?

00:02:38.239 --> 00:02:41.504
SS: Well, it's an important part of the 
journey. So I had -- TEDWomen --

00:02:41.504 --> 00:02:45.313
the original one was in D.C. -- so I live here, 
so I had gotten on a plane the day before,

00:02:45.313 --> 00:02:50.362
and my daughter was three, she was 
clinging to my leg: "Mommy, don't go."

00:02:50.362 --> 00:02:54.095
And Pat's a friend, and so, not related 
to the speech I was planning on giving,

00:02:54.095 --> 00:02:58.557
which was chock full of facts and 
figures, and nothing personal,

00:02:58.557 --> 00:03:00.823
I told Pat the story. I said, well, 
I'm having a hard day.

00:03:00.823 --> 00:03:03.427
Yesterday my daughter was clinging 
to my leg, and "Don't go."

00:03:03.427 --> 00:03:05.171
And you looked at me and said, 
you have to tell that story.

00:03:05.171 --> 00:03:09.406
I said, on the TED stage? Are you kidding?

00:03:09.406 --> 00:03:11.863
I'm going to get on a stage and admit 
my daughter was clinging to my leg?

00:03:11.863 --> 00:03:16.030
And you said yes, because if you want to talk 
about getting more women into leadership roles,

00:03:16.030 --> 00:03:19.167
you have to be honest about how hard it is.

00:03:19.167 --> 00:03:23.903
And I did. And I think that's a really 
important part of the journey.

00:03:23.903 --> 00:03:29.201
The same thing happened when I wrote my book. 
I started writing the book. I wrote a first chapter,

00:03:29.201 --> 00:03:33.167
I thought it was fabulous. It was 
chock-full of data and figures,

00:03:33.167 --> 00:03:41.027
I had three pages on matrilineal Maasai 
tribes, and their sociological patterns.

00:03:41.027 --> 00:03:46.090
My husband read it and he was like, this 
is like eating your Wheaties. (Laughter)

00:03:46.090 --> 00:03:53.455
No one -- and I apologize to Wheaties if there's 
someone -- no one, no one will read this book.

00:03:53.455 --> 00:03:57.640
And I realized through the process that I 
had to be more honest and more open,

00:03:57.640 --> 00:04:02.386
and I had to tell my stories. My stories of still 
not feeling as self-confident as I should,

00:04:02.386 --> 00:04:08.605
in many situations. My first and 
failed marriage. Crying at work.

00:04:08.605 --> 00:04:12.277
Felling like I didn't belong there, 
feeling guilty to this day.

00:04:12.277 --> 00:04:16.672
And part of my journey, starting on this stage, 
going to "Lean In," going to the foundation,

00:04:16.672 --> 00:04:20.560
is all about being more open and 
honest about those challenges,

00:04:20.560 --> 00:04:22.568
so that other women can be more open and honest,

00:04:22.568 --> 00:04:26.200
and all of us can work together towards real equality.

00:04:26.200 --> 00:04:29.542
PM: I think that one of the most 
striking parts about the book,

00:04:29.542 --> 00:04:35.407
and in my opinion, one of the reasons it's hit such 
a nerve and is resonating around the world,

00:04:35.407 --> 00:04:41.192
is that you are personal in the book, 
and that you do make it clear that,

00:04:41.192 --> 00:04:45.350
while you've observed some things that are 
very important for other women to know,

00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:49.909
that you've had the same challenges 
that many others of us have,

00:04:49.909 --> 00:04:56.704
as you faced the hurdles and the barriers and 
possibly the people who don't believe the same.

00:04:56.704 --> 00:05:01.342
So talk about that process: deciding 
you'd go public with the private part,

00:05:01.342 --> 00:05:05.059
and then you would also put yourself in 
the position of something of an expert

00:05:05.059 --> 00:05:08.500
on how to resolve those challenges.

00:05:08.500 --> 00:05:10.684
SS: After I did the TED Talk, what happened was --

00:05:10.684 --> 00:05:14.432
you know, I never really expected to write 
a book, I'm not an author, I'm not a writer,

00:05:14.432 --> 00:05:19.101
and it was viewed a lot, and it really 
started impacting people's lives.

00:05:19.101 --> 00:05:22.621
I got this great --- one of the first 
letters I got was from a woman

00:05:22.621 --> 00:05:27.747
who said that she was offered a really big 
promotion at work, and she turned it down,

00:05:27.747 --> 00:05:30.100
and she told her best friend she turned 
it down, and her best friend said,

00:05:30.100 --> 00:05:31.933
you really need to watch this TED Talk.

00:05:31.933 --> 00:05:36.349
And so she watched this TED Talk, and she 
went back the next day, she took the job,

00:05:36.349 --> 00:05:41.197
she went home, and she handed her 
husband the grocery list. (Laughter)

00:05:41.197 --> 00:05:42.789
And she said, I can do this.

00:05:42.789 --> 00:05:45.942
And what really mattered to me -- it wasn't 
only women in the corporate world,

00:05:45.942 --> 00:05:48.912
even though I did hear from a lot of 
them, and it did impact a lot of them,

00:05:48.912 --> 00:05:52.742
it was also people of all different circumstances.

00:05:52.742 --> 00:05:56.489
There was a doctor I met who was an 
attending physician at Johns Hopkins,

00:05:56.489 --> 00:06:00.082
and he said that until he saw my TED 
Talk, it never really occurred to him

00:06:00.082 --> 00:06:02.456
that even though half the students in 
his med school classes were women,

00:06:02.456 --> 00:06:05.367
they weren't speaking as much as 
the men as he did his rounds.

00:06:05.367 --> 00:06:11.593
So he started paying attention, and as he waited for 
raised hands, he realized the men's hands were up.

00:06:11.593 --> 00:06:13.878
So he started encouraging the 
women to raise their hands more,

00:06:13.878 --> 00:06:15.155
and it still didn't work.

00:06:15.155 --> 00:06:18.709
So he told everyone, no more 
hand raising, I'm cold-calling.

00:06:18.709 --> 00:06:22.913
So he could call evenly on men and women. 
And what he proved to himself was that

00:06:22.913 --> 00:06:25.546
the women knew the answers just as well or better,

00:06:25.546 --> 00:06:27.434
and he was able to go back 
to them and tell them that.

00:06:27.434 --> 00:06:32.553
And then there was the woman, stay-at-home 
mom, lives in a really difficult neighborhood,

00:06:32.553 --> 00:06:36.589
with not a great school, she said that TED 
Talk -- she's never had a corporate job,

00:06:36.589 --> 00:06:42.364
but that TED Talk inspired her to go to her school 
and fight for a better teacher for her child.

00:06:42.364 --> 00:06:46.656
And I guess it was part of was finding my own voice.

00:06:46.656 --> 00:06:50.710
And I realized that other women and 
men could find their voice through it,

00:06:50.710 --> 00:06:53.432
which is why I went from the talk to the book.

00:06:53.432 --> 00:06:59.757
PM: And in the book, you not only found your 
voice, which is clear and strong in the book,

00:06:59.757 --> 00:07:03.321
but you also share what you've learned --

00:07:03.321 --> 00:07:06.464
the experiences of other people in the lessons.

00:07:06.464 --> 00:07:10.646
And that's what I'm thinking about 
in terms of putting yourself in a --

00:07:10.646 --> 00:07:15.600
you became a sort of expert in how you lean in.

00:07:15.600 --> 00:07:19.992
So what did that feel like, and 
become like in your life?


00:07:19.992 --> 00:07:26.204
To launch not just a book, not just 
a best-selling, best-viewed talk,

00:07:26.204 --> 00:07:32.048
but a movement, where people began to 
literally describe their actions at work as,

00:07:32.048 --> 00:07:34.730
I'm leaning in.

00:07:34.730 --> 00:07:41.944
SS: I mean, I'm grateful, I'm honored, 
I'm happy, and it's the very beginning.

00:07:41.944 --> 00:07:46.458
So I don't know if I'm an expert, or if anyone is 
an expert. I certainly have done a lot of research.

00:07:46.458 --> 00:07:49.671
I have read every study, I have 
pored over the materials,

00:07:49.671 --> 00:07:53.299
and the lessons are very clear. 
Because here's what we know:

00:07:53.299 --> 00:07:58.011
What we know is that stereotypes are holding women 
back from leadership roles all over the world.

00:07:58.011 --> 00:08:00.614
It's so striking. "Lean In" is very global, 
I've been all over the world,

00:08:00.614 --> 00:08:03.009
talking about it, and -- cultures are so different.

00:08:03.009 --> 00:08:08.002
Even within our own country, to Japan, 
to Korea, to China, to Asia, Europe,

00:08:08.002 --> 00:08:12.189
they're so different. Except for one thing: gender.

00:08:12.189 --> 00:08:14.109
All over the world, no matter what our cultures are,

00:08:14.109 --> 00:08:18.439
we think men should be strong, 
assertive, aggressive, have voice;

00:08:18.439 --> 00:08:22.956
we think women should speak 
when spoken to, help others.

00:08:22.956 --> 00:08:26.661
Now we have, all over the world,

00:08:26.661 --> 00:08:30.454
women are called "bossy." 
There is a word for "bossy,"

00:08:30.454 --> 00:08:32.772
for little girls, in every language there's one.

00:08:32.772 --> 00:08:34.982
It's a word that's pretty much not used for little boys,

00:08:34.982 --> 00:08:37.910
because if a little boy leads, 
there's no negative word for it,

00:08:37.910 --> 00:08:42.699
it's expected. But if a little girl leads, she's bossy.

00:08:42.699 --> 00:08:44.694
Now I know there aren't a lot of 
men here, but bear with me.

00:08:44.694 --> 00:08:47.228
If you're a man, you'll have 
to represent your gender.

00:08:47.228 --> 00:08:52.792
Please raise your hand if you've been 
told you're too aggressive at work.

00:08:52.792 --> 00:08:58.676
(Laughter) There's always a few, it runs about 
five percent. Okay, get ready, gentlemen.

00:08:58.676 --> 00:09:05.239
If you're a woman, please raise your hand if you've 
ever been told you're too aggressive at work.

00:09:05.239 --> 00:09:08.852
(Laughter) That is what audiences have 
said in every country in the world,

00:09:08.852 --> 00:09:11.718
and it's deeply supported by the data.

00:09:11.718 --> 00:09:16.057
Now, do we think women are more 
aggressive than men? Of course not.

00:09:16.057 --> 00:09:18.407
It's just that we judge them through a different lens,

00:09:18.407 --> 00:09:23.258
and a lot of the character traits that you must 
exhibit to perform at work, to get results, to lead,

00:09:23.258 --> 00:09:26.122
are ones that we think, in a man, he's a boss,

00:09:26.122 --> 00:09:27.744
and in a woman, she's bossy.

00:09:27.744 --> 00:09:31.830
And the good news about this is that we 
can change this by acknowledging it.

00:09:31.830 --> 00:09:34.220
One of the happiest moments 
I had in this whole journey is,

00:09:34.220 --> 00:09:39.153
after the book came out, I stood on a stage 
with John Chambers, the CEO of Cisco.

00:09:39.153 --> 00:09:42.812
He read the book. He stood on a stage with me, he 
invited me in front of his whole management team,

00:09:42.812 --> 00:09:46.204
men and women, and he said, I thought we 
were good at this. I thought I was good at this.

00:09:46.204 --> 00:09:51.270
And then I read this book, and I 
realized that we -- my company --

00:09:51.270 --> 00:09:53.254
we have called all of our 
senior women too aggressive,

00:09:53.254 --> 00:09:55.703
and I'm standing on this stage, and I'm sorry.

00:09:55.703 --> 00:09:59.448
And I want you to know we're 
never going to do it again.

00:09:59.448 --> 00:10:02.832
PM: Can we send that to a lot of other 
people that we know? (Applause)

00:10:02.832 --> 00:10:06.733
SS: And so John is doing that because 
he believes it's good for his company,

00:10:06.733 --> 00:10:09.771
and so this kind of acknowledgement 
of these biases can change it.

00:10:09.787 --> 00:10:13.435
And so next time you all see 
someone call a little girl "bossy,"

00:10:13.435 --> 00:10:15.983
you walk right up to that person, 
big smile, and you say,

00:10:15.983 --> 00:10:22.518
"That little girl's not bossy. That little girl has 
executive leadership skills." (Laughter)

00:10:22.518 --> 00:10:25.723
PM: I know that's what you're telling your daughter. 
SS: Absolutely.

00:10:25.723 --> 00:10:28.792
PM: And you did focus in the book -- and 
the reason, as you said, in writing it,

00:10:28.792 --> 00:10:30.717
was to create a dialogue about this.

00:10:30.717 --> 00:10:34.231
I mean, let's just put it out there, 
face the fact that women are --

00:10:34.231 --> 00:10:37.906
in a time when we have more open 
doors, and more opportunities --

00:10:37.906 --> 00:10:41.206
are still not getting to the leadership positions.

00:10:41.206 --> 00:10:43.404
So in the months that have come since the book,

00:10:43.404 --> 00:10:45.962
in which "Lean In" focused on that and said,

00:10:45.962 --> 00:10:50.262
here are some of the challenges that remain, and 
many of them we have to own within ourselves

00:10:50.262 --> 00:10:53.024
and look at ourselves. What has changed?

00:10:53.024 --> 00:10:55.110
Have you seen changes?

00:10:55.110 --> 00:10:57.373
SS: Well, there's certainly more 
dialogue, which is great.

00:10:57.373 --> 00:11:00.421
But what really matters to me, 
and I think all of us, is action.

00:11:00.421 --> 00:11:04.205
So everywhere I go, CEOs, 
they're mostly men, say to me,

00:11:04.205 --> 00:11:06.824
you're costing me so much money

00:11:06.824 --> 00:11:09.996
because all the women want to 
be paid as much as the men.

00:11:09.996 --> 00:11:14.277
And to them I say, I'm not sorry at all. (Laughter)

00:11:14.277 --> 00:11:17.515
At all. I mean, the women should 
be paid as much as the men.

00:11:17.515 --> 00:11:20.652
Everywhere I go, women tell me they ask for raises.

00:11:20.652 --> 00:11:24.649
Everywhere I go, women say they're getting 
better relationships with their spouses,

00:11:24.649 --> 00:11:28.629
asking for more help at home, asking for the 
promotions they should be getting at work,

00:11:28.629 --> 00:11:31.627
and importantly, believing it 
themselves. Even little things.

00:11:31.627 --> 00:11:35.659
One of the governors of one of the states told me 
that he didn't realize that more women were, in fact,

00:11:35.659 --> 00:11:37.888
literally sitting on the side 
of the room, which they are,

00:11:37.888 --> 00:11:43.375
and now he made a rule that all the women 
on his staff need to sit at the table.

00:11:43.375 --> 00:11:45.531
The foundation I started along 
with the book "Lean In"

00:11:45.531 --> 00:11:48.883
helps women, or men, start circles -- small groups,

00:11:48.883 --> 00:11:52.132
it can be 10, it can be however many 
you want, which meet once a month.

00:11:52.132 --> 00:11:55.453
I would have hoped that by now, we'd have 
about 500 circles. That would've been great.

00:11:55.453 --> 00:11:58.375
You know, 500 times roughly 10.

00:11:58.375 --> 00:12:01.605
There are over 12,000 circles 
in 50 countries in the world.

00:12:01.605 --> 00:12:03.165
PM: Wow, that's amazing.

00:12:03.165 --> 00:12:06.240
SS: And these are people who 
are meeting every single month.

00:12:06.240 --> 00:12:08.579
I met one of them, I was in Beijing.

00:12:08.579 --> 00:12:13.279
A group of women, they're all about 29 or 30, 
they started the first Lean In circle in Beijing,

00:12:13.279 --> 00:12:17.272
several of them grew up in very poor, rural China.

00:12:17.272 --> 00:12:23.080
These women are 29, they are told by 
their society that they are "left over,"

00:12:23.080 --> 00:12:25.093
because they are not yet married,

00:12:25.093 --> 00:12:27.876
and the process of coming together 
once a month at a meeting

00:12:27.876 --> 00:12:31.176
is helping them define who they are for themselves.

00:12:31.176 --> 00:12:35.512
What they want in their careers. The 
kind of partners they want, if at all.

00:12:35.512 --> 00:12:37.499
I looked at them, we went around 
and introduced ourselves,

00:12:37.499 --> 00:12:39.338
and they all said their names 
and where they're from,

00:12:39.338 --> 00:12:42.818
and I said, I'm Sheryl Sandberg, 
and this was my dream.

00:12:42.818 --> 00:12:44.658
And I kind of just started crying.

00:12:44.658 --> 00:12:49.415
Right, which, I admit, I do. Right? 
I've talked about it before.

00:12:49.415 --> 00:12:53.985
But the fact that a woman so far away out in 
the world, who grew up in a rural village,

00:12:53.985 --> 00:12:58.096
who's being told to marry someone 
she doesn't want to marry,

00:12:58.096 --> 00:13:01.033
can now go meet once a month with 
a group of people and refuse that,

00:13:01.033 --> 00:13:04.027
and find life on her own terms.

00:13:04.027 --> 00:13:05.970
That's the kind of change we have to hope for.

00:13:05.970 --> 00:13:09.517
PM: Have you been surprised by 
the global nature of the message?


00:13:09.517 --> 00:13:12.822
Because I think when the book first 
came out, many people thought,

00:13:12.822 --> 00:13:16.574
well, this is a really important handbook 
for young women on their way up.

00:13:16.574 --> 00:13:20.888
They need to look at this, anticipate 
the barriers, and recognize them,

00:13:20.888 --> 00:13:23.538
put them out in the open, have the dialogue about it,

00:13:23.538 --> 00:13:28.657
but that it's really for women who are that. 
Doing that. Pursuing the corporate world.

00:13:28.657 --> 00:13:33.035
And yet the book is being read, as you 
say, in rural and developing countries.

00:13:33.040 --> 00:13:40.317
What part of that has surprised you, and 
perhaps led to a new perspective on your part?

00:13:40.317 --> 00:13:43.473
SS: The book is about self-confidence, 
and about equality.

00:13:43.473 --> 00:13:47.373
And it turns out, everywhere in the world, 
women need more self-confidence,

00:13:47.373 --> 00:13:49.594
because the world tells us we're not equal to men.

00:13:49.594 --> 00:13:53.007
Everywhere in the world, we live in 
a world where the men get "and,"

00:13:53.007 --> 00:13:54.318
and women get "or."

00:13:54.318 --> 00:13:57.992
I've never met a man who's been 
asked how he does it all. (Laughter)

00:13:57.992 --> 00:14:01.205
Again, I'm going to turn to the men in the audience:

00:14:01.205 --> 00:14:04.237
Please raise your hand if you've 
been asked, how do you do it all?

00:14:04.237 --> 00:14:05.686
(Laughter)

00:14:05.686 --> 00:14:07.117
Men only.

00:14:07.117 --> 00:14:11.995
Women, women. Please raise your hand 
if you've been asked how you do it all?

00:14:11.995 --> 00:14:18.354
We assume men can do it all, 
slash -- have jobs and children.

00:14:18.354 --> 00:14:20.132
We assume women can't, and that's ridiculous,

00:14:20.132 --> 00:14:23.708
because the great majority of women everywhere 
in the world, including the United States,

00:14:23.708 --> 00:14:26.004
work full time and have children.

00:14:26.004 --> 00:14:31.176
And I think people don't fully understand 
how broad the message is.

00:14:31.176 --> 00:14:35.538
There is a circle that's been started 
for rescued sex workers in Miami.

00:14:35.538 --> 00:14:40.889
They're using "Lean In" to help 
people make the transition

00:14:40.889 --> 00:14:45.630
back to what would be a fair life, really rescuing 
them from their pimps, and using it.

00:14:45.630 --> 00:14:49.379
There are dress-for-success groups 
in Texas which are using the book,

00:14:49.379 --> 00:14:51.038
for women who have never been to college.

00:14:51.038 --> 00:14:54.966
And we know there are groups 
all the way to Ethiopia.

00:14:54.966 --> 00:15:00.849
And so these messages of equality -- of how women 
are told they can't have what men can have --

00:15:00.849 --> 00:15:05.082
how we assume that leadership is for men, 
how we assume that voice is for men,

00:15:05.082 --> 00:15:08.220
these affect all of us, and I 
think they are very universal.

00:15:08.220 --> 00:15:09.881
And it's part of what TEDWomen does.

00:15:09.881 --> 00:15:13.664
It unites all of us in a cause we have to believe in,

00:15:13.664 --> 00:15:17.912
which is more women, more voice, more equality.

00:15:17.912 --> 00:15:24.693
PM: If you were invited now to 
make another TEDWomen talk,

00:15:24.693 --> 00:15:29.987
what would you say that is a result 
of this experience, for you personally,

00:15:29.987 --> 00:15:32.606
and what you've learned about women, and men,

00:15:32.606 --> 00:15:36.292
as you've made this journey?

00:15:36.292 --> 00:15:39.390
SS: I think I would say -- I tried to say this strongly,

00:15:39.390 --> 00:15:41.844
but I think I can say it more strongly --

00:15:41.844 --> 00:15:45.248
I want to say that the status quo is not enough.

00:15:45.248 --> 00:15:48.228
That it's not good enough, that it's 
not changing quickly enough.

00:15:48.228 --> 00:15:53.355
Since I gave my TED Talk and published my book, 
another year of data came out from the U.S. Census.

00:15:53.355 --> 00:15:55.144
And you know what we found?

00:15:55.144 --> 00:15:57.921
No movement in the wage gap 
for women in the United States.

00:15:57.921 --> 00:16:00.467
Seventy-seven cents to the dollar.

00:16:00.467 --> 00:16:02.501
If you are a black woman, 64 cents.

00:16:02.501 --> 00:16:05.009
If you are a Latina, we're at 54 cents.

00:16:05.009 --> 00:16:07.437
Do you know when the last 
time those numbers went up?

00:16:07.437 --> 00:16:11.744
2002.

00:16:11.744 --> 00:16:14.628
We are stagnating, we are 
stagnating in so many ways.

00:16:14.628 --> 00:16:17.436
And I think we are not really being honest about that,

00:16:17.436 --> 00:16:20.682
for so many reasons. It's so 
hard to talk about gender.

00:16:20.682 --> 00:16:24.499
We shy away from the word "feminist," 
a word I really think we need to embrace.

00:16:24.499 --> 00:16:27.691
We have to get rid of the 
word bossy and bring back --

00:16:27.691 --> 00:16:30.851
(Applause)

00:16:30.851 --> 00:16:35.173
I think I would say in a louder voice, 
we need to get rid of the word "bossy"

00:16:35.173 --> 00:16:38.234
and bring back the word "feminist," 
because we need it.

00:16:38.234 --> 00:16:39.719
(Applause)

00:16:39.719 --> 00:16:42.761
PM: And we all need to do a lot more leaning in.

00:16:42.761 --> 00:16:43.962
SS: A lot more leaning in.

00:16:43.962 --> 00:16:45.192
PM: Thank you, Sheryl.

00:16:45.192 --> 00:16:46.426
Thanks for leaning in and saying yes.

00:16:46.426 --> 00:16:48.588
SS: Thank you.

00:16:48.588 --> 00:16:50.857
(Applause)

title: How I learned to stop worrying and love "useless" art
transcript: Two years ago, I have to say there was no problem. Two years ago, I knew exactly  what an icon looked like. It looks like this. Everybody's icon, but also the default position of a curator of Italian Renaissance  paintings, which I was then. And in a way, this is also another default selection. Leonardo da Vinci's exquisitely soulful image of the "Lady with an Ermine." And I use that word, soulful, deliberately. Or then there's this, or rather these: the two versions of Leonardo's "Virgin of the Rocks" that were about to come together  in London for the very first time. In the exhibition that I was then in  the absolute throes of organizing. I was literally up to my eyes in Leonardo, and I had been for three years. So, he was occupying every part of my brain. Leonardo had taught me, during that three years, about what a picture can do. About taking you from your own  material world into a spiritual world. He said, actually, that he believed  the job of the painter was to paint everything that was visible  and invisible in the universe. That's a huge task. And yet,  somehow he achieves it. He shows us, I think, the human soul. He shows us the capacity of ourselves to move into a spiritual realm. To see a vision of the universe that's  more perfect than our own. To see God's own plan, in some sense. So this, in a sense, was really  what I believed an icon was.At about that time, I started talking to Tom Campbell,director here of the Metropolitan Museum, about what my next move might be. The move, in fact, back to an earlier life, one I'd begun at the British Museum, back to the world of three dimensions — of sculpture and of decorative arts — to take over the department of European sculpture  and decorative arts, here at the Met. But it was an incredibly busy time. All the conversations were done  at very peculiar times of the day — over the phone. In the end, I accepted the job without actually having been here. Again, I'd been there a couple of years before, but on that particular visit. So, it was just before the time that  the Leonardo show was due to open when I finally made it back to the Met, to New York, to see my new domain. To see what European sculpture  and decorative arts looked like, beyond those Renaissance collections  with which I was so already familiar. And I thought, on that very first day,  I better tour the galleries. Fifty-seven of these galleries — like 57 varieties of baked beans, I believe. I walked through and I started in my comfort zone in the Italian Renaissance. And then I moved gradually around, feeling a little lost sometimes. My head, also still full of the Leonardo exhibition that was about to open, and I came across this. And I thought to myself: What the hell have I done? There was absolutely no connection in my mind at all and, in fact, if there was any emotion going on, it was a kind of repulsion. This object felt utterly and completely alien. Silly at a level that I hadn't yet  understood silliness to be. And then it was made worse — there were two of them. (Laughter) So, I started thinking about why it was, in fact, that I disliked this object so much. What was the anatomy of my distaste? Well, so much gold, so vulgar. You know, so nouveau riche, frankly. Leonardo himself had preached  against the use of gold, so it was absolutely anathema at that moment. And then there's little pretty sprigs  of flowers everywhere. (Laughter) And finally, that pink. That damned pink. It's such an extraordinarily artificial color. I mean, it's a color that I can't think of  anything that you actually see in nature, that looks that shade. The object even has its own tutu. (Laughter) This little flouncy, spangly, bottomy bit that sits at the bottom of the vase. It reminded me, in an odd kind of way, of my niece's fifth birthday party. Where all the little girls would come  either as a princess or a fairy. There was one who would come as a fairy princess. You should have seen the looks. (Laughter) And I realize that this object was in my mind, born from the same mind, from the same womb, practically, as Barbie Ballerina. (Laughter) And then there's the elephants. (Laughter) Those extraordinary elephants with their little, sort of strange, sinister expressions and Greta Garbo eyelashes, with  these golden tusks and so on. I realized this was an elephant that had absolutely nothing to do with a majestic  march across the Serengeti. It was a Dumbo nightmare. (Laughter)But something more profound  was happening as well. These objects, it seemed to me, were quintessentially the kind that I  and my liberal left friends in London had always seen as summing up something deplorable about the French aristocracy in the 18th century. The label had told me that these pieces were made by the Sèvres Manufactory, made of porcelain in the late 1750s, and designed by a designer called  Jean-Claude Duplessis, actually somebody of extraordinary distinction as I later learned. But for me, they summed up a kind of, that sort of sheer uselessness of the aristocracy in the 18th century. I and my colleagues had always thought that these objects, in way, summed up the idea of, you know — no wonder there was a revolution. Or, indeed, thank God there was a revolution. There was a sort of idea really, that, if you owned a vase like this, then there was really only one fate possible. (Laughter)So, there I was — in a sort of paroxysm of horror. But I took the job and I went  on looking at these vases. I sort of had to because they're  on a through route in the Met. So, almost anywhere I went, there they were. They had this kind of odd sort of fascination, like a car accident. Where I couldn't stop looking. And as I did so, I started thinking: Well, what are we actually looking at here? And what I started with was understanding this as really a supreme piece of design. It took me a little time. But, that tutu for example — actually, this is a piece that  does dance in its own way. It has an extraordinary lightness and yet, it is also amazing balanced. It has these kinds of sculptural ingredients. And then the play between — actually really quite carefully disposed  color and gilding, and the sculptural surface, is really rather remarkable. And then I realized that this piece went into the kiln four times, at least four times  in order to arrive at this. How many moments for accident can you think of that could have happened to this piece? And then remember, not just one, but two. So he's having to arrive at two exactly matched vases of this kind. And then this question of uselessness. Well actually, the end of the trunks  were originally candle holders. So what you would have had  were candles on either side. Imagine that effect of candlelight on that surface. On the slightly uneven pink, on the beautiful gold. It would have glittered in an interior, a little like a little firework.And at that point, actually,  a firework went off in my brain. Somebody reminded me that, that word 'fancy' — which in a sense for me, encapsulated this object — actually comes from the same  root as the word 'fantasy.' And that what this object was just as much in a way, in its own way, as a Leonardo da Vinci painting, is a portal to somewhere else. This is an object of the imagination. If you think about the mad 18th-century  operas of the time — set in the Orient. If you think about divans and perhaps even  opium-induced visions of pink elephants, then at that point, this object starts to make sense. This is an object which is all about escapism. It's about an escapism that happens — that the aristocracy in France sought very deliberately to distinguish themselves from ordinary people.It's not an escapism that we feel particularly happy with today, however. And again, going on thinking about this, I realize that in a way we're all victims of a certain kind of tyranny of the triumph of modernism whereby form and function in an object have to follow one another, or are deemed to do so. And the extraneous ornament is seen as really, essentially, criminal. It's a triumph, in a way, of bourgeois values rather than aristocratic ones. And that seems fine. Except for the fact that it becomes a kind of  sequestration of imagination. So just as in the 20th century, so many people had the idea that their faith took place on the Sabbath day, and the rest of their lives — their lives of washing machines and orthodontics — took place on another day. Then, I think we've started doing the same. We've allowed ourselves to lead our fantasy lives in front of screens. In the dark of the cinema, with the television in the corner of the room. We've eliminated, in a sense, that constant of the imagination that these vases  represented in people's lives. So maybe it's time we got this back a little. I think it's beginning to happen. In London, for example, with these extraordinary buildings that have been appearing over the last few years. Redolent, in a sense, of science fiction, turning London into a kind of fantasy playground. It's actually amazing to look out of  a high building nowadays there. But even then, there's a resistance. London has called these buildings the  Gherkin, the Shard, the Walkie Talkie — bringing these soaring buildings down to Earth. There's an idea that we don't want these anxious-making, imaginative journeys  to happen in our daily lives. I feel lucky in a way, I've encountered this object. (Laughter) I found him on the Internet when  I was looking up a reference. And there he was. And unlike the pink elephant vase, this was a kind of love at first sight. In fact, reader, I married him. I bought him. And he now adorns my office. He's a Staffordshire figure made  in the middle of the 19th century. He represents the actor, Edmund Kean,  playing Shakespeare's Richard III. And it's based, actually, on a more  elevated piece of porcelain. So I loved, on an art historical level, I loved that layered quality that he has. But more than that, I love him. In a way that I think would have been impossible without the pink Sèvres vase in my Leonardo days. I love his orange and pink breeches. I love the fact that he seems to be going off to war, having just finished the washing up. (Laughter) He seems also to have forgotten his sword. I love his pink little cheeks, his munchkin energy. In a way, he's become my sort of alter ego. He's, I hope, a little bit dignified, but mostly rather vulgar. (Laughter) And energetic, I hope, too. I let him into my life because the Sèvres pink elephant vase allowed me to do so. And before that Leonardo, I understood that this object could become  part of a journey for me every day, sitting in my office. I really hope that others, all of you, visiting objects in the museum, and taking them home and  finding them for yourselves, will allow those objects to flourish  in your imaginative lives. Thank you very much. (Applause)

00:07:57.912 --> 00:08:02.871
Well actually, the end of the trunks 
were originally candle holders.

00:08:02.871 --> 00:08:06.621
So what you would have had 
were candles on either side.

00:08:06.621 --> 00:08:09.177
Imagine that effect of candlelight on that surface.

00:08:09.177 --> 00:08:11.909
On the slightly uneven pink, on the beautiful gold.

00:08:11.909 --> 00:08:14.655
It would have glittered in an interior,

00:08:14.655 --> 00:08:17.737
a little like a little firework.

00:08:17.737 --> 00:08:21.389
And at that point, actually, 
a firework went off in my brain.

00:08:21.389 --> 00:08:24.224
Somebody reminded me that, that word 'fancy' --

00:08:24.224 --> 00:08:27.334
which in a sense for me, encapsulated this object --

00:08:27.334 --> 00:08:31.380
actually comes from the same 
root as the word 'fantasy.'

00:08:31.380 --> 00:08:33.996
And that what this object was just as much in a way,

00:08:33.996 --> 00:08:36.448
in its own way, as a Leonardo da Vinci painting,

00:08:36.448 --> 00:08:38.655
is a portal to somewhere else.

00:08:38.655 --> 00:08:42.850
This is an object of the imagination.

00:08:42.850 --> 00:08:49.659
If you think about the mad 18th-century 
operas of the time -- set in the Orient.

00:08:49.679 --> 00:08:56.158
If you think about divans and perhaps even 
opium-induced visions of pink elephants,

00:08:56.158 --> 00:08:59.459
then at that point, this object starts to make sense.

00:08:59.459 --> 00:09:03.515
This is an object which is all about escapism.

00:09:03.515 --> 00:09:06.712
It's about an escapism that happens --

00:09:06.712 --> 00:09:08.733
that the aristocracy in France sought

00:09:08.733 --> 00:09:10.519
very deliberately

00:09:10.519 --> 00:09:15.087
to distinguish themselves from ordinary people.

00:09:15.087 --> 00:09:17.051
It's not an escapism that

00:09:17.051 --> 00:09:20.918
we feel particularly happy with today, however.

00:09:20.918 --> 00:09:23.903
And again, going on thinking about this,

00:09:23.903 --> 00:09:27.077
I realize that in a way we're all victims

00:09:27.077 --> 00:09:29.088
of a certain kind of tyranny

00:09:29.088 --> 00:09:31.109
of the triumph of modernism

00:09:31.109 --> 00:09:33.835
whereby form and function in an object

00:09:33.835 --> 00:09:37.240
have to follow one another, or are deemed to do so.

00:09:37.240 --> 00:09:40.204
And the extraneous ornament is seen as really,

00:09:40.204 --> 00:09:43.224
essentially, criminal.

00:09:43.224 --> 00:09:46.375
It's a triumph, in a way, of bourgeois
values rather than aristocratic ones.

00:09:46.375 --> 00:09:48.198
And that seems fine.

00:09:48.198 --> 00:09:55.655
Except for the fact that it becomes a kind of 
sequestration of imagination.

00:09:55.655 --> 00:09:58.345
So just as in the 20th century, so many people

00:09:58.345 --> 00:10:00.333
had the idea that their faith

00:10:00.333 --> 00:10:03.015
took place on the Sabbath day,

00:10:03.015 --> 00:10:04.389
and the rest of their lives --

00:10:04.389 --> 00:10:08.367
their lives of washing machines and orthodontics --

00:10:08.367 --> 00:10:10.399
took place on another day.

00:10:10.399 --> 00:10:14.167
Then, I think we've started doing the same.

00:10:14.167 --> 00:10:17.499
We've allowed ourselves to

00:10:17.499 --> 00:10:19.856
lead our fantasy lives in front of screens.

00:10:19.856 --> 00:10:23.838
In the dark of the cinema, with the
television in the corner of the room.

00:10:23.838 --> 00:10:27.916
We've eliminated, in a sense, that constant

00:10:27.916 --> 00:10:32.844
of the imagination that these vases 
represented in people's lives.

00:10:32.844 --> 00:10:36.880
So maybe it's time we got this back a little.

00:10:36.880 --> 00:10:39.230
I think it's beginning to happen.

00:10:39.230 --> 00:10:40.496
In London, for example,

00:10:40.496 --> 00:10:42.645
with these extraordinary buildings

00:10:42.645 --> 00:10:45.636
that have been appearing over the last few years.

00:10:45.636 --> 00:10:48.039
Redolent, in a sense, of science fiction,

00:10:48.039 --> 00:10:50.153
turning London into a kind of fantasy playground.

00:10:50.153 --> 00:10:55.007
It's actually amazing to look out of 
a high building nowadays there.

00:10:55.007 --> 00:10:56.811
But even then, there's a resistance.

00:10:56.811 --> 00:11:01.147
London has called these buildings the 
Gherkin, the Shard, the Walkie Talkie --

00:11:01.147 --> 00:11:04.452
bringing these soaring buildings down to Earth.

00:11:04.452 --> 00:11:08.532
There's an idea that we don't want these

00:11:08.532 --> 00:11:13.393
anxious-making, imaginative journeys 
to happen in our daily lives.

00:11:13.393 --> 00:11:16.661
I feel lucky in a way,

00:11:16.661 --> 00:11:19.209
I've encountered this object.

00:11:19.209 --> 00:11:21.650
(Laughter)

00:11:21.650 --> 00:11:24.952
I found him on the Internet when 
I was looking up a reference.

00:11:24.952 --> 00:11:27.846
And there he was.

00:11:27.846 --> 00:11:31.160
And unlike the pink elephant vase,

00:11:31.160 --> 00:11:33.133
this was a kind of love at first sight.

00:11:33.133 --> 00:11:35.989
In fact, reader, I married him. I bought him.

00:11:35.989 --> 00:11:39.853
And he now adorns my office.

00:11:39.853 --> 00:11:43.394
He's a Staffordshire figure made 
in the middle of the 19th century.

00:11:43.394 --> 00:11:48.200
He represents the actor, Edmund Kean, 
playing Shakespeare's Richard III.

00:11:48.200 --> 00:11:50.653
And it's based, actually, on a more 
elevated piece of porcelain.

00:11:50.653 --> 00:11:52.807
So I loved, on an art historical level,

00:11:52.807 --> 00:11:57.467
I loved that layered quality that he has.

00:11:57.467 --> 00:11:59.960
But more than that, I love him.

00:11:59.960 --> 00:12:01.638
In a way that I think would have been impossible

00:12:01.638 --> 00:12:04.250
without the pink Sèvres vase in my Leonardo days.

00:12:04.250 --> 00:12:07.467
I love his orange and pink breeches.

00:12:07.467 --> 00:12:10.217
I love the fact that he seems to be going off to war,

00:12:10.217 --> 00:12:14.649
having just finished the washing up. (Laughter)

00:12:14.649 --> 00:12:17.126
He seems also to have forgotten his sword.

00:12:17.126 --> 00:12:19.745
I love his pink little cheeks, his munchkin energy.

00:12:19.745 --> 00:12:22.936
In a way, he's become my sort of alter ego.

00:12:22.936 --> 00:12:25.237
He's, I hope, a little bit dignified,

00:12:25.237 --> 00:12:30.411
but mostly rather vulgar. (Laughter)

00:12:30.411 --> 00:12:33.629
And energetic, I hope, too.

00:12:33.629 --> 00:12:38.784
I let him into my life because the Sèvres
pink elephant vase allowed me to do so.

00:12:38.784 --> 00:12:40.352
And before that Leonardo,

00:12:40.352 --> 00:12:45.458
I understood that this object could become 
part of a journey for me every day,

00:12:45.458 --> 00:12:48.203
sitting in my office.

00:12:48.203 --> 00:12:51.192
I really hope that others, all of you,

00:12:51.192 --> 00:12:52.767
visiting objects in the museum,

00:12:52.767 --> 00:12:55.221
and taking them home and 
finding them for yourselves,

00:12:55.221 --> 00:12:59.535
will allow those objects to flourish 
in your imaginative lives.

00:12:59.535 --> 00:13:01.088
Thank you very much.

00:13:01.088 --> 00:13:04.971
(Applause)

title: Robots with "soul"
transcript: My job is to design, build and study robots that communicate with people. But this story doesn't start with robotics at all, it starts with animation. When I first saw Pixar's "Luxo Jr.," I was amazed by how much emotion they could put into something as trivial as a desk lamp. I mean, look at them — at the end of this movie, you actually feel something for two pieces of furniture.(Laughter)And I said, I have to learn how to do this. So I made a really bad career decision.(Laughter)And that's what my mom was like when I did it.(Laughter)I left a very cozy tech job in Israel at a nice software company and I moved to New York to study animation. And there I lived in a collapsing apartment building in Harlem with roommates. I'm not using this phrase metaphorically — the ceiling actually collapsed one day in our living room. Whenever they did news stories about building violations in New York, they would put the report in front of our building, as kind of, like, a backdrop to show how bad things are.Anyway, during the day, I went to school and at night I would sit and draw frame by frame of pencil animation. And I learned two surprising lessons. One of them was that when you want to arouse emotions, it doesn't matter so much how something looks; it's all in the motion, in the timing of how the thing moves. And the second was something one of our teachers told us. He actually did the weasel in "Ice Age." And he said, "As an animator, you're not a director — you're an actor." So, if you want to find the right motion for a character, don't think about it — go use your body to find it. Stand in front of a mirror, act it out in front of a camera — whatever you need — and then put it back in your character.A year later I found myself at MIT in the Robotic Life Group. It was one of the first groups researching the relationships between humans and robots. And I still had this dream to make an actual, physical Luxo Jr. lamp. But I found that robots didn't move at all in this engaging way that I was used to from my animation studies. Instead, they were all — how should I put it — they were all kind of robotic. (Laughter) And I thought, what if I took whatever I learned in animation school, and used that to design my robotic desk lamp. So I went and designed frame by frame to try to make this robot as graceful and engaging as possible. And here when you see the robot interacting with me on a desktop — and I'm actually redesigning the robot, so, unbeknownst to itself, it's kind of digging its own grave by helping me.(Laughter)I wanted it to be less of a mechanical structure giving me light, and more of a helpful, kind of quiet apprentice that's always there when you need it and doesn't really interfere. And when, for example, I'm looking for a battery that I can't find, in a subtle way, it'll show me where the battery is. So you can see my confusion here. I'm not an actor. And I want you to notice how the same mechanical structure can, at one point, just by the way it moves, seem gentle and caring and in the other case, seem violent and confrontational. And it's the same structure, just the motion is different. Actor: "You want to know something? Well, you want to know something? He was already dead! Just laying there, eyes glazed over!"(Laughter)But, moving in a graceful way is just one building block of this whole structure called human-robot interaction. I was, at the time, doing my PhD, I was working on human-robot teamwork, teams of humans and robots working together. I was studying the engineering, the psychology, the philosophy of teamwork, and at the same time, I found myself in my own kind of teamwork situation, with a good friend of mine, who's actually here. And in that situation, we can easily imagine robots in the near future being there with us. It was after a Passover Seder. We were folding up a lot of folding chairs, and I was amazed at how quickly we found our own rhythm. Everybody did their own part, we didn't have to divide our tasks. We didn't have to communicate verbally about this — it all just happened.And I thought, humans and robots don't look at all like this. When humans and robots interact, it's much more like a chess game: the human does a thing, the robot analyzes whatever the human did, the robot decides what to do next, plans it and does it. Then the human waits, until it's their turn again. So it's much more like a chess game, and that makes sense, because chess is great for mathematicians and computer scientists. It's all about information, analysis, decision-making and planning.But I wanted my robot to be less of a chess player, and more like a doer that just clicks and works together. So I made my second horrible career choice: I decided to study acting for a semester. I took off from the PhD, I went to acting classes. I actually participated in a play — I hope there’s no video of that around still.(Laughter)And I got every book I could find about acting, including one from the 19th century that I got from the library. And I was really amazed, because my name was the second name on the list — the previous name was in 1889.(Laughter)And this book was kind of waiting for 100 years to be rediscovered for robotics. And this book shows actors how to move every muscle in the body to match every kind of emotion that they want to express.But the real revelation was when I learned about method acting. It became very popular in the 20th century. And method acting said you don't have to plan every muscle in your body; instead, you have to use your body to find the right movement. You have to use your sense memory to reconstruct the emotions and kind of think with your body to find the right expression — improvise, play off your scene partner. And this came at the same time as I was reading about this trend in cognitive psychology, called embodied cognition, which also talks about the same ideas. We use our bodies to think; we don't just think with our brains and use our bodies to move, but our bodies feed back into our brain to generate the way that we behave.And it was like a lightning bolt. I went back to my office, I wrote this paper, which I never really published, called "Acting Lessons for Artificial Intelligence." And I even took another month to do what was then the first theater play with a human and a robot acting together. That's what you saw before with the actors. And I thought: How can we make an artificial intelligence model — a computer, computational model — that will model some of these ideas of improvisation, of taking risks, of taking chances, even of making mistakes? Maybe it can make for better robotic teammates. So I worked for quite a long time on these models and I implemented them on a number of robots.Here you can see a very early example with the robots trying to use this embodied artificial intelligence to try to match my movements as closely as possible. It's sort of like a game. Let's look at it. You can see when I psych it out, it gets fooled. And it's a little bit like what you might see actors do when they try to mirror each other to find the right synchrony between them. And then, I did another experiment, and I got people off the street to use the robotic desk lamp, and try out this idea of embodied artificial intelligence. So, I actually used two kinds of brains for the same robot.The robot is the same lamp that you saw, and I put two brains in it. For one half of the people, I put in a brain that's kind of the traditional, calculated robotic brain. It waits for its turn, it analyzes everything, it plans. Let's call it the calculated brain. The other got more the stage actor, risk-taker brain. Let's call it the adventurous brain. It sometimes acts without knowing everything it has to know. It sometimes makes mistakes and corrects them. And I had them do this very tedious task that took almost 20 minutes, and they had to work together, somehow simulating, like, a factory job of repetitively doing the same thing. What I found is that people actually loved the adventurous robot. They thought it was more intelligent, more committed, a better member of the team, contributed to the success of the team more. They even called it "he" and "she," whereas people with the calculated brain called it "it," and nobody ever called it "he" or "she." When they talked about it after the task, with the adventurous brain, they said, "By the end, we were good friends and high-fived mentally." Whatever that means.(Laughter)Sounds painful. Whereas the people with the calculated brain said it was just like a lazy apprentice. It only did what it was supposed to do and nothing more, which is almost what people expect robots to do, so I was surprised that people had higher expectations of robots than what anybody in robotics thought robots should be doing. And in a way, I thought, maybe it's time — just like method acting changed the way people thought about acting in the 19th century, from going from the very calculated, planned way of behaving, to a more intuitive, risk-taking, embodied way of behaving — maybe it's time for robots to have the same kind of revolution.A few years later, I was at my next research job at Georgia Tech in Atlanta, and I was working in a group dealing with robotic musicians. And I thought, music: that's the perfect place to look at teamwork, coordination, timing, improvisation — and we just got this robot playing marimba. And the marimba, for everybody like me, it was this huge, wooden xylophone. And when I was looking at this, I looked at other works in human-robot improvisation — yes, there are other works in human-robot improvisation — and they were also a little bit like a chess game. The human would play, the robot analyzed what was played, and would improvise their own part. So, this is what musicians called a call-and-response interaction, and it also fits very well robots and artificial intelligence. But I thought, if I use the same ideas I used in the theater play and in the teamwork studies, maybe I can make the robots jam together like a band. Everybody's riffing off each other, nobody is stopping for a moment. And so I tried to do the same things, this time with music, where the robot doesn't really know what it's about to play, it just sort of moves its body and uses opportunities to play, and does what my jazz teacher when I was 17 taught me. She said, when you improvise, sometimes you don't know what you're doing, and you still do it. So I tried to make a robot that doesn't actually know what it's doing, but is still doing it. So let's look at a few seconds from this performance, where the robot listens to the human musician and improvises. And then, look how the human musician also responds to what the robot is doing and picking up from its behavior, and at some point can even be surprised by what the robot came up with.(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)Being a musician is not just about making notes, otherwise nobody would ever go see a live show. Musicians also communicate with their bodies, with other band members, with the audience, they use their bodies to express the music. And I thought, we already have a robot musician on stage, why not make it be a full-fledged musician? And I started designing a socially expressive head for the robot. The head doesn’t actually touch the marimba, it just expresses what the music is like. These are some napkin sketches from a bar in Atlanta that was dangerously located exactly halfway between my lab and my home. So I spent, I would say, on average, three to four hours a day there. I think.(Laughter)And I went back to my animation tools and tried to figure out not just what a robotic musician would look like, but especially what a robotic musician would move like, to sort of show that it doesn't like what the other person is playing — and maybe show whatever beat it's feeling at the moment.So we ended up actually getting the money to build this robot, which was nice. I'm going to show you now the same kind of performance, this time with a socially expressive head. And notice one thing — how the robot is really showing us the beat it's picking up from the human, while also giving the human a sense that the robot knows what it's doing. And also how it changes the way it moves as soon as it starts its own solo.(Music)Now it's looking at me, showing that it's listening.(Music)Now look at the final chord of the piece again. And this time the robot communicates with its body when it's busy doing its own thing, and when it's ready to coordinate the final chord with me.(Music)(Music ending)(Final chord)(Applause)Thanks. I hope you see how much this part of the body that doesn't touch the instrument actually helps with the musical performance. And at some point — we are in Atlanta, so obviously some rapper will come into our lab at some point — and we had this rapper come in and do a little jam with the robot. Here you can see the robot basically responding to the beat. Notice two things: one, how irresistible it is to join the robot while it's moving its head. You kind of want to move your own head when it does it. And second, even though the rapper is really focused on his iPhone, as soon as the robot turns to him, he turns back. So even though it's just in the periphery of his vision, in the corner of his eye, it's very powerful. And the reason is that we can't ignore physical things moving in our environment. We are wired for that. So if you have a problem — maybe your partner is looking at their iPhone or smartphone too much — you might want to have a robot there to get their attention.(Laughter)(Music)(Music ends)(Applause)Just to introduce the last robot that we've worked on, it came out of something surprising that we found: Some point people didn't care about the robot being intelligent, able to improvise and listen, and do all these embodied intelligence things that I spent years developing. They really liked that the robot was enjoying the music.(Laughter)And they didn't say the robot was moving to the music, they said "enjoying" the music. And we thought, why don't we take this idea, and I designed a new piece of furniture. This time it wasn't a desk lamp, it was a speaker dock, one of those things you plug your smartphone in. And I thought, what would happen if your speaker dock didn't just play the music for you, but would actually enjoy it, too? And so again, here are some animation tests from an early stage.(Laughter)And this is what the final product looked like.(Music)(Music ends)So, a lot of bobbing heads.(Applause)A lot of bobbing heads in the audience, so we can still see robots influence people. And it's not just fun and games.I think one of the reasons I care so much about robots that use their body to communicate and use their body to move is — I'm going to let you in on a little secret we roboticists are hiding — is that every one of you is going to be living with a robot at some point in your life. Somewhere in your future, there will be a robot in your life. If not in yours, your children's lives. And I want these robots to be more fluent, more engaging, more graceful than currently they seem to be. And for that I think maybe robots need to be less like chess players and more like stage actors and more like musicians. Maybe they should be able to take chances and improvise. Maybe they should be able to anticipate what you're about to do. Maybe they even need to be able to make mistakes and correct them, because in the end, we are human. And maybe as humans, robots that are a little less than perfect are just perfect for us.Thank you.(Applause)

00:02:17.556 --> 00:02:19.601
So I went and designed frame by frame

00:02:19.625 --> 00:02:23.585
to try to make this robot as graceful
and engaging as possible.

00:02:24.157 --> 00:02:27.866
And here when you see the robot
interacting with me on a desktop --

00:02:27.890 --> 00:02:29.926
and I'm actually redesigning the robot,

00:02:29.950 --> 00:02:31.754
so, unbeknownst to itself,

00:02:31.778 --> 00:02:34.353
it's kind of digging its own
grave by helping me.

00:02:34.377 --> 00:02:36.383
(Laughter)

00:02:36.407 --> 00:02:39.646
I wanted it to be less of a mechanical
structure giving me light,

00:02:39.670 --> 00:02:42.688
and more of a helpful,
kind of quiet apprentice

00:02:42.712 --> 00:02:45.881
that's always there when you need it
and doesn't really interfere.

00:02:45.905 --> 00:02:49.240
And when, for example, I'm looking
for a battery that I can't find,

00:02:49.264 --> 00:02:52.211
in a subtle way, it'll show me
where the battery is.

00:02:53.830 --> 00:02:55.663
So you can see my confusion here.

00:02:56.400 --> 00:02:57.612
I'm not an actor.

00:03:00.543 --> 00:03:03.576
And I want you to notice
how the same mechanical structure

00:03:03.600 --> 00:03:05.687
can, at one point,
just by the way it moves,

00:03:05.711 --> 00:03:07.855
seem gentle and caring
and in the other case,

00:03:07.879 --> 00:03:10.250
seem violent and confrontational.

00:03:10.274 --> 00:03:13.121
And it's the same structure,
just the motion is different.

00:03:19.377 --> 00:03:23.949
Actor: "You want to know something?
Well, you want to know something?

00:03:23.973 --> 00:03:25.862
He was already dead!

00:03:25.886 --> 00:03:29.788
Just laying there, eyes glazed over!"

00:03:29.812 --> 00:03:30.833
(Laughter)

00:03:30.857 --> 00:03:33.913
But, moving in a graceful way
is just one building block

00:03:33.937 --> 00:03:36.532
of this whole structure
called human-robot interaction.

00:03:36.556 --> 00:03:40.009
I was, at the time, doing my PhD,
I was working on human-robot teamwork,

00:03:40.033 --> 00:03:42.095
teams of humans and robots
working together.

00:03:42.119 --> 00:03:43.754
I was studying the engineering,

00:03:43.778 --> 00:03:46.310
the psychology,
the philosophy of teamwork,

00:03:46.334 --> 00:03:47.485
and at the same time,

00:03:47.509 --> 00:03:50.003
I found myself in my own kind
of teamwork situation,

00:03:50.027 --> 00:03:52.279
with a good friend of mine,
who's actually here.

00:03:52.303 --> 00:03:54.707
And in that situation,
we can easily imagine robots

00:03:54.731 --> 00:03:56.631
in the near future being there with us.

00:03:56.655 --> 00:03:58.345
It was after a Passover Seder.

00:03:58.369 --> 00:04:00.424
We were folding up
a lot of folding chairs,

00:04:00.448 --> 00:04:03.106
and I was amazed at how quickly
we found our own rhythm.

00:04:03.130 --> 00:04:06.240
Everybody did their own part,
we didn't have to divide our tasks.

00:04:06.264 --> 00:04:08.710
We didn't have to communicate
verbally about this --

00:04:08.734 --> 00:04:09.923
it all just happened.

00:04:09.947 --> 00:04:12.827
And I thought, humans and robots
don't look at all like this.

00:04:12.851 --> 00:04:15.982
When humans and robots interact,
it's much more like a chess game:

00:04:16.006 --> 00:04:19.127
the human does a thing, the robot
analyzes whatever the human did,

00:04:19.151 --> 00:04:21.794
the robot decides what to do next,
plans it and does it.

00:04:21.818 --> 00:04:24.173
Then the human waits,
until it's their turn again.

00:04:24.197 --> 00:04:26.928
So it's much more like a chess game,
and that makes sense,

00:04:26.952 --> 00:04:30.063
because chess is great for mathematicians
and computer scientists.

00:04:30.087 --> 00:04:33.515
It's all about information, analysis,
decision-making and planning.

00:04:33.539 --> 00:04:37.269
But I wanted my robot
to be less of a chess player,

00:04:37.293 --> 00:04:39.086
and more like a doer

00:04:39.110 --> 00:04:41.111
that just clicks and works together.

00:04:41.135 --> 00:04:44.504
So I made my second
horrible career choice:

00:04:44.528 --> 00:04:47.081
I decided to study acting for a semester.

00:04:47.105 --> 00:04:50.024
I took off from the PhD,
I went to acting classes.

00:04:50.048 --> 00:04:52.086
I actually participated in a play --

00:04:52.110 --> 00:04:54.412
I hope there’s no video
of that around still.

00:04:54.436 --> 00:04:55.474
(Laughter)

00:04:55.498 --> 00:04:57.792
And I got every book
I could find about acting,

00:04:57.816 --> 00:05:00.945
including one from the 19th century
that I got from the library.

00:05:00.969 --> 00:05:04.582
And I was really amazed, because my name
was the second name on the list --

00:05:04.606 --> 00:05:06.606
the previous name was in 1889.

00:05:06.630 --> 00:05:07.645
(Laughter)

00:05:07.669 --> 00:05:09.918
And this book was
kind of waiting for 100 years

00:05:09.942 --> 00:05:12.274
to be rediscovered for robotics.

00:05:12.298 --> 00:05:13.874
And this book shows actors

00:05:13.898 --> 00:05:16.136
how to move every muscle in the body

00:05:16.160 --> 00:05:18.876
to match every kind of emotion
that they want to express.

00:05:18.900 --> 00:05:21.926
But the real revelation was
when I learned about method acting.

00:05:21.950 --> 00:05:24.203
It became very popular
in the 20th century.

00:05:24.227 --> 00:05:25.378
And method acting said

00:05:25.402 --> 00:05:27.702
you don't have to plan
every muscle in your body;

00:05:27.726 --> 00:05:30.671
instead, you have to use your body
to find the right movement.

00:05:30.695 --> 00:05:33.575
You have to use your sense memory
to reconstruct the emotions

00:05:33.599 --> 00:05:36.637
and kind of think with your body
to find the right expression --

00:05:36.661 --> 00:05:38.536
improvise, play off your scene partner.

00:05:38.560 --> 00:05:40.005
And this came at the same time

00:05:40.029 --> 00:05:43.135
as I was reading about this trend
in cognitive psychology,

00:05:43.159 --> 00:05:46.411
called embodied cognition,
which also talks about the same ideas.

00:05:46.435 --> 00:05:47.950
We use our bodies to think;

00:05:47.974 --> 00:05:50.931
we don't just think with our brains
and use our bodies to move,

00:05:50.955 --> 00:05:52.873
but our bodies feed back into our brain

00:05:52.897 --> 00:05:55.062
to generate the way that we behave.

00:05:55.086 --> 00:05:56.682
And it was like a lightning bolt.

00:05:56.706 --> 00:05:57.920
I went back to my office,

00:05:57.944 --> 00:06:00.349
I wrote this paper,
which I never really published,

00:06:00.373 --> 00:06:02.905
called "Acting Lessons
for Artificial Intelligence."

00:06:02.929 --> 00:06:04.310
And I even took another month

00:06:04.334 --> 00:06:06.778
to do what was then the first theater play

00:06:06.802 --> 00:06:08.755
with a human and a robot acting together.

00:06:08.779 --> 00:06:11.172
That's what you saw
before with the actors.

00:06:12.522 --> 00:06:13.673
And I thought:

00:06:13.697 --> 00:06:16.634
How can we make an artificial
intelligence model --

00:06:16.658 --> 00:06:18.641
a computer, computational model --

00:06:18.665 --> 00:06:21.172
that will model some of these
ideas of improvisation,

00:06:21.196 --> 00:06:23.026
of taking risks, of taking chances,

00:06:23.050 --> 00:06:24.577
even of making mistakes?

00:06:24.601 --> 00:06:27.214
Maybe it can make for better
robotic teammates.

00:06:27.238 --> 00:06:29.842
So I worked for quite
a long time on these models

00:06:29.866 --> 00:06:32.261
and I implemented them
on a number of robots.

00:06:32.285 --> 00:06:34.586
Here you can see a very early example

00:06:34.610 --> 00:06:38.189
with the robots trying to use
this embodied artificial intelligence

00:06:38.213 --> 00:06:40.676
to try to match my movements
as closely as possible.

00:06:40.700 --> 00:06:42.163
It's sort of like a game.

00:06:42.488 --> 00:06:43.697
Let's look at it.

00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:51.149
You can see when I psych
it out, it gets fooled.

00:06:51.656 --> 00:06:54.251
And it's a little bit
like what you might see actors do

00:06:54.275 --> 00:06:55.909
when they try to mirror each other

00:06:55.933 --> 00:06:58.298
to find the right synchrony between them.

00:06:58.322 --> 00:07:00.154
And then, I did another experiment,

00:07:00.178 --> 00:07:04.237
and I got people off the street
to use the robotic desk lamp,

00:07:04.261 --> 00:07:07.363
and try out this idea
of embodied artificial intelligence.

00:07:07.879 --> 00:07:12.477
So, I actually used two kinds
of brains for the same robot.

00:07:12.501 --> 00:07:14.453
The robot is the same lamp that you saw,

00:07:14.477 --> 00:07:15.816
and I put two brains in it.

00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:17.567
For one half of the people,

00:07:17.591 --> 00:07:20.527
I put in a brain
that's kind of the traditional,

00:07:20.551 --> 00:07:21.780
calculated robotic brain.

00:07:21.804 --> 00:07:24.444
It waits for its turn,
it analyzes everything, it plans.

00:07:24.468 --> 00:07:26.150
Let's call it the calculated brain.

00:07:26.174 --> 00:07:29.421
The other got more the stage
actor, risk-taker brain.

00:07:29.445 --> 00:07:31.567
Let's call it the adventurous brain.

00:07:31.591 --> 00:07:34.528
It sometimes acts without knowing
everything it has to know.

00:07:34.552 --> 00:07:36.844
It sometimes makes mistakes
and corrects them.

00:07:36.868 --> 00:07:40.786
And I had them do this very tedious task
that took almost 20 minutes,

00:07:40.810 --> 00:07:42.286
and they had to work together,

00:07:42.310 --> 00:07:44.863
somehow simulating, like, a factory job

00:07:44.887 --> 00:07:46.974
of repetitively doing the same thing.

00:07:47.403 --> 00:07:50.734
What I found is that people
actually loved the adventurous robot.

00:07:50.758 --> 00:07:52.535
They thought it was more intelligent,

00:07:52.559 --> 00:07:54.665
more committed,
a better member of the team,

00:07:54.689 --> 00:07:56.754
contributed to the success
of the team more.

00:07:56.778 --> 00:07:58.486
They even called it "he" and "she,"

00:07:58.510 --> 00:08:00.631
whereas people with the calculated brain

00:08:00.655 --> 00:08:03.457
called it "it," and nobody
ever called it "he" or "she."

00:08:03.834 --> 00:08:07.127
When they talked about it after the task,
with the adventurous brain,

00:08:07.151 --> 00:08:10.934
they said, "By the end, we were good
friends and high-fived mentally."

00:08:11.355 --> 00:08:12.648
Whatever that means.

00:08:12.672 --> 00:08:14.578
(Laughter)

00:08:14.602 --> 00:08:15.955
Sounds painful.

00:08:15.979 --> 00:08:18.717
Whereas the people
with the calculated brain

00:08:18.741 --> 00:08:21.099
said it was just like a lazy apprentice.

00:08:21.123 --> 00:08:23.868
It only did what it was supposed
to do and nothing more,

00:08:23.892 --> 00:08:26.241
which is almost what people
expect robots to do,

00:08:26.265 --> 00:08:29.820
so I was surprised that people
had higher expectations of robots

00:08:29.844 --> 00:08:33.350
than what anybody in robotics
thought robots should be doing.

00:08:33.985 --> 00:08:36.000
And in a way, I thought,
maybe it's time --

00:08:36.024 --> 00:08:38.986
just like method acting
changed the way people thought

00:08:39.010 --> 00:08:40.606
about acting in the 19th century,

00:08:40.630 --> 00:08:43.707
from going from the very calculated,
planned way of behaving,

00:08:43.731 --> 00:08:47.229
to a more intuitive, risk-taking,
embodied way of behaving --

00:08:47.253 --> 00:08:50.449
maybe it's time for robots
to have the same kind of revolution.

00:08:51.952 --> 00:08:55.551
A few years later, I was at my next
research job at Georgia Tech in Atlanta,

00:08:55.575 --> 00:08:58.399
and I was working in a group
dealing with robotic musicians.

00:08:58.423 --> 00:09:00.783
And I thought, music:
that's the perfect place

00:09:00.807 --> 00:09:04.950
to look at teamwork, coordination,
timing, improvisation --

00:09:04.974 --> 00:09:07.417
and we just got this robot
playing marimba.

00:09:07.441 --> 00:09:09.697
And the marimba, for everybody like me,

00:09:09.721 --> 00:09:12.460
it was this huge, wooden xylophone.

00:09:12.484 --> 00:09:14.547
And when I was looking at this,

00:09:14.571 --> 00:09:17.569
I looked at other works
in human-robot improvisation --

00:09:17.593 --> 00:09:20.340
yes, there are other works
in human-robot improvisation --

00:09:20.364 --> 00:09:22.713
and they were also a little bit
like a chess game.

00:09:22.737 --> 00:09:23.888
The human would play,

00:09:23.912 --> 00:09:26.085
the robot analyzed what was played,

00:09:26.109 --> 00:09:28.188
and would improvise their own part.

00:09:28.212 --> 00:09:31.350
So, this is what musicians called
a call-and-response interaction,

00:09:31.374 --> 00:09:35.121
and it also fits very well
robots and artificial intelligence.

00:09:35.145 --> 00:09:38.398
But I thought, if I use the same ideas
I used in the theater play

00:09:38.422 --> 00:09:40.166
and in the teamwork studies,

00:09:40.190 --> 00:09:43.840
maybe I can make the robots
jam together like a band.

00:09:43.864 --> 00:09:48.132
Everybody's riffing off each other,
nobody is stopping for a moment.

00:09:48.156 --> 00:09:51.030
And so I tried to do the same
things, this time with music,

00:09:51.054 --> 00:09:53.888
where the robot doesn't really know
what it's about to play,

00:09:53.912 --> 00:09:56.929
it just sort of moves its body
and uses opportunities to play,

00:09:56.953 --> 00:09:59.492
and does what my jazz teacher
when I was 17 taught me.

00:09:59.516 --> 00:10:00.913
She said, when you improvise,

00:10:00.937 --> 00:10:03.953
sometimes you don't know
what you're doing, and you still do it.

00:10:03.977 --> 00:10:07.303
So I tried to make a robot that doesn't
actually know what it's doing,

00:10:07.327 --> 00:10:08.548
but is still doing it.

00:10:08.572 --> 00:10:11.083
So let's look at a few seconds
from this performance,

00:10:11.107 --> 00:10:13.234
where the robot listens
to the human musician

00:10:13.258 --> 00:10:14.423
and improvises.

00:10:14.447 --> 00:10:17.422
And then, look how the human
musician also responds

00:10:17.446 --> 00:10:18.719
to what the robot is doing

00:10:18.743 --> 00:10:21.387
and picking up from its behavior,

00:10:21.411 --> 00:10:25.367
and at some point can even be surprised
by what the robot came up with.

00:10:25.391 --> 00:10:27.585
(Music)

00:11:07.576 --> 00:11:09.576
(Music ends)

00:11:11.092 --> 00:11:16.826
(Applause)

00:11:16.850 --> 00:11:19.100
Being a musician
is not just about making notes,

00:11:19.124 --> 00:11:21.472
otherwise nobody
would ever go see a live show.

00:11:21.496 --> 00:11:23.618
Musicians also communicate
with their bodies,

00:11:23.642 --> 00:11:25.659
with other band members,
with the audience,

00:11:25.683 --> 00:11:27.697
they use their bodies
to express the music.

00:11:27.721 --> 00:11:30.418
And I thought, we already have
a robot musician on stage,

00:11:30.442 --> 00:11:32.754
why not make it be
a full-fledged musician?

00:11:32.778 --> 00:11:35.452
And I started designing
a socially expressive head

00:11:35.476 --> 00:11:36.819
for the robot.

00:11:36.843 --> 00:11:38.913
The head doesn’t actually
touch the marimba,

00:11:38.937 --> 00:11:40.896
it just expresses what the music is like.

00:11:40.920 --> 00:11:43.416
These are some napkin sketches
from a bar in Atlanta

00:11:43.440 --> 00:11:45.983
that was dangerously
located exactly halfway

00:11:46.007 --> 00:11:47.818
between my lab and my home.

00:11:47.842 --> 00:11:51.780
So I spent, I would say, on average,
three to four hours a day there.

00:11:51.804 --> 00:11:52.991
I think.

00:11:53.015 --> 00:11:54.542
(Laughter)

00:11:54.875 --> 00:11:57.757
And I went back to my animation
tools and tried to figure out

00:11:57.781 --> 00:12:00.151
not just what a robotic
musician would look like,

00:12:00.175 --> 00:12:02.800
but especially what a robotic
musician would move like,

00:12:02.824 --> 00:12:06.226
to sort of show that it doesn't like
what the other person is playing --

00:12:06.250 --> 00:12:10.075
and maybe show whatever beat
it's feeling at the moment.

00:12:10.099 --> 00:12:14.602
So we ended up actually getting the money
to build this robot, which was nice.

00:12:14.626 --> 00:12:17.230
I'm going to show you now
the same kind of performance,

00:12:17.254 --> 00:12:19.294
this time with a socially expressive head.

00:12:19.318 --> 00:12:21.118
And notice one thing --

00:12:21.142 --> 00:12:22.813
how the robot is really showing us

00:12:22.837 --> 00:12:24.743
the beat it's picking up from the human,

00:12:24.767 --> 00:12:28.694
while also giving the human a sense
that the robot knows what it's doing.

00:12:28.718 --> 00:12:30.638
And also how it changes the way it moves

00:12:30.662 --> 00:12:32.614
as soon as it starts its own solo.

00:12:32.638 --> 00:12:36.534
(Music)

00:12:36.558 --> 00:12:39.578
Now it's looking at me,
showing that it's listening.

00:12:39.602 --> 00:12:42.325
(Music)

00:13:01.139 --> 00:13:04.060
Now look at the final chord
of the piece again.

00:13:04.084 --> 00:13:07.001
And this time the robot
communicates with its body

00:13:07.025 --> 00:13:09.138
when it's busy doing its own thing,

00:13:09.162 --> 00:13:14.013
and when it's ready to coordinate
the final chord with me.

00:13:14.037 --> 00:13:16.774
(Music)

00:13:21.741 --> 00:13:23.741
(Music ending)

00:13:26.061 --> 00:13:27.062
(Final chord)

00:13:27.086 --> 00:13:32.840
(Applause)

00:13:32.864 --> 00:13:34.019
Thanks.

00:13:34.043 --> 00:13:35.624
I hope you see

00:13:35.648 --> 00:13:40.044
how much this part of the body
that doesn't touch the instrument

00:13:40.068 --> 00:13:42.660
actually helps
with the musical performance.

00:13:43.118 --> 00:13:45.127
And at some point -- we are in Atlanta,

00:13:45.151 --> 00:13:48.401
so obviously some rapper
will come into our lab at some point --

00:13:48.425 --> 00:13:53.218
and we had this rapper come in and do
a little jam with the robot.

00:13:53.242 --> 00:13:57.290
Here you can see the robot
basically responding to the beat.

00:13:57.314 --> 00:13:58.465
Notice two things:

00:13:58.489 --> 00:14:02.098
one, how irresistible it is to join
the robot while it's moving its head.

00:14:02.122 --> 00:14:04.725
You kind of want to move
your own head when it does it.

00:14:04.749 --> 00:14:08.335
And second, even though the rapper
is really focused on his iPhone,

00:14:08.359 --> 00:14:11.469
as soon as the robot turns
to him, he turns back.

00:14:11.493 --> 00:14:14.129
So even though it's just
in the periphery of his vision,

00:14:14.153 --> 00:14:16.273
in the corner of his eye,
it's very powerful.

00:14:16.297 --> 00:14:18.131
And the reason is that we can't ignore

00:14:18.155 --> 00:14:20.179
physical things moving in our environment.

00:14:20.203 --> 00:14:21.373
We are wired for that.

00:14:21.397 --> 00:14:23.041
So if you have a problem --

00:14:23.065 --> 00:14:27.740
maybe your partner is looking
at their iPhone or smartphone too much --

00:14:27.764 --> 00:14:30.598
you might want to have a robot
there to get their attention.

00:14:30.622 --> 00:14:31.623
(Laughter)

00:14:31.647 --> 00:14:33.716
(Music)

00:14:46.071 --> 00:14:48.071
(Music ends)

00:14:50.096 --> 00:14:57.044
(Applause)

00:14:57.591 --> 00:15:01.425
Just to introduce the last robot
that we've worked on,

00:15:01.449 --> 00:15:03.799
it came out of something
surprising that we found:

00:15:03.823 --> 00:15:06.981
Some point people didn't care
about the robot being intelligent,

00:15:07.005 --> 00:15:08.407
able to improvise and listen,

00:15:08.431 --> 00:15:12.837
and do all these embodied intelligence
things that I spent years developing.

00:15:12.861 --> 00:15:15.542
They really liked that the robot
was enjoying the music.

00:15:15.566 --> 00:15:16.567
(Laughter)

00:15:16.591 --> 00:15:19.136
And they didn't say the robot
was moving to the music,

00:15:19.160 --> 00:15:20.648
they said "enjoying" the music.

00:15:20.672 --> 00:15:22.798
And we thought,
why don't we take this idea,

00:15:22.822 --> 00:15:25.563
and I designed a new piece of furniture.

00:15:25.587 --> 00:15:28.159

but would actually enjoy it, too?

animation tests from an early stage.

product looked like.

so we can still see

00:16:35.153 --> 00:16:37.354
I think one of the reasons I care so much

00:16:37.378 --> 00:16:39.611
about robots that use
their body to communicate

and use their body to move is --

I'm going to let you in on a little
secret we roboticists are hiding --

00:16:44.779 --> 00:16:47.572
is that every one of you
is going to be living with a robot

00:16:47.596 --> 00:16:49.188
at some point in your life.

00:16:49.212 --> 00:16:52.145
Somewhere in your future,
there will be a robot in your life.

00:16:52.169 --> 00:16:54.037

00:16:54.061 --> 00:16:59.051
And I want these robots to be more fluent,
more engaging, more graceful

00:16:59.075 --> 00:17:00.804
than currently they seem to be.

00:17:00.828 --> 00:17:04.115
And for that I think maybe robots
need to be less like chess players

00:17:04.139 --> 00:17:06.780
and more like stage actors
and more like musicians.

00:17:06.804 --> 00:17:09.617
Maybe they should be able
to take chances and improvise.
