00:03:49.056 --> 00:03:51.019
but fortunately we had help.

00:03:51.019 --> 00:03:53.954
In the late 1990s, a couple of professors

00:03:53.954 --> 00:03:57.435
proposed a concept for radically reducing the price

00:03:57.435 --> 00:03:59.207
of putting things in space.

00:03:59.207 --> 00:04:01.318
This was hitchhiking small satellites

00:04:01.318 --> 00:04:04.334
alongside much larger satellites.

00:04:04.334 --> 00:04:07.243
This dropped the cost of putting objects up there

00:04:07.243 --> 00:04:09.241
by over a factor of 100,

00:04:09.241 --> 00:04:12.327
and suddenly we could afford to experiment,

00:04:12.327 --> 00:04:13.795
to take a little bit of risk,

00:04:13.795 --> 00:04:16.061
and to realize a lot of innovation.

00:04:16.061 --> 00:04:19.150
And a new generation of engineers and scientists,

00:04:19.150 --> 00:04:20.749
mostly out of universities,

00:04:20.749 --> 00:04:23.092
began launching these very small,

00:04:23.092 --> 00:04:25.683
breadbox-sized satellites called CubeSats.

00:04:25.683 --> 00:04:28.086
And these were built with electronics obtained

00:04:28.086 --> 00:04:31.984
from RadioShack instead of Lockheed Martin.

00:04:31.984 --> 00:04:34.824
Now it was using the lessons
learned from these early missions

00:04:34.824 --> 00:04:37.519
that my friends and I began a series of sketches

00:04:37.519 --> 00:04:39.208
of our own satellite design.

00:04:39.208 --> 00:04:41.992
And I can't remember a specific day

00:04:41.992 --> 00:04:43.852
where we made a conscious decision

00:04:43.852 --> 00:04:46.487
that we were actually going to
go out and build these things,

00:04:46.487 --> 00:04:48.917
but once we got that idea in our minds

00:04:48.917 --> 00:04:51.078
of the world as a dataset,

00:04:51.078 --> 00:04:53.568
of being able to capture millions of data points

00:04:53.568 --> 00:04:56.621
on a daily basis describing the global economy,

00:04:56.621 --> 00:04:59.141
of being able to unearth billions of connections

00:04:59.141 --> 00:05:02.306
between them that had never before been found,

00:05:02.306 --> 00:05:03.954
it just seemed boring

00:05:03.954 --> 00:05:06.861
to go work on anything else.

00:05:06.861 --> 00:05:09.834
And so we moved into a cramped,

00:05:09.834 --> 00:05:12.813
windowless office in Palo Alto,

00:05:12.813 --> 00:05:14.780
and began working to take our design

00:05:14.780 --> 00:05:17.718
from the drawing board into the lab.

00:05:17.718 --> 00:05:20.376
The first major question we had to tackle

00:05:20.376 --> 00:05:22.710
was just how big to build this thing.

00:05:22.710 --> 00:05:25.893
In space, size drives cost,

00:05:25.893 --> 00:05:27.906
and we had worked with these very small,

00:05:27.906 --> 00:05:30.000
breadbox-sized satellites in school,

00:05:30.000 --> 00:05:32.551
but as we began to better
understand the laws of physics,

00:05:32.551 --> 00:05:34.673
we found that the quality of pictures

00:05:34.673 --> 00:05:37.757
those satellites could take was very limited,

00:05:37.757 --> 00:05:39.461
because the laws of physics dictate

00:05:39.461 --> 00:05:42.567
that the best picture you
can take through a telescope

00:05:42.567 --> 00:05:44.806
is a function of the diameter of that telescope,

00:05:44.806 --> 00:05:46.468
and these satellites had a very small,

00:05:46.468 --> 00:05:48.174
very constrained volume.

00:05:48.174 --> 00:05:49.969
And we found that the best picture we would

00:05:49.969 --> 00:05:52.454
have been able to get looked something like this.

00:05:52.454 --> 00:05:54.699
Although this was the low-cost option,

00:05:54.699 --> 00:05:56.372
quite frankly it was just too blurry

00:05:56.372 --> 00:05:59.941
to see the things that make
satellite imagery valuable.

00:05:59.941 --> 00:06:02.087
So about three or four weeks later,

00:06:02.087 --> 00:06:04.904
we met a group of engineers randomly

00:06:04.904 --> 00:06:06.545
who had worked on the first

00:06:06.545 --> 00:06:08.986
private imaging satellite ever developed,

00:06:08.986 --> 00:06:11.104
and they told us that back in the 1970s,

00:06:11.104 --> 00:06:13.286
the U.S. government had found a powerful

00:06:13.286 --> 00:06:14.929
optimal tradeoff --

00:06:14.929 --> 00:06:18.017
that in taking pictures at right
about one meter resolution,

00:06:18.017 --> 00:06:20.901
being able to see objects one meter in size,

00:06:20.901 --> 00:06:23.592
they had found that they could not
just get very high-quality images,

00:06:23.592 --> 00:06:26.485
but get a lot of them at an affordable price.

00:06:26.485 --> 00:06:28.461
From our own computer simulations,

00:06:28.461 --> 00:06:30.466
we quickly found that one meter really was

00:06:30.466 --> 00:06:32.230
the minimum viable product

00:06:32.230 --> 00:06:35.309
to be able to see the drivers of our global economy,

00:06:35.309 --> 00:06:36.870
for the first time, being able to count

00:06:36.870 --> 00:06:39.591
the ships and cars and shipping
containers and trucks

00:06:39.591 --> 00:06:42.415
that move around our world on a daily basis,

00:06:42.415 --> 00:06:46.219
while conveniently still not
being able to see individuals.

00:06:46.219 --> 00:06:47.840
We had found our compromise.

00:06:47.840 --> 00:06:49.444
We would have to build something larger

00:06:49.444 --> 00:06:51.007
than the original breadbox,

00:06:51.007 --> 00:06:52.658
now more like a mini-fridge,

00:06:52.658 --> 00:06:55.419
but we still wouldn't have to build a pickup truck.

00:06:55.419 --> 00:06:58.043
So now we had our constraint.

00:06:58.043 --> 00:06:59.800
The laws of physics dictated

00:06:59.800 --> 00:07:03.124
the absolute minimum-sized
telescope that we could build.

00:07:03.124 --> 00:07:06.178
What came next was making the rest of the satellite

00:07:06.178 --> 00:07:07.919
as small and as simple as possible,

00:07:07.919 --> 00:07:10.571
basically a flying telescope with four walls

00:07:10.571 --> 00:07:13.512
and a set of electronics smaller than a phone book

00:07:13.512 --> 00:07:16.950
that used less power than a 100 watt lightbulb.

00:07:16.950 --> 00:07:18.850
The big challenge became actually taking

00:07:18.850 --> 00:07:21.048
the pictures through that telescope.

00:07:21.048 --> 00:07:24.092
Traditional imaging satellites use a line scanner,

00:07:24.092 --> 00:07:25.853
similar to a Xerox machine,

00:07:25.853 --> 00:07:28.253
and as they traverse the Earth, they take pictures,

00:07:28.253 --> 00:07:30.449
scanning row by row by row

00:07:30.449 --> 00:07:32.124
to build the complete image.

00:07:32.124 --> 00:07:35.128
Now people use these because they get a lot of light,

00:07:35.128 --> 00:07:36.959
which means less of the noise you see

00:07:36.974 --> 00:07:39.710
in a low-cost cell phone image.

00:07:39.710 --> 00:07:42.071
The problem with them is they require

00:07:42.071 --> 00:07:44.311
very sophisticated pointing.

00:07:44.311 --> 00:07:46.857
You have to stay focused on a 50-centimeter target

00:07:46.857 --> 00:07:48.609
from over 600 miles away

00:07:48.609 --> 00:07:50.841
while moving at more than
seven kilometers a second,

00:07:50.841 --> 00:07:53.590
which requires an awesome degree of complexity.

00:07:53.590 --> 00:07:57.027
So instead, we turned to a new
generation of video sensors,

00:07:57.027 --> 00:08:00.118
originally created for use in night vision goggles.

00:08:00.118 --> 00:08:03.017
Instead of taking a single, high quality image,

00:08:03.017 --> 00:08:04.404
we could take a videostream

00:08:04.404 --> 00:08:07.327
of individually noisier frames,

00:08:07.327 --> 00:08:09.071
but then we could recombine

00:08:09.071 --> 00:08:10.537
all of those frames together

00:08:10.537 --> 00:08:12.533
into very high-quality images

00:08:12.533 --> 00:08:15.126
using sophisticated pixel processing techniques

00:08:15.126 --> 00:08:16.647
here on the ground,

00:08:16.647 --> 00:08:19.784
at a cost of one one hundredth a traditional system.

00:08:19.784 --> 00:08:20.937
And we applied this technique

00:08:20.937 --> 00:08:23.911
to many of the other systems on the satellite as well,

00:08:23.911 --> 00:08:26.751
and day by day, our design evolved

00:08:26.751 --> 00:08:30.240
from CAD to prototypes

00:08:30.240 --> 00:08:33.128
to production units.

00:08:33.128 --> 00:08:34.785
A few short weeks ago,

00:08:34.785 --> 00:08:36.636
we packed up SkySat 1,

00:08:36.636 --> 00:08:38.409
put our signatures on it,

00:08:38.409 --> 00:08:40.632
and waved goodbye for the last time on Earth.

00:08:40.632 --> 00:08:44.113
Today, it's sitting in its final launch configuration

00:08:44.113 --> 00:08:47.174
ready to blast off in a few short weeks.

00:08:47.174 --> 00:08:49.516
And soon, we'll turn our attention to launching

00:08:49.516 --> 00:08:52.547
a constellation of 24 or more of these satellites

00:08:52.547 --> 00:08:55.097
and beginning to build the scalable analytics

00:08:55.097 --> 00:08:57.436
that will allow us to unearth the insights

00:08:57.436 --> 00:09:00.625
in the petabytes of data we will collect.

00:09:00.625 --> 00:09:04.598
So why do all of this? Why build these satellites?

00:09:04.598 --> 00:09:07.209
Well, it turns out imaging satellites

00:09:07.209 --> 00:09:10.919
have a unique ability to provide global transparency,

00:09:10.919 --> 00:09:13.545
and providing that transparency on a timely basis

00:09:13.545 --> 00:09:16.956
is simply an idea whose time has come.

00:09:16.956 --> 00:09:20.479
We see ourselves as pioneers of a new frontier,

00:09:20.479 --> 00:09:22.243
and beyond economic data,

00:09:22.243 --> 00:09:25.844
unlocking the human story, moment by moment.

00:09:25.844 --> 00:09:27.407
For a data scientist

00:09:27.407 --> 00:09:30.157
that just happened to go to space camp as a kid,

00:09:30.157 --> 00:09:32.872
it just doesn't get much better than that.

00:09:32.872 --> 00:09:35.087
Thank you.

00:09:35.087 --> 00:09:39.221
(Applause)

title: How architectural innovations migrate across borders
transcript: The urban explosion of the last years of economic boom also produced dramatic marginalization, resulting in the explosion of slums in many parts of the world. This polarization of enclaves of mega-wealth surrounded by sectors of poverty and the socioeconomic inequalities they have engendered is really at the center of today's urban crisis. But I want to begin tonight by suggesting that this urban crisis is not only economic or environmental. It's particularly a cultural crisis, a crisis of the institutions unable to reimagine the stupid ways which we have been growing, unable to challenge the oil-hungry, selfish urbanization that have perpetuated cities based on consumption, from southern California to New York to Dubai. So I just really want to share with you a reflection that the future of cities today depends less on buildings and, in fact, depends more on the fundamental reorganization of socioeconomic relations, that the best ideas in the shaping of the city in the future will not come from enclaves of economic power and abundance, but in fact from sectors of conflict and scarcity from which an urgent imagination can really inspire us to rethink urban growth today.And let me illustrate what I mean by understanding or engaging sites of conflict as harboring creativity, as I briefly introduce you to the Tijuana-San Diego border region, which has been the laboratory to rethink my practice as an architect.This is the wall, the border wall, that separates San Diego and Tijuana, Latin America and the United States, a physical emblem of exclusionary planning policies that have perpetuated the division of communities, jurisdictions and resources across the world. In this border region, we find some of the wealthiest real estate, as I once found in the edges of San Diego, barely 20 minutes away from some of the poorest  settlements in Latin America. And while these two cities have the same population, San Diego has grown six times larger than Tijuana in the last decades, immediately thrusting us to confront the tensions and conflicts between sprawl and density, which are at the center of today's discussion about environmental sustainability. So I've been arguing in the last years that, in fact, the slums of Tijuana can teach a lot to the sprawls of San Diego when it comes to socioeconomic sustainability, that we should pay attention and learn from the many migrant communities on both sides of this border wall so that we can translate their informal processes of urbanization.What do I mean by the informal in this case? I'm really just talking about the compendium of social practices of adaptation that enable many of these migrant communities to transgress imposed political and economic recipes of urbanization. I'm talking simply about the creative intelligence of the bottom-up, whether manifested in the slums of Tijuana that build themselves, in fact, with the waste of San Diego, or the many migrant neighborhoods in Southern California that have begun to be retrofitted with difference in the last decades.So I've been interested as an artist in the measuring, the observation, of many of the trans-border informal flows across this border: in one direction, from south to north, the flow of immigrants into the United States, and from north to south the flow of waste from southern California into Tijuana. I'm referring to the recycling of these old post-war bungalows that Mexican contractors bring to the border as American developers are disposing of them in the process of building a more inflated version of suburbia in the last decades. So these are houses waiting to cross the border. Not only people cross the border here, but entire chunks of one city move to the next, and when these houses are placed on top of these steel frames, they leave the first floor to become the second to be in-filled with more house, with a small business. This layering of spaces and economies is very interesting to notice. But not only houses, also small debris from one city, from San Diego, to Tijuana. Probably a lot of you have seen the rubber tires that are used in the slums to build retaining walls. But look at what people have done here in conditions of socioeconomic emergency. They have figured out how to peel off the tire, how to thread it and interlock it to construct a more efficient retaining wall. Or the garage doors that are brought from San Diego in trucks to become the new skin of emergency housing in many of these slums surrounding the edges of Tijuana.So while, as an architect, this is a very compelling thing to witness, this creative intelligence, I also want to keep myself in check. I don't want to romanticize poverty. I just want to suggest that this informal urbanization is not just the image of precariousness, that informality here, the informal, is really a set of socioeconomic and political procedures that we could translate as artists, that this is about a bottom-up urbanization that performs. See here, buildings are not important just for their looks, but, in fact, they are important for what they can do. They truly perform as they transform through time and as communities negotiate the spaces and boundaries and resources.So while waste flows southbound, people go north in search of dollars, and most of my research has had to do with the impact of immigration in the alteration of the homogeneity of many neighborhoods in the United States, particularly in San Diego. And I'm talking about how this begins to suggest that the future of Southern California depends on the retrofitting of the large urbanization — I mean, on steroids — with the small programs, social and economic. I'm referring to how immigrants, when they come to these neighborhoods, they begin to alter the one-dimensionality of parcels and properties into more socially and economically complex systems, as they begin to plug an informal economy into a garage, or as they build an illegal granny flat to support an extended family. This socioeconomic entrepreneurship on the ground within these neighborhoods really begins to suggest ways of translating that into new, inclusive and more equitable land use policies. So many stories emerge from these dynamics of alteration of space, such as "the informal Buddha," which tells the story of a small house that saved itself, it did not travel to Mexico, but it was retrofitted in the end into a Buddhist temple, and in so doing, this small house transforms or mutates from a singular dwelling into a small, or a micro, socioeconomic and cultural infrastructure inside a neighborhood.So these action neighborhoods, as I call them, really become the inspiration to imagine other interpretations of citizenship that have less to do, in fact, with belonging to the nation-state, and more with upholding the notion of citizenship as a creative act that reorganizes institutional protocols in the spaces of the city.As an artist, I've been interested, in fact, in the visualization of citizenship, the gathering of many anecdotes, urban stories, in order to narrativize the relationship between social processes and spaces. This is a story of a group of teenagers that one night, a few months ago, decided to invade this space under the freeway to begin constructing their own skateboard park. With shovels in hand, they started to dig. Two weeks later, the police stopped them. They barricaded the place, and the teenagers were evicted, and the teenagers decided to fight back, not with bank cards or slogans but with constructing a critical process. The first thing they did was to recognize the specificity of political jurisdiction inscribed in that empty space. They found out that they had been lucky because they had not begun to dig under Caltrans territoy. Caltrans is a state agency that governs the freeway, so it would have been very difficult to negotiate with them. They were lucky, they said, because they began to dig under an arm of the freeway that belongs to the local municipality. They were also lucky, they said, because they began to dig in a sort of Bermuda Triangle of jurisdiction, between port authority, airport authority, two city districts, and a review board. All these red lines are the invisible political institutions that were inscribed in that leftover empty space. With this knowledge, these teenagers as skaters confronted the city. They came to the city attorney's office. The city attorney told them that in order to continue the negotiation they had to become an NGO, and of course they didn't know what an NGO was. They had to talk to their friends in Seattle who had gone through the same experience. And they began to realize the necessity to organize themselves even deeper and began to fundraise, to organize budgets, to really be aware of all the knowledge embedded in the urban code in San Diego so that they could begin to redefine the very meaning of public space in the city, expanding it to other categories. At the end, the teenagers won the case with that evidence, and they were able to construct their skateboard park under that freeway.Now for many of you, this story might seem trivial or naive. For me as an architect, it has become a fundamental narrative, because it begins to teach me that this micro-community not only designed another category of public space but they also designed the socioeconomic protocols that were necessary to be inscribed in that space for its long-term sustainability. They also taught me that similar to the migrant communities on both sides of the border, they engaged conflict itself as a creative tool, because they had to produce a process that enabled them to reorganize resources and the politics of the city. In that act, that informal, bottom-up act of transgression, really began to trickle up to transform top-down policy.Now this journey from the bottom-up to the transformation of the top-down is where I find hope today. And I'm thinking of how these modest alterations with space and with policy in many cities in the world, in primarily the urgency of a collective imagination as these communities reimagine their own forms of governance, social organization, and infrastructure, really is at the center of the new formation of democratic politics of the urban. It is, in fact, this that could become the framework for producing new social and economic justice in the city. I want to say this and emphasize it, because this is the only way I see that can enable us to move from urbanizations of consumption to neighborhoods of production today.Thank you.(Applause)

I'm talking simply about the creative intelligence

00:03:53.777 --> 00:03:56.152
of the bottom-up,

00:03:56.152 --> 00:03:59.349
whether manifested in the slums of Tijuana

00:03:59.349 --> 00:04:03.093
that build themselves, in fact,
with the waste of San Diego,

00:04:03.093 --> 00:04:05.851
or the many migrant neighborhoods
in Southern California

00:04:05.851 --> 00:04:08.927
that have begun to be retrofitted with difference

00:04:08.927 --> 00:04:10.584
in the last decades.

00:04:10.584 --> 00:04:12.792
So I've been interested as an artist

00:04:12.792 --> 00:04:15.376
in the measuring, the observation,

00:04:15.376 --> 00:04:17.648
of many of the trans-border informal flows

00:04:17.648 --> 00:04:19.338
across this border:

00:04:19.338 --> 00:04:21.775
in one direction, from south to north,

00:04:21.775 --> 00:04:24.368
the flow of immigrants into the United States,

00:04:24.368 --> 00:04:27.377
and from north to south the flow of waste

00:04:27.377 --> 00:04:30.408
from southern California into Tijuana.

00:04:30.408 --> 00:04:32.676
I'm referring to the recycling

00:04:32.676 --> 00:04:36.128
of these old post-war bungalows

00:04:36.128 --> 00:04:39.587
that Mexican contractors bring to the border

00:04:39.587 --> 00:04:42.432
as American developers are disposing of them

00:04:42.432 --> 00:04:45.000
in the process of building a more inflated version

00:04:45.000 --> 00:04:47.076
of suburbia in the last decades.

00:04:47.076 --> 00:04:49.991
So these are houses waiting to cross the border.

00:04:49.991 --> 00:04:52.343
Not only people cross the border here,

00:04:52.343 --> 00:04:55.610
but entire chunks of one city move to the next,

00:04:55.610 --> 00:04:59.504
and when these houses are placed
on top of these steel frames,

00:04:59.504 --> 00:05:02.081
they leave the first floor to become the second

00:05:02.081 --> 00:05:04.135
to be in-filled with more house,

00:05:04.135 --> 00:05:05.793
with a small business.

00:05:05.793 --> 00:05:08.670
This layering of spaces and economies

00:05:08.670 --> 00:05:10.952
is very interesting to notice.

00:05:10.952 --> 00:05:13.467
But not only houses, also small debris

00:05:13.467 --> 00:05:15.814
from one city, from San Diego, to Tijuana.

00:05:15.814 --> 00:05:18.200
Probably a lot of you have seen the rubber tires

00:05:18.200 --> 00:05:20.829
that are used in the slums to build retaining walls.

00:05:20.829 --> 00:05:23.182
But look at what people have done here in conditions

00:05:23.182 --> 00:05:25.410
of socioeconomic emergency.

00:05:25.410 --> 00:05:28.571
They have figured out how to peel off the tire,

00:05:28.571 --> 00:05:30.936
how to thread it and interlock it

00:05:30.936 --> 00:05:35.064
to construct a more efficient retaining wall.

00:05:35.064 --> 00:05:38.276
Or the garage doors that are brought

00:05:38.276 --> 00:05:40.784
from San Diego in trucks

00:05:40.784 --> 00:05:45.513
to become the new skin of emergency housing

00:05:45.513 --> 00:05:47.352
in many of these slums

00:05:47.352 --> 00:05:49.682
surrounding the edges of Tijuana.

00:05:49.682 --> 00:05:51.098
So while, as an architect,

00:05:51.098 --> 00:05:53.025
this is a very compelling thing to witness,

00:05:53.025 --> 00:05:54.719
this creative intelligence,

00:05:54.719 --> 00:05:56.732
I also want to keep myself in check.

00:05:56.732 --> 00:05:58.768
I don't want to romanticize poverty.

00:05:58.768 --> 00:06:00.759
I just want to suggest

00:06:00.759 --> 00:06:02.900
that this informal urbanization

00:06:02.900 --> 00:06:06.499
is not just the image of precariousness,

00:06:06.499 --> 00:06:09.581
that informality here, the informal,

00:06:09.581 --> 00:06:14.111
is really a set of socioeconomic
and political procedures

00:06:14.111 --> 00:06:16.820
that we could translate as artists,

00:06:16.820 --> 00:06:19.165
that this is about a bottom-up urbanization

00:06:19.165 --> 00:06:20.690
that performs.

00:06:20.690 --> 00:06:23.516
See here, buildings are not important

00:06:23.516 --> 00:06:25.479
just for their looks,

00:06:25.479 --> 00:06:28.920
but, in fact, they are important for what they can do.

00:06:28.920 --> 00:06:32.019
They truly perform as they transform through time

00:06:32.034 --> 00:06:34.182
and as communities negotiate

00:06:34.182 --> 00:06:37.691
the spaces and boundaries and resources.

00:06:37.691 --> 00:06:40.812
So while waste flows southbound,

00:06:40.812 --> 00:06:43.340
people go north in search of dollars,

00:06:43.340 --> 00:06:45.875
and most of my research has had to do

00:06:45.875 --> 00:06:49.770
with the impact of immigration

00:06:49.770 --> 00:06:52.244
in the alteration of the homogeneity

00:06:52.244 --> 00:06:54.570
of many neighborhoods in the United States,

00:06:54.570 --> 00:06:56.534
particularly in San Diego.

00:06:56.534 --> 00:06:58.919
And I'm talking about how this begins to suggest

00:06:58.919 --> 00:07:01.572
that the future of Southern California

00:07:01.572 --> 00:07:04.095
depends on the retrofitting

00:07:04.095 --> 00:07:07.302
of the large urbanization -- I mean, on steroids --

00:07:07.302 --> 00:07:09.790
with the small programs,

00:07:09.790 --> 00:07:11.566
social and economic.

00:07:11.566 --> 00:07:13.671
I'm referring to how immigrants,

00:07:13.671 --> 00:07:15.469
when they come to these neighborhoods,

00:07:15.469 --> 00:07:18.520
they begin to alter the one-dimensionality

00:07:18.520 --> 00:07:20.502
of parcels and properties

00:07:20.502 --> 00:07:24.889
into more socially and
economically complex systems,

00:07:24.889 --> 00:07:28.626
as they begin to plug an
informal economy into a garage,

00:07:28.626 --> 00:07:30.940
or as they build an illegal granny flat

00:07:30.940 --> 00:07:33.442
to support an extended family.

00:07:33.442 --> 00:07:38.517
This socioeconomic entrepreneurship

00:07:38.517 --> 00:07:41.620
on the ground within these neighborhoods

00:07:41.620 --> 00:07:45.166
really begins to suggest ways of translating that

00:07:45.166 --> 00:07:49.313
into new, inclusive and more equitable

00:07:49.313 --> 00:07:51.352
land use policies.

00:07:51.352 --> 00:07:54.083
So many stories emerge from these dynamics

00:07:54.083 --> 00:07:56.944
of alteration of space,

00:07:56.944 --> 00:07:58.792
such as &quot;the informal Buddha,&quot;

00:07:58.792 --> 00:08:01.365
which tells the story of a small house

00:08:01.365 --> 00:08:04.366
that saved itself, it did not travel to Mexico,

00:08:04.366 --> 00:08:06.370
but it was retrofitted in the end

00:08:06.370 --> 00:08:08.620
into a Buddhist temple,

00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:09.849
and in so doing,

00:08:09.849 --> 00:08:13.105
this small house transforms or mutates

00:08:13.105 --> 00:08:14.803
from a singular dwelling

00:08:14.803 --> 00:08:17.625
into a small, or a micro, socioeconomic

00:08:17.625 --> 00:08:21.581
and cultural infrastructure inside a neighborhood.

00:08:21.581 --> 00:08:24.328
So these action neighborhoods, as I call them,

00:08:24.328 --> 00:08:26.356
really become the inspiration

00:08:26.356 --> 00:08:29.752
to imagine other interpretations of citizenship

00:08:29.752 --> 00:08:31.932
that have less to do, in fact,

00:08:31.932 --> 00:08:33.914
with belonging to the nation-state,

00:08:33.914 --> 00:08:37.760
and more with upholding the notion of citizenship

00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:39.654
as a creative act

00:08:39.654 --> 00:08:42.505
that reorganizes institutional protocols

00:08:42.505 --> 00:08:44.835
in the spaces of the city.

00:08:44.835 --> 00:08:47.690
As an artist, I've been interested, in fact,

00:08:47.690 --> 00:08:50.419
in the visualization of citizenship,

00:08:50.419 --> 00:08:53.984
the gathering of many anecdotes, urban stories,

00:08:53.984 --> 00:08:57.052
in order to narrativize the relationship

00:08:57.052 --> 00:09:00.182
between social processes and spaces.

00:09:00.182 --> 00:09:03.301
This is a story of a group of teenagers

00:09:03.301 --> 00:09:06.224
that one night, a few months ago,

00:09:06.224 --> 00:09:09.156
decided to invade this space under the freeway

00:09:09.156 --> 00:09:12.370
to begin constructing their own skateboard park.

00:09:12.370 --> 00:09:15.511
With shovels in hand, they started to dig.

00:09:15.511 --> 00:09:18.368
Two weeks later, the police stopped them.

00:09:18.368 --> 00:09:20.069
They barricaded the place,

00:09:20.069 --> 00:09:22.021
and the teenagers were evicted,

00:09:22.021 --> 00:09:24.734
and the teenagers decided to fight back,

00:09:24.734 --> 00:09:27.201
not with bank cards or slogans

00:09:27.201 --> 00:09:29.954
but with constructing a critical process.

00:09:29.954 --> 00:09:32.669
The first thing they did was to recognize

00:09:32.669 --> 00:09:35.649
the specificity of political jurisdiction

00:09:35.649 --> 00:09:38.376
inscribed in that empty space.

00:09:38.376 --> 00:09:40.454
They found out that they had been lucky

00:09:40.454 --> 00:09:42.268
because they had not begun to dig

00:09:42.268 --> 00:09:44.651
under Caltrans territoy.

00:09:44.651 --> 00:09:47.883
Caltrans is a state agency that governs the freeway,

00:09:47.883 --> 00:09:50.448
so it would have been very
difficult to negotiate with them.

00:09:50.448 --> 00:09:52.328
They were lucky, they said, because they began

00:09:52.328 --> 00:09:54.735
to dig under an arm of the freeway

00:09:54.735 --> 00:09:56.998
that belongs to the local municipality.

00:09:56.998 --> 00:09:58.897
They were also lucky, they said,

00:09:58.897 --> 00:10:00.635
because they began to dig in a sort of

00:10:00.635 --> 00:10:02.977
Bermuda Triangle of jurisdiction,

00:10:02.977 --> 00:10:06.454
between port authority, airport authority,

00:10:06.454 --> 00:10:09.267
two city districts, and a review board.

00:10:09.267 --> 00:10:12.045
All these red lines are the invisible

00:10:12.045 --> 00:10:14.623
political institutions that were inscribed

00:10:14.623 --> 00:10:17.657
in that leftover empty space.

00:10:17.657 --> 00:10:20.612
With this knowledge, these teenagers

00:10:20.612 --> 00:10:23.295
as skaters confronted the city.

00:10:23.295 --> 00:10:25.449
They came to the city attorney's office.

00:10:25.449 --> 00:10:27.398
The city attorney told them

00:10:27.398 --> 00:10:29.294
that in order to continue the negotiation

00:10:29.294 --> 00:10:31.237
they had to become an NGO,

00:10:31.237 --> 00:10:33.498
and of course they didn't know what an NGO was.

00:10:33.498 --> 00:10:36.437
They had to talk to their friends in Seattle

00:10:36.437 --> 00:10:38.348
who had gone through the same experience.

00:10:38.348 --> 00:10:40.532
And they began to realize the necessity

00:10:40.532 --> 00:10:42.871
to organize themselves even deeper

00:10:42.871 --> 00:10:47.005
and began to fundraise, to organize budgets,

00:10:47.005 --> 00:10:49.329
to really be aware of all the knowledge

00:10:49.329 --> 00:10:52.562
embedded in the urban code in San Diego

00:10:52.562 --> 00:10:54.780
so that they could begin to redefine

00:10:54.780 --> 00:10:58.600
the very meaning of public space in the city,

00:10:58.600 --> 00:11:01.092
expanding it to other categories.

00:11:01.092 --> 00:11:03.727
At the end, the teenagers won the case

00:11:03.727 --> 00:11:06.200
with that evidence, and they were able

00:11:06.200 --> 00:11:08.815
to construct their skateboard park

00:11:08.815 --> 00:11:10.425
under that freeway.

00:11:10.425 --> 00:11:12.870
Now for many of you, this story

00:11:12.870 --> 00:11:15.110
might seem trivial or naive.

00:11:15.110 --> 00:11:17.059
For me as an architect, it has become

00:11:17.059 --> 00:11:19.397
a fundamental narrative,

00:11:19.397 --> 00:11:21.250
because it begins to teach me

00:11:21.250 --> 00:11:23.205
that this micro-community

00:11:23.205 --> 00:11:26.697
not only designed another category of public space

00:11:26.697 --> 00:11:30.502
but they also designed the socioeconomic protocols

00:11:30.502 --> 00:11:33.599
that were necessary to be inscribed in that space

00:11:33.599 --> 00:11:36.560
for its long-term sustainability.

00:11:36.560 --> 00:11:38.045
They also taught me

00:11:38.045 --> 00:11:40.080
that similar to the migrant communities

00:11:40.080 --> 00:11:41.609
on both sides of the border,

00:11:41.609 --> 00:11:45.326
they engaged conflict itself as a creative tool,

00:11:45.326 --> 00:11:47.130
because they had to produce a process

00:11:47.130 --> 00:11:50.747
that enabled them to reorganize resources

00:11:50.747 --> 00:11:52.581
and the politics of the city.

00:11:52.581 --> 00:11:55.106
In that act, that informal,

00:11:55.106 --> 00:11:57.361
bottom-up act of transgression,

00:11:57.361 --> 00:11:59.510
really began to trickle up

00:11:59.510 --> 00:12:02.628
to transform top-down policy.

00:12:02.628 --> 00:12:07.131
Now this journey from the bottom-up

00:12:07.131 --> 00:12:09.311
to the transformation of the top-down

00:12:09.311 --> 00:12:11.829
is where I find hope today.

00:12:11.829 --> 00:12:16.078
And I'm thinking of how these modest alterations

00:12:16.078 --> 00:12:19.021
with space and with policy

00:12:19.021 --> 00:12:21.046
in many cities in the world,

00:12:21.046 --> 00:12:23.760
in primarily the urgency

00:12:23.760 --> 00:12:26.034
of a collective imagination

00:12:26.034 --> 00:12:27.508
as these communities

00:12:27.508 --> 00:12:29.915
reimagine their own forms of governance,

00:12:29.915 --> 00:12:32.606
social organization, and infrastructure,

00:12:32.606 --> 00:12:34.534
really is at the center

00:12:34.534 --> 00:12:36.622
of the new formation

00:12:36.622 --> 00:12:39.934
of democratic politics of the urban.

00:12:39.934 --> 00:12:43.211
It is, in fact, this that could become the framework

00:12:43.211 --> 00:12:46.232
for producing new social

00:12:46.232 --> 00:12:49.288
and economic justice in the city.

00:12:49.288 --> 00:12:50.906
I want to say this and emphasize it,

00:12:50.906 --> 00:12:54.555
because this is the only way I see

00:12:54.555 --> 00:12:56.768
that can enable us to move

00:12:56.768 --> 00:12:59.993
from urbanizations of consumption

00:12:59.993 --> 00:13:03.351
to neighborhoods of production today.

00:13:03.351 --> 00:13:05.239
Thank you.

00:13:05.239 --> 00:13:09.239
(Applause)

title: A new equation for intelligence
transcript: Intelligence — what is it? If we take a look back at the history of how intelligence has been viewed, one seminal example has been Edsger Dijkstra's famous quote that "the question of whether a machine can think is about as interesting as the question of whether a submarine can swim." Now, Edsger Dijkstra, when he wrote this, intended it as a criticism of the early pioneers of computer science, like Alan Turing. However, if you take a look back and think about what have been the most empowering innovations that enabled us to build artificial machines that swim and artificial machines that [fly], you find that it was only through understanding the underlying physical mechanisms of swimming and flight that we were able to build these machines. And so, several years ago, I undertook a program to try to understand the fundamental physical mechanisms underlying intelligence.Let's take a step back. Let's first begin with a thought experiment. Pretend that you're an alien race that doesn't know anything about Earth biology or Earth neuroscience or Earth intelligence, but you have amazing telescopes and you're able to watch the Earth, and you have amazingly long lives, so you're able to watch the Earth over millions, even billions of years. And you observe a really strange effect. You observe that, over the course of the millennia, Earth is continually bombarded with asteroids up until a point, and that at some point, corresponding roughly to our year, 2000 AD, asteroids that are on a collision course with the Earth that otherwise would have collided mysteriously get deflected or they detonate before they can hit the Earth. Now of course, as earthlings, we know the reason would be that we're trying to save ourselves. We're trying to prevent an impact. But if you're an alien race who doesn't know any of this, doesn't have any concept of Earth intelligence, you'd be forced to put together a physical theory that explains how, up until a certain point in time, asteroids that would demolish the surface of a planet mysteriously stop doing that. And so I claim that this is the same question as understanding the physical nature of intelligence.So in this program that I undertook several years ago, I looked at a variety of different threads across science, across a variety of disciplines, that were pointing, I think, towards a single, underlying mechanism for intelligence. In cosmology, for example, there have been a variety of different threads of evidence that our universe appears to be finely tuned for the development of intelligence, and, in particular, for the development of universal states that maximize the diversity of possible futures. In game play, for example, in Go — everyone remembers in 1997 when IBM's Deep Blue beat  Garry Kasparov at chess — fewer people are aware that in the past 10 years or so, the game of Go, arguably a much more challenging game because it has a much higher branching factor, has also started to succumb to computer game players for the same reason: the best techniques right now for computers playing Go are techniques that try to maximize future options during game play. Finally, in robotic motion planning, there have been a variety of recent techniques that have tried to take advantage of abilities of robots to maximize future freedom of action in order to accomplish complex tasks. And so, taking all of these different threads and putting them together, I asked, starting several years ago, is there an underlying mechanism for intelligence that we can factor out of all of these different threads? Is there a single equation for intelligence?And the answer, I believe, is yes. ["F = T ∇ Sτ"] What you're seeing is probably the closest equivalent to an E = mc² for intelligence that I've seen. So what you're seeing here is a statement of correspondence that intelligence is a force, F, that acts so as to maximize future freedom of action. It acts to maximize future freedom of action, or keep options open, with some strength T, with the diversity of possible accessible futures, S, up to some future time horizon, tau. In short, intelligence doesn't like to get trapped. Intelligence tries to maximize future freedom of action and keep options open. And so, given this one equation, it's natural to ask, so what can you do with this? How predictive is it? Does it predict human-level intelligence? Does it predict artificial intelligence? So I'm going to show you now a video that will, I think, demonstrate some of the amazing applications of just this single equation.(Video) Narrator: Recent research in cosmology has suggested that universes that produce more disorder, or "entropy," over their lifetimes should tend to have more favorable conditions for the existence of intelligent beings such as ourselves. But what if that tentative cosmological connection between entropy and intelligence hints at a deeper relationship? What if intelligent behavior doesn't just correlate with the production of long-term entropy, but actually emerges directly from it? To find out, we developed a software engine called Entropica, designed to maximize the production of long-term entropy of any system that it finds itself in. Amazingly, Entropica was able to pass multiple animal intelligence tests, play human games, and even earn money trading stocks, all without being instructed to do so. Here are some examples of Entropica in action.Just like a human standing upright without falling over, here we see Entropica automatically balancing a pole using a cart. This behavior is remarkable in part because we never gave Entropica a goal. It simply decided on its own to balance the pole. This balancing ability will have appliactions for humanoid robotics and human assistive technologies. Just as some animals can use objects in their environments as tools to reach into narrow spaces, here we see that Entropica, again on its own initiative, was able to move a large disk representing an animal around so as to cause a small disk, representing a tool, to reach into a confined space holding a third disk and release the third disk from its initially fixed position. This tool use ability will have applications for smart manufacturing and agriculture. In addition, just as some other animals are able to cooperate by pulling opposite ends of a rope at the same time to release food, here we see that Entropica is able to accomplish a model version of that task. This cooperative ability has interesting implications for economic planning and a variety of other fields.Entropica is broadly applicable to a variety of domains. For example, here we see it successfully playing a game of pong against itself, illustrating its potential for gaming. Here we see Entropica orchestrating new connections on a social network where friends are constantly falling out of touch and successfully keeping the network well connected. This same network orchestration ability also has applications in health care, energy, and intelligence. Here we see Entropica directing the paths of a fleet of ships, successfully discovering and utilizing the Panama Canal to globally extend its reach from the Atlantic to the Pacific. By the same token, Entropica is broadly applicable to problems in autonomous defense, logistics and transportation.Finally, here we see Entropica spontaneously discovering and executing a buy-low, sell-high strategy on a simulated range traded stock, successfully growing assets under management exponentially. This risk management ability will have broad applications in finance and insurance.Alex Wissner-Gross: So what you've just seen is that a variety of signature human intelligent cognitive behaviors such as tool use and walking upright and social cooperation all follow from a single equation, which drives a system to maximize its future freedom of action.Now, there's a profound irony here. Going back to the beginning of the usage of the term robot, the play "RUR," there was always a concept that if we developed machine intelligence, there would be a cybernetic revolt. The machines would rise up against us. One major consequence of this work is that maybe all of these decades, we've had the whole concept of cybernetic revolt in reverse. It's not that machines first become intelligent and then megalomaniacal and try to take over the world. It's quite the opposite, that the urge to take control of all possible futures is a more fundamental principle than that of intelligence, that general intelligence may in fact emerge directly from this sort of control-grabbing, rather than vice versa.Another important consequence is goal seeking. I'm often asked, how does the ability to seek goals follow from this sort of framework? And the answer is, the ability to seek goals will follow directly from this in the following sense: just like you would travel through a tunnel, a bottleneck in your future path space, in order to achieve many other diverse objectives later on, or just like you would invest in a financial security, reducing your short-term liquidity in order to increase your wealth over the long term, goal seeking emerges directly from a long-term drive to increase future freedom of action.Finally, Richard Feynman, famous physicist, once wrote that if human civilization were destroyed and you could pass only a single concept on to our descendants to help them rebuild civilization, that concept should be that all matter around us is made out of tiny elements that attract each other when they're far apart but repel each other when they're close together. My equivalent of that statement to pass on to descendants to help them build artificial intelligences or to help them understand human intelligence, is the following: Intelligence should be viewed as a physical process that tries to maximize future freedom of action and avoid constraints in its own future.Thank you very much.(Applause)

00:00:54.821 --> 00:00:56.700
that enabled us to build

00:00:56.700 --> 00:00:58.934
artificial machines that swim

00:00:58.934 --> 00:01:01.507
and artificial machines that [fly],

00:01:01.507 --> 00:01:05.054
you find that it was only through understanding

00:01:05.054 --> 00:01:07.662
the underlying physical mechanisms

00:01:07.662 --> 00:01:10.441
of swimming and flight

00:01:10.441 --> 00:01:13.613
that we were able to build these machines.

00:01:13.613 --> 00:01:15.869
And so, several years ago,

00:01:15.869 --> 00:01:19.118
I undertook a program to try to understand

00:01:19.118 --> 00:01:21.752
the fundamental physical mechanisms

00:01:21.752 --> 00:01:24.520
underlying intelligence.

00:01:24.520 --> 00:01:26.380
Let's take a step back.

00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:29.529
Let's first begin with a thought experiment.

00:01:29.529 --> 00:01:32.383
Pretend that you're an alien race

00:01:32.383 --> 00:01:35.424
that doesn't know anything about Earth biology

00:01:35.424 --> 00:01:38.540
or Earth neuroscience or Earth intelligence,

00:01:38.540 --> 00:01:40.732
but you have amazing telescopes

00:01:40.732 --> 00:01:43.094
and you're able to watch the Earth,

00:01:43.094 --> 00:01:45.426
and you have amazingly long lives,

00:01:45.426 --> 00:01:46.925
so you're able to watch the Earth

00:01:46.925 --> 00:01:50.367
over millions, even billions of years.

00:01:50.367 --> 00:01:53.382
And you observe a really strange effect.

00:01:53.382 --> 00:01:57.694
You observe that, over the course of the millennia,

00:01:57.694 --> 00:02:01.979
Earth is continually bombarded with asteroids

00:02:01.979 --> 00:02:04.066
up until a point,

00:02:04.066 --> 00:02:05.597
and that at some point,

00:02:05.597 --> 00:02:09.789
corresponding roughly to our year, 2000 AD,

00:02:09.789 --> 00:02:11.505
asteroids that are on

00:02:11.505 --> 00:02:13.436
a collision course with the Earth

00:02:13.436 --> 00:02:15.411
that otherwise would have collided

00:02:15.411 --> 00:02:17.826
mysteriously get deflected

00:02:17.826 --> 00:02:20.898
or they detonate before they can hit the Earth.

00:02:20.898 --> 00:02:22.981
Now of course, as earthlings,

00:02:22.981 --> 00:02:24.525
we know the reason would be

00:02:24.525 --> 00:02:26.281
that we're trying to save ourselves.

00:02:26.281 --> 00:02:29.361
We're trying to prevent an impact.

00:02:29.361 --> 00:02:31.072
But if you're an alien race

00:02:31.072 --> 00:02:32.218
who doesn't know any of this,

00:02:32.218 --> 00:02:34.732
doesn't have any concept of Earth intelligence,

00:02:34.732 --> 00:02:36.460
you'd be forced to put together

00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:39.378
a physical theory that explains how,

00:02:39.378 --> 00:02:41.916
up until a certain point in time,

00:02:41.916 --> 00:02:46.365
asteroids that would demolish the surface of a planet

00:02:46.365 --> 00:02:49.596
mysteriously stop doing that.

00:02:49.596 --> 00:02:53.800
And so I claim that this is the same question

00:02:53.800 --> 00:02:57.798
as understanding the physical nature of intelligence.

00:02:57.798 --> 00:03:01.680
So in this program that I
undertook several years ago,

00:03:01.680 --> 00:03:04.445
I looked at a variety of different threads

00:03:04.445 --> 00:03:07.607
across science, across a variety of disciplines,

00:03:07.607 --> 00:03:09.499
that were pointing, I think,

00:03:09.499 --> 00:03:12.047
towards a single, underlying mechanism

00:03:12.047 --> 00:03:13.628
for intelligence.

00:03:13.628 --> 00:03:16.174
In cosmology, for example,

00:03:16.174 --> 00:03:18.921
there have been a variety of
different threads of evidence

00:03:18.921 --> 00:03:22.328
that our universe appears to be finely tuned

00:03:22.328 --> 00:03:24.481
for the development of intelligence,

00:03:24.481 --> 00:03:26.870
and, in particular, for the development

00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:28.756
of universal states

00:03:28.756 --> 00:03:32.854
that maximize the diversity of possible futures.

00:03:32.854 --> 00:03:35.198
In game play, for example, in Go --

00:03:35.198 --> 00:03:38.223
everyone remembers in 1997

00:03:38.223 --> 00:03:42.174
when IBM's Deep Blue beat 
Garry Kasparov at chess --

00:03:42.174 --> 00:03:43.697
fewer people are aware

00:03:43.697 --> 00:03:45.715
that in the past 10 years or so,

00:03:45.715 --> 00:03:46.913
the game of Go,

00:03:46.913 --> 00:03:48.869
arguably a much more challenging game

00:03:48.869 --> 00:03:51.294
because it has a much higher branching factor,

00:03:51.294 --> 00:03:52.996
has also started to succumb

00:03:52.996 --> 00:03:54.861
to computer game players

00:03:54.861 --> 00:03:56.434
for the same reason:

00:03:56.434 --> 00:03:59.234
the best techniques right now
for computers playing Go

00:03:59.234 --> 00:04:02.930
are techniques that try to maximize future options

00:04:02.930 --> 00:04:04.944
during game play.

00:04:04.944 --> 00:04:08.525
Finally, in robotic motion planning,

00:04:08.525 --> 00:04:10.707
there have been a variety of recent techniques

00:04:10.707 --> 00:04:12.609
that have tried to take advantage

00:04:12.609 --> 00:04:15.755
of abilities of robots to maximize

00:04:15.755 --> 00:04:17.261
future freedom of action

00:04:17.261 --> 00:04:20.358
in order to accomplish complex tasks.

00:04:20.358 --> 00:04:22.713
And so, taking all of these different threads

00:04:22.713 --> 00:04:24.335
and putting them together,

00:04:24.335 --> 00:04:26.975
I asked, starting several years ago,

00:04:26.975 --> 00:04:29.825
is there an underlying mechanism for intelligence

00:04:29.825 --> 00:04:31.498
that we can factor out

00:04:31.498 --> 00:04:33.272
of all of these different threads?

00:04:33.272 --> 00:04:37.865
Is there a single equation for intelligence?

00:04:37.865 --> 00:04:41.236
And the answer, I believe, is yes.
["F = T ∇ Sτ"]

00:04:41.236 --> 00:04:43.149
What you're seeing is probably

00:04:43.149 --> 00:04:46.443
the closest equivalent to an E = mc²

00:04:46.443 --> 00:04:49.273
for intelligence that I've seen.

00:04:49.273 --> 00:04:50.975
So what you're seeing here

00:04:50.975 --> 00:04:53.644
is a statement of correspondence

00:04:53.644 --> 00:04:58.079
that intelligence is a force, F,

00:04:58.079 --> 00:05:02.729
that acts so as to maximize future freedom of action.

00:05:02.729 --> 00:05:05.104
It acts to maximize future freedom of action,

00:05:05.104 --> 00:05:06.732
or keep options open,

00:05:06.732 --> 00:05:08.957
with some strength T,

00:05:08.957 --> 00:05:13.734
with the diversity of possible accessible futures, S,

00:05:13.734 --> 00:05:16.284
up to some future time horizon, tau.

00:05:16.284 --> 00:05:19.493
In short, intelligence doesn't like to get trapped.

00:05:19.493 --> 00:05:22.548
Intelligence tries to maximize
future freedom of action

00:05:22.548 --> 00:05:25.221
and keep options open.

00:05:25.221 --> 00:05:27.654
And so, given this one equation,

00:05:27.654 --> 00:05:30.186
it's natural to ask, so what can you do with this?

00:05:30.186 --> 00:05:31.537
How predictive is it?

00:05:31.537 --> 00:05:33.672
Does it predict human-level intelligence?

00:05:33.672 --> 00:05:36.490
Does it predict artificial intelligence?

00:05:36.490 --> 00:05:38.532
So I'm going to show you now a video

00:05:38.532 --> 00:05:41.952
that will, I think, demonstrate

00:05:41.952 --> 00:05:44.240
some of the amazing applications

00:05:44.240 --> 00:05:46.559
of just this single equation.

00:05:46.559 --> 00:05:48.538
(Video) Narrator: Recent research in cosmology

00:05:48.538 --> 00:05:50.585
has suggested that universes that produce

00:05:50.585 --> 00:05:54.066
more disorder, or "entropy," over their lifetimes

00:05:54.066 --> 00:05:56.544
should tend to have more favorable conditions

00:05:56.544 --> 00:05:59.560
for the existence of intelligent
beings such as ourselves.

00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:02.134
But what if that tentative cosmological connection

00:06:02.134 --> 00:06:03.977
between entropy and intelligence

00:06:03.977 --> 00:06:05.748
hints at a deeper relationship?

00:06:05.748 --> 00:06:08.312
What if intelligent behavior doesn't just correlate

00:06:08.312 --> 00:06:10.156
with the production of long-term entropy,

00:06:10.156 --> 00:06:12.474
but actually emerges directly from it?

00:06:12.474 --> 00:06:14.880
To find out, we developed a software engine

00:06:14.880 --> 00:06:17.383
called Entropica, designed to maximize

00:06:17.383 --> 00:06:19.151
the production of long-term entropy

00:06:19.151 --> 00:06:21.727
of any system that it finds itself in.

00:06:21.727 --> 00:06:23.882
Amazingly, Entropica was able to pass

00:06:23.882 --> 00:06:27.338
multiple animal intelligence
tests, play human games,

00:06:27.338 --> 00:06:29.484
and even earn money trading stocks,

00:06:29.484 --> 00:06:31.595
all without being instructed to do so.

00:06:31.595 --> 00:06:34.113
Here are some examples of Entropica in action.

00:06:34.113 --> 00:06:37.318
Just like a human standing
upright without falling over,

00:06:37.318 --> 00:06:38.548
here we see Entropica

00:06:38.548 --> 00:06:41.433
automatically balancing a pole using a cart.

00:06:41.433 --> 00:06:43.445
This behavior is remarkable in part

00:06:43.445 --> 00:06:45.776
because we never gave Entropica a goal.

00:06:45.776 --> 00:06:48.933
It simply decided on its own to balance the pole.

00:06:48.933 --> 00:06:51.065
This balancing ability will have appliactions

00:06:51.065 --> 00:06:52.462
for humanoid robotics

00:06:52.462 --> 00:06:54.977
and human assistive technologies.

00:06:54.977 --> 00:06:56.978
Just as some animals can use objects

00:06:56.978 --> 00:06:58.420
in their environments as tools

00:06:58.420 --> 00:07:00.407
to reach into narrow spaces,

00:07:00.407 --> 00:07:02.289
here we see that Entropica,

00:07:02.289 --> 00:07:04.127
again on its own initiative,

00:07:04.127 --> 00:07:07.037
was able to move a large
disk representing an animal

00:07:07.037 --> 00:07:09.382
around so as to cause a small disk,

00:07:09.382 --> 00:07:12.153
representing a tool, to reach into a confined space

00:07:12.153 --> 00:07:13.690
holding a third disk

00:07:13.690 --> 00:07:16.662
and release the third disk
from its initially fixed position.

00:07:16.662 --> 00:07:18.851
This tool use ability will have applications

00:07:18.851 --> 00:07:21.210
for smart manufacturing and agriculture.

00:07:21.210 --> 00:07:23.154
In addition, just as some other animals

00:07:23.154 --> 00:07:25.850
are able to cooperate by pulling
opposite ends of a rope

00:07:25.850 --> 00:07:27.903
at the same time to release food,

00:07:27.903 --> 00:07:30.198
here we see that Entropica is able to accomplish

00:07:30.198 --> 00:07:32.186
a model version of that task.

00:07:32.186 --> 00:07:34.708
This cooperative ability has interesting implications

00:07:34.708 --> 00:07:38.143
for economic planning and a variety of other fields.

00:07:38.143 --> 00:07:40.214
Entropica is broadly applicable

00:07:40.214 --> 00:07:42.157
to a variety of domains.

00:07:42.157 --> 00:07:44.599
For example, here we see it successfully

00:07:44.599 --> 00:07:47.158
playing a game of pong against itself,

00:07:47.158 --> 00:07:49.501
illustrating its potential for gaming.

00:07:49.501 --> 00:07:51.420
Here we see Entropica orchestrating

00:07:51.420 --> 00:07:53.259
new connections on a social network

00:07:53.259 --> 00:07:56.019
where friends are constantly falling out of touch

00:07:56.019 --> 00:07:58.875
and successfully keeping
the network well connected.

00:07:58.875 --> 00:08:01.173
This same network orchestration ability

00:08:01.173 --> 00:08:03.501
also has applications in health care,

00:08:03.501 --> 00:08:06.733
energy, and intelligence.

00:08:06.733 --> 00:08:08.818
Here we see Entropica directing the paths

00:08:08.818 --> 00:08:10.304
of a fleet of ships,

00:08:10.304 --> 00:08:13.479
successfully discovering and
utilizing the Panama Canal

00:08:13.479 --> 00:08:15.937
to globally extend its reach from the Atlantic

00:08:15.937 --> 00:08:17.466
to the Pacific.

00:08:17.466 --> 00:08:19.193
By the same token, Entropica

00:08:19.193 --> 00:08:20.813
is broadly applicable to problems

00:08:20.813 --> 00:08:26.115
in autonomous defense, logistics and transportation.

00:08:26.131 --> 00:08:28.161
Finally, here we see Entropica

00:08:28.161 --> 00:08:30.884
spontaneously discovering and executing

00:08:30.884 --> 00:08:32.951
a buy-low, sell-high strategy

00:08:32.951 --> 00:08:35.129
on a simulated range traded stock,

00:08:35.129 --> 00:08:37.460
successfully growing assets under management

00:08:37.460 --> 00:08:38.884
exponentially.

00:08:38.884 --> 00:08:40.192
This risk management ability

00:08:40.192 --> 00:08:42.679
will have broad applications in finance

00:08:42.679 --> 00:08:46.007
and insurance.

00:08:46.007 --> 00:08:48.098
Alex Wissner-Gross: So what you've just seen

00:08:48.098 --> 00:08:52.490
is that a variety of signature human intelligent

00:08:52.490 --> 00:08:54.247
cognitive behaviors

00:08:54.247 --> 00:08:57.078
such as tool use and walking upright

00:08:57.078 --> 00:08:59.107
and social cooperation

00:08:59.107 --> 00:09:02.079
all follow from a single equation,

00:09:02.079 --> 00:09:04.011
which drives a system

00:09:04.011 --> 00:09:07.922
to maximize its future freedom of action.

00:09:07.922 --> 00:09:10.929
Now, there's a profound irony here.

00:09:10.929 --> 00:09:12.953
Going back to the beginning

00:09:12.953 --> 00:09:16.226
of the usage of the term robot,

00:09:16.226 --> 00:09:19.129
the play "RUR,"

00:09:19.129 --> 00:09:21.364
there was always a concept

00:09:21.364 --> 00:09:24.590
that if we developed machine intelligence,

00:09:24.590 --> 00:09:27.617
there would be a cybernetic revolt.

00:09:27.617 --> 00:09:31.168
The machines would rise up against us.

00:09:31.168 --> 00:09:33.487
One major consequence of this work

00:09:33.487 --> 00:09:36.256
is that maybe all of these decades,

00:09:36.256 --> 00:09:39.232
we've had the whole concept of cybernetic revolt

00:09:39.232 --> 00:09:41.243
in reverse.

00:09:41.243 --> 00:09:44.522
It's not that machines first become intelligent

00:09:44.522 --> 00:09:46.537
and then megalomaniacal

00:09:46.537 --> 00:09:48.761
and try to take over the world.

00:09:48.761 --> 00:09:50.195
It's quite the opposite,

00:09:50.195 --> 00:09:53.101
that the urge to take control

00:09:53.101 --> 00:09:55.362
of all possible futures

00:09:55.362 --> 00:09:57.480
is a more fundamental principle

00:09:57.480 --> 00:09:58.843
than that of intelligence,

00:09:58.843 --> 00:10:02.543
that general intelligence may in fact emerge

00:10:02.543 --> 00:10:06.102
directly from this sort of control-grabbing,

00:10:06.102 --> 00:10:10.287
rather than vice versa.

00:10:10.287 --> 00:10:14.056
Another important consequence is goal seeking.

00:10:14.056 --> 00:10:18.416
I'm often asked, how does the ability to seek goals

00:10:18.416 --> 00:10:20.036
follow from this sort of framework?

00:10:20.036 --> 00:10:23.064
And the answer is, the ability to seek goals

00:10:23.064 --> 00:10:24.946
will follow directly from this

00:10:24.946 --> 00:10:26.780
in the following sense:

00:10:26.780 --> 00:10:29.645
just like you would travel through a tunnel,

00:10:29.645 --> 00:10:32.150
a bottleneck in your future path space,

00:10:32.150 --> 00:10:34.021
in order to achieve many other

00:10:34.021 --> 00:10:36.042
diverse objectives later on,

00:10:36.042 --> 00:10:38.414
or just like you would invest

00:10:38.414 --> 00:10:40.201
in a financial security,

00:10:40.201 --> 00:10:42.438
reducing your short-term liquidity

00:10:42.438 --> 00:10:44.838
in order to increase your wealth over the long term,

00:10:44.838 --> 00:10:47.175
goal seeking emerges directly

00:10:47.175 --> 00:10:48.904
from a long-term drive

00:10:48.904 --> 00:10:52.941
to increase future freedom of action.

00:10:52.941 --> 00:10:56.469
Finally, Richard Feynman, famous physicist,

00:10:56.469 --> 00:11:00.141
once wrote that if human civilization were destroyed

00:11:00.141 --> 00:11:02.034
and you could pass only a single concept

00:11:02.034 --> 00:11:03.405
on to our descendants

00:11:03.405 --> 00:11:05.712
to help them rebuild civilization,

00:11:05.712 --> 00:11:07.398
that concept should be

00:11:07.398 --> 00:11:09.250
that all matter around us

00:11:09.250 --> 00:11:11.573
is made out of tiny elements

00:11:11.573 --> 00:11:14.081
that attract each other when they're far apart

00:11:14.081 --> 00:11:17.411
but repel each other when they're close together.

00:11:17.411 --> 00:11:19.192
My equivalent of that statement

00:11:19.192 --> 00:11:20.460
to pass on to descendants

00:11:20.460 --> 00:11:23.172
to help them build artificial intelligences

00:11:23.172 --> 00:11:26.121
or to help them understand human intelligence,

00:11:26.121 --> 00:11:27.388
is the following:

00:11:27.388 --> 00:11:29.441
Intelligence should be viewed

00:11:29.441 --> 00:11:30.854
as a physical process

00:11:30.854 --> 00:11:33.819
that tries to maximize future freedom of action

00:11:33.819 --> 00:11:37.435
and avoid constraints in its own future.

00:11:37.435 --> 00:11:38.793
Thank you very much.

00:11:38.793 --> 00:11:42.793
(Applause)

title: Art that craves your attention
transcript: Hi. So today, I'd like to share some works in progress. Since we are still realizing these works, we are largely working within the realm of intuition and mystery, still. So I'm going to try and describe some of the experiences that we're looking for through each of the works.So the first work is called the Imperial Monochromes. A viewer sort of unsuspectingly walks into the room, and catches a glimpse of these panels in a messy composition on the wall. Within seconds, as if the panels have noticed the presence of the viewer, they appear to panic and sort of get into a strict symmetry. (Laughter) So this is the sketch of the two states. One is total chaos. The other is absolute order. And we were interested in seeing how little change it takes to move from one state to the other state. This also reminded us of two very different pictorial traditions. One is the altar tablets of the 15th century, and the other is about 100 years ago, Malevich's abstract compositions. So I'm just going to take you to a video. To give you a sense of scale, the largest panel is about two meters high. That's about this much.  And the smallest one is an A4. So a viewer enters the space, and they snap to attention. And after a while, if the viewer continues to remain in the space, the panels will sort of become immune to the presence of the viewer and become lax and autonomous again, until they sort of sense a presence in the room or a movement, when they will again snap to attention. (Laughter) So here it appears as if it's the viewer that's sort of instigating the sense of order among the panels, but it could also be the other way around, that the panels are so stuck within their preconditioned behaviors that they sort of thrust the viewer with the role of a tyrant.So this brings me to a quieter, small work called Handheld. The viewer sees a piece of paper that's mounted on the far end of the wall, but when you go closer, you see that it's a blank A4, or a letter-sized piece of paper, that's held on either side by two small hands that appear to be carved with a great deal of attention and care from a small block of wood. The viewer also sees that this entire sculpture is sort of moving very slightly, as if these two hands are trying to hold the paper very still for a long period of time, and somehow are not managing to. So this instability in the movement very closely resembles the unsteady nature of images seen through a handheld camera. So here I'm going to show you two tandem clips. One is through a still camera and the other is through a handheld camera. And you immediately see how the unsteady nature of the video suggests the presence of an observer and a subjective point of view. So we've just removed the camera and transferred that movement onto the panel. So here's a video. You have to imagine the other hand. It's not there yet. But to us, we're sort of trying to evoke a self-effacing gesture, as if there's a little person with outstretched arms behind this enormous piece of paper. That sort of likens it to the amount of strain to be at the service of the observer and present this piece of paper very delicately to the viewer in front of them.The next work is Decoy. This is a cardboard model, so the object is about as tall as I am. It has a rounded body, two arms, and a very tall, head-like antenna, and its sole purpose is to attract attention towards itself. So when a viewer passes by, it sort of tilts from side to side, and moves its arms more and more frantically as the person gets closer. So here is the first test scenario. You see the two movements integrated, and the object seems to be employing its entire being in this expression of desperation. But the idea is that once it's got the person's attention, it's no longer interested, and it looks for the next person whose attention to get. (Laughter) So this is the final fabricated body of the Decoy. It appears to be mass-manufactured like it came out of a factory like vacuum cleaners and washing machines. Because we are always working from a very personal space, we like how this consumer aesthetic sort of depersonalizes the object and gives us a bit of distance in its appearance, at least. And so to us this is a kind of sinister being which is trying to distract you from the things that actually need your attention, but it could also be a figure that needs a lot of help. The next work is an object, that's also a kind of sound instrument. In the shape of an amphitheater that's scaled to the size of an audience as perceived from somebody from the stage. So from where I'm standing, each of you appears to be this big, and the audience sort of takes the entire field of my vision. Seated in this audience are 996 small figures. They're mechanically enabled to clap of their own free will. This means that each of them can decide if and when they want to clap, how hard, for how long, how they want to be influenced by those around them or influence others, and if they want to contribute to innovation. So when the viewer steps in front of the audience, there will be a response. It could be a few claps or a strong applause, and then nothing happens until the viewer leaves the stage, and again the audience will respond. It could be anything from a few feeble claps from members in the audience, or it could be a very loud ovation. So to us, I think we're really looking at an audience as its own object or its own organism that's also got a sort of musical-like quality to it, an instrument. So the viewer can play it by eliciting quite complex and varied, nuanced musical or sound patterns, but cannot really provoke the audience into any particular kind of response. So there's a sense of judgment and capriciousness and uneasiness involved. It also has an alluring and trap-like quality to it. So here if you see we're quite excited about the image of the head splitting to form the two hands. So here's a small visual animation, as if the two sides of the brain are sort of clashing against each other to kind of make sense of the duality and the tension. And here is a prototype. So we can't wait to be engulfed by 996 of them.Okay, this is the last work. It's called the Framerunners. It comes out of the idea of a window. This is an actual window in our studio, and as you can see, it's made up of three different thicknesses of wooden sections. So we used the same window vocabulary to construct our own frame or grid that's suspended in the room and that can be viewed from two sides. This grid is inhabited by a tribe of small figures. They're also made up of three different sizes, as if to suggest a kind of perspective or landscape on the single plain. Each of these figures can also run backward and forward in the track and hide behind two adjacent tracks. So in contrast to this very tight grid, we wanted to give these figures a very comical and slapstick-like quality, as if a puppeteer has taken them and physically animated them down the path. So we like the idea of these figures sort of skipping along like they're oblivious and carefree and happy-go-lucky and content, until they sort of sense a movement from the viewer and they will hide behind the fastest wall. So to us, this work also presents its own contradiction. These figures are sort of entrapped within this very strong grid, which is like a prison, but also a fortress, because it allows them to be oblivious and naive and carefree and quite oblivious of the external world. So all these real life qualities that I talk about are sort of translated to a very specific technical configuration, and we were very lucky to collaborate with ETH Zurich to develop the first prototype. So you see they extracted the motion cogs from our animations and created a wiggle that integrated the head-bobbing movement and the back-and-forth movement. So it's really quite small. You can see it can fit into the palm of my hand. So imagine our excitement when we saw it really working in the studio, and here it is.(Laughter)Thank you.(Applause)
subtitle:
WEBVTT
