00:00:12.611 --> 00:00:15.911
Hi. So today, I'd like to share
some works in progress.

00:00:15.911 --> 00:00:18.128
Since we are still realizing these works,

00:00:18.128 --> 00:00:19.879
we are largely working within the realm

00:00:19.879 --> 00:00:21.984
of intuition and mystery, still.

00:00:21.984 --> 00:00:23.747
So I'm going to try and describe

00:00:23.747 --> 00:00:25.874
some of the experiences that we're looking for

00:00:25.874 --> 00:00:27.597
through each of the works.

00:00:27.597 --> 00:00:30.903
So the first work is called the Imperial Monochromes.

00:00:30.903 --> 00:00:33.898
A viewer sort of unsuspectingly walks into the room,

00:00:33.898 --> 00:00:36.290
and catches a glimpse of these panels

00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:38.465
in a messy composition on the wall.

00:00:38.465 --> 00:00:41.017
Within seconds, as if the panels have noticed

00:00:41.017 --> 00:00:42.642
the presence of the viewer,

00:00:42.642 --> 00:00:45.686
they appear to panic and sort of get into

00:00:45.686 --> 00:00:47.200
a strict symmetry.

00:00:47.200 --> 00:00:48.943
(Laughter)

00:00:48.943 --> 00:00:51.091
So this is the sketch of the two states.

00:00:51.091 --> 00:00:53.749
One is total chaos. The other is absolute order.

00:00:53.749 --> 00:00:56.100
And we were interested in seeing how little change

00:00:56.100 --> 00:00:59.756
it takes to move from one state to the other state.

00:00:59.756 --> 00:01:03.486
This also reminded us of two
very different pictorial traditions.

00:01:03.486 --> 00:01:06.039
One is the altar tablets of the 15th century,

00:01:06.039 --> 00:01:08.273
and the other is about 100 years ago,

00:01:08.273 --> 00:01:11.229
Malevich's abstract compositions.

00:01:11.229 --> 00:01:13.245
So I'm just going to take you to a video.

00:01:13.245 --> 00:01:14.618
To give you a sense of scale,

00:01:14.618 --> 00:01:16.833
the largest panel is about two meters high.

00:01:16.833 --> 00:01:19.651
That's about this much. 
And the smallest one is an A4.

00:01:19.651 --> 00:01:21.863
So a viewer enters the space,

00:01:21.863 --> 00:01:23.959
and they snap to attention.

00:01:23.959 --> 00:01:25.947
And after a while, if the viewer continues

00:01:25.947 --> 00:01:27.675
to remain in the space,

00:01:27.675 --> 00:01:29.663
the panels will sort of become immune

00:01:29.663 --> 00:01:31.376
to the presence of the viewer

00:01:31.376 --> 00:01:34.411
and become lax and autonomous again,

00:01:34.411 --> 00:01:37.786
until they sort of sense a presence
in the room or a movement,

00:01:37.786 --> 00:01:40.485
when they will again snap to attention.

00:01:40.485 --> 00:01:41.964
(Laughter)

00:01:41.964 --> 00:01:44.363
So here it appears as if it's the viewer

00:01:44.363 --> 00:01:47.608
that's sort of instigating the sense
of order among the panels,

00:01:47.608 --> 00:01:49.633
but it could also be the other way around,

00:01:49.633 --> 00:01:51.977
that the panels are so stuck within

00:01:51.977 --> 00:01:53.971
their preconditioned behaviors

00:01:53.971 --> 00:01:59.499
that they sort of thrust the
viewer with the role of a tyrant.

00:01:59.499 --> 00:02:01.997
So this brings me to a quieter, small work

00:02:01.997 --> 00:02:03.566
called Handheld.

00:02:03.566 --> 00:02:05.300
The viewer sees a piece of paper

00:02:05.300 --> 00:02:07.770
that's mounted on the far end of the wall,

00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:10.398
but when you go closer, you see that it's a blank

00:02:10.398 --> 00:02:12.670
A4, or a letter-sized piece of paper,

00:02:12.670 --> 00:02:13.987
that's held on either side

00:02:13.987 --> 00:02:15.928
by two small hands

00:02:15.928 --> 00:02:18.195
that appear to be carved with a great deal

00:02:18.195 --> 00:02:21.668
of attention and care from a small block of wood.

00:02:21.668 --> 00:02:24.664
The viewer also sees that this entire sculpture

00:02:24.664 --> 00:02:27.126
is sort of moving very slightly,

00:02:27.126 --> 00:02:28.987
as if these two hands are trying

00:02:28.987 --> 00:02:30.489
to hold the paper very still

00:02:30.489 --> 00:02:32.668
for a long period of time,

00:02:32.668 --> 00:02:35.603
and somehow are not managing to.

00:02:35.603 --> 00:02:37.576
So this instability in the movement

00:02:37.576 --> 00:02:41.094
very closely resembles the unsteady nature

00:02:41.094 --> 00:02:43.656
of images seen through a handheld camera.

00:02:43.656 --> 00:02:46.344
So here I'm going to show you two tandem clips.

00:02:46.344 --> 00:02:47.764
One is through a still camera

00:02:47.764 --> 00:02:49.842
and the other is through a handheld camera.

00:02:49.842 --> 00:02:52.443
And you immediately see how the unsteady nature

00:02:52.443 --> 00:02:55.487
of the video suggests the presence

00:02:55.502 --> 00:02:57.989
of an observer and a subjective point of view.

00:02:57.989 --> 00:02:59.818
So we've just removed the camera

00:02:59.818 --> 00:03:02.099
and transferred that movement onto the panel.

00:03:02.099 --> 00:03:03.616
So here's a video.

00:03:03.632 --> 00:03:06.071
You have to imagine the other hand.
It's not there yet.

00:03:06.071 --> 00:03:08.818
But to us, we're sort of trying to evoke

00:03:08.818 --> 00:03:12.357
a self-effacing gesture, as if there's a little person

00:03:12.357 --> 00:03:13.948
with outstretched arms

00:03:13.948 --> 00:03:16.450
behind this enormous piece of paper.

00:03:16.450 --> 00:03:19.035
That sort of likens it to the amount of strain

00:03:19.035 --> 00:03:21.339
to be at the service of the observer and present

00:03:21.339 --> 00:03:24.589
this piece of paper very delicately to the viewer

00:03:24.589 --> 00:03:27.352
in front of them.

00:03:27.352 --> 00:03:29.512
The next work is Decoy.

00:03:29.512 --> 00:03:31.300
This is a cardboard model, so the object

00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:33.204
is about as tall as I am.

00:03:33.204 --> 00:03:35.093
It has a rounded body, two arms,

00:03:35.093 --> 00:03:37.304
and a very tall, head-like antenna,

00:03:37.304 --> 00:03:41.201
and its sole purpose is to
attract attention towards itself.

00:03:41.201 --> 00:03:42.987
So when a viewer passes by,

00:03:42.987 --> 00:03:45.802
it sort of tilts from side to side,

00:03:45.802 --> 00:03:47.975
and moves its arms more and more frantically

00:03:47.975 --> 00:03:51.342
as the person gets closer.

00:03:51.342 --> 00:03:53.866
So here is the first test scenario.

00:03:53.866 --> 00:03:55.755
You see the two movements integrated,

00:03:55.755 --> 00:03:57.744
and the object seems to be employing

00:03:57.744 --> 00:04:02.816
its entire being in this expression of desperation.

00:04:02.816 --> 00:04:05.480
But the idea is that once it's
got the person's attention,

00:04:05.480 --> 00:04:09.552
it's no longer interested, and it looks for the next person whose attention to get.

00:04:09.552 --> 00:04:12.666
(Laughter)

00:04:12.666 --> 00:04:15.698
So this is the final fabricated body of the Decoy.

00:04:15.698 --> 00:04:17.815
It appears to be mass-manufactured

00:04:17.815 --> 00:04:19.517
like it came out of a factory

00:04:19.517 --> 00:04:21.794
like vacuum cleaners and washing machines.

00:04:21.794 --> 00:04:23.297
Because we are always working

00:04:23.297 --> 00:04:24.705
from a very personal space,

00:04:24.705 --> 00:04:27.132
we like how this consumer aesthetic

00:04:27.132 --> 00:04:29.204
sort of depersonalizes the object

00:04:29.204 --> 00:04:30.935
and gives us a bit of distance

00:04:30.935 --> 00:04:32.855
in its appearance, at least.

00:04:32.855 --> 00:04:35.195
And so to us this is a kind of sinister being

00:04:35.195 --> 00:04:37.314
which is trying to distract you from the things

00:04:37.314 --> 00:04:38.909
that actually need your attention,

00:04:38.909 --> 00:04:43.659
but it could also be a figure that needs a lot of help.

00:04:43.683 --> 00:04:45.855
The next work is an object,

00:04:45.855 --> 00:04:48.279
that's also a kind of sound instrument.

00:04:48.279 --> 00:04:50.066
In the shape of an amphitheater

00:04:50.066 --> 00:04:52.006
that's scaled to the size of an audience

00:04:52.006 --> 00:04:54.072
as perceived from somebody from the stage.

00:04:54.072 --> 00:04:55.686
So from where I'm standing,

00:04:55.686 --> 00:04:57.348
each of you appears to be this big,

00:04:57.348 --> 00:04:59.401
and the audience sort of takes the entire

00:04:59.401 --> 00:05:01.414
field of my vision.

00:05:01.414 --> 00:05:05.376
Seated in this audience are 996 small figures.

00:05:05.376 --> 00:05:07.562
They're mechanically enabled to clap

00:05:07.562 --> 00:05:09.332
of their own free will.

00:05:09.332 --> 00:05:11.365
This means that each of them can decide

00:05:11.365 --> 00:05:12.945
if and when they want to clap,

00:05:12.945 --> 00:05:14.577
how hard, for how long,

00:05:14.577 --> 00:05:18.264
how they want to be influenced by
those around them or influence others,

00:05:18.264 --> 00:05:22.244
and if they want to contribute to innovation.

00:05:22.244 --> 00:05:24.761
So when the viewer steps in front of the audience,

00:05:24.761 --> 00:05:26.445
there will be a response.

00:05:26.445 --> 00:05:29.043
It could be a few claps or a strong applause,

00:05:29.043 --> 00:05:31.227
and then nothing happens until the viewer

00:05:31.227 --> 00:05:34.303
leaves the stage, and again
the audience will respond.

00:05:34.303 --> 00:05:36.628
It could be anything from a few feeble claps

00:05:36.628 --> 00:05:38.310
from members in the audience,

00:05:38.310 --> 00:05:42.638
or it could be a very loud ovation.

00:05:42.638 --> 00:05:44.600
So to us, I think we're really looking

00:05:44.600 --> 00:05:46.897
at an audience as its own object

00:05:46.897 --> 00:05:48.613
or its own organism

00:05:48.613 --> 00:05:52.363
that's also got a sort of musical-like quality to it,

00:05:52.363 --> 00:05:53.743
an instrument.

00:05:53.743 --> 00:05:55.499
So the viewer can play it

00:05:55.499 --> 00:05:57.935
by eliciting quite complex and varied,

00:05:57.935 --> 00:06:00.631
nuanced musical or sound patterns,

00:06:00.631 --> 00:06:02.907
but cannot really provoke the audience

00:06:02.907 --> 00:06:05.295
into any particular kind of response.

00:06:05.295 --> 00:06:08.039
So there's a sense of judgment and capriciousness

00:06:08.039 --> 00:06:10.280
and uneasiness involved.

00:06:10.280 --> 00:06:14.389
It also has an alluring and trap-like quality to it.

00:06:14.389 --> 00:06:16.509
So here if you see we're quite excited about

00:06:16.509 --> 00:06:20.331
the image of the head splitting
to form the two hands.

00:06:20.331 --> 00:06:22.242
So here's a small visual animation,

00:06:22.242 --> 00:06:26.574
as if the two sides of the brain are sort of clashing

00:06:26.574 --> 00:06:28.601
against each other to kind of make sense

00:06:28.601 --> 00:06:31.136
of the duality and the tension.

00:06:31.136 --> 00:06:33.704
And here is a prototype.

00:06:33.704 --> 00:06:38.506
So we can't wait to be engulfed by 996 of them.

00:06:38.506 --> 00:06:41.509
Okay, this is the last work.
It's called the Framerunners.

00:06:41.509 --> 00:06:44.028
It comes out of the idea of a window.

00:06:44.028 --> 00:06:46.339
This is an actual window in our studio,

00:06:46.339 --> 00:06:48.257
and as you can see, it's made up of three

00:06:48.257 --> 00:06:50.539
different thicknesses of wooden sections.

00:06:50.539 --> 00:06:52.812
So we used the same window vocabulary

00:06:52.812 --> 00:06:55.639
to construct our own frame or grid

00:06:55.639 --> 00:06:57.581
that's suspended in the room and that can

00:06:57.581 --> 00:06:59.394
be viewed from two sides.

00:06:59.394 --> 00:07:02.368
This grid is inhabited by a tribe of small figures.

00:07:02.368 --> 00:07:04.933
They're also made up of three different sizes,

00:07:04.933 --> 00:07:07.359
as if to suggest a kind of perspective

00:07:07.359 --> 00:07:10.070
or landscape on the single plain.

00:07:10.070 --> 00:07:12.515
Each of these figures can also run backward

00:07:12.515 --> 00:07:14.080
and forward in the track

00:07:14.080 --> 00:07:17.637
and hide behind two adjacent tracks.

00:07:17.637 --> 00:07:19.747
So in contrast to this very tight grid,

00:07:19.747 --> 00:07:22.168
we wanted to give these figures a very comical

00:07:22.168 --> 00:07:24.257
and slapstick-like quality,

00:07:24.257 --> 00:07:26.096
as if a puppeteer has taken them

00:07:26.096 --> 00:07:28.837
and physically animated them down the path.

00:07:28.837 --> 00:07:31.117
So we like the idea of these figures

00:07:31.117 --> 00:07:32.653
sort of skipping along

00:07:32.653 --> 00:07:34.741
like they're oblivious and carefree

00:07:34.741 --> 00:07:37.289
and happy-go-lucky and content,

00:07:37.289 --> 00:07:40.489
until they sort of sense a movement from the viewer

00:07:40.489 --> 00:07:44.757
and they will hide behind the fastest wall.

00:07:44.757 --> 00:07:48.591
So to us, this work also presents
its own contradiction.

00:07:48.591 --> 00:07:50.415
These figures are sort of entrapped

00:07:50.415 --> 00:07:52.562
within this very strong grid,

00:07:52.562 --> 00:07:55.318
which is like a prison, but also a fortress,

00:07:55.318 --> 00:07:57.252
because it allows them to be oblivious

00:07:57.252 --> 00:07:59.957
and naive and carefree and quite oblivious

00:07:59.957 --> 00:08:02.526
of the external world.

00:08:02.526 --> 00:08:05.331
So all these real life qualities that I talk about

00:08:05.331 --> 00:08:07.613
are sort of translated to a very specific

00:08:07.613 --> 00:08:09.374
technical configuration,

00:08:09.374 --> 00:08:11.417
and we were very lucky to collaborate

00:08:11.417 --> 00:08:14.585
with ETH Zurich to develop the first prototype.

00:08:14.585 --> 00:08:16.850
So you see they extracted the motion cogs

00:08:16.850 --> 00:08:18.940
from our animations and created a wiggle

00:08:18.940 --> 00:08:20.894
that integrated the head-bobbing movement

00:08:20.894 --> 00:08:22.662
and the back-and-forth movement.

00:08:22.662 --> 00:08:24.184
So it's really quite small.

00:08:24.184 --> 00:08:26.476
You can see it can fit into the palm of my hand.

00:08:26.476 --> 00:08:28.287
So imagine our excitement when we saw it

00:08:28.287 --> 00:08:31.452
really working in the studio, and here it is.

00:08:33.580 --> 00:08:37.217
(Laughter)

00:08:37.217 --> 00:08:38.765
Thank you.

00:08:38.765 --> 00:08:48.748
(Applause)

title: Does the media have a "duty of care"?
transcript: I'd like to start, if I may, with the story of the Paisley snail. On the evening of the 26th of August, 1928, May Donoghue took a train from Glasgow to the town of Paisley, seven miles east of the city, and there at the Wellmeadow Café, she had a Scots ice cream float, a mix of ice cream and ginger beer bought for her by a friend. The ginger beer came in a brown, opaque bottle labeled "D. Stevenson, Glen Lane, Paisley." She drank some of the ice cream float, but as the remaining ginger beer was poured into her tumbler, a decomposed snail floated to the surface of her glass. Three days later, she was admitted to the Glasgow Royal Infirmary and diagnosed with severe gastroenteritis and shock.The case of Donoghue vs. Stevenson that followed set a very important legal precedent: Stevenson, the manufacturer of the ginger beer, was held to have a clear duty of care towards May Donoghue, even though there was no contract between them, and, indeed, she hadn't even bought the drink. One of the judges, Lord Atkin, described it like this: You must take care to avoid acts or omissions which you can reasonably foresee would be likely to injure your neighbor. Indeed, one wonders that without a duty of care, how many people would have had to suffer from gastroenteritis before Stevenson eventually went out of business.Now please hang on to that Paisley snail story, because it's an important principle. Last year, the Hansard Society, a nonpartisan charity which seeks to strengthen parliamentary democracy and encourage greater public involvement in politics published, alongside their annual audit of political engagement, an additional section devoted entirely to politics and the media. Here are a couple of rather depressing observations from that survey. Tabloid newspapers do not appear to advance the political citizenship of their readers, relative even to those who read no newspapers whatsoever. Tabloid-only readers are twice as likely to agree with a negative view of politics than readers of no newspapers. They're not just less politically engaged. They are consuming media that reinforces their negative evaluation of politics, thereby contributing to a fatalistic and cynical attitude to democracy and their own role within it. Little wonder that the report concluded that in this respect, the press, particularly the tabloids, appear not to be living up to the importance of their role in our democracy.Now I doubt if anyone in this room would seriously challenge that view. But if Hansard are right, and they usually are, then we've got a very serious problem on our hands, and it's one that I'd like to spend the next 10 minutes focusing upon.Since the Paisley snail, and especially over the past decade or so, a great deal of thinking has been developed around the notion of a duty of care as it relates to a number of aspects of civil society. Generally a duty of care arises when one individual or a group of individuals undertakes an activity which has the potential to cause harm to another, either physically, mentally or economically. This is principally focused on obvious areas, such as our empathetic response to children and young people, to our service personnel, and to the elderly and infirm. It is seldom, if ever, extended to equally important arguments around the fragility of our present system of government, to the notion that honesty, accuracy and impartiality are fundamental to the process of building and embedding an informed, participatory democracy. And the more you think about it, the stranger that is.A couple of years ago, I had the pleasure of opening a brand new school in the northeast of England. It had been renamed by its pupils as Academy 360. As I walked through their impressive, glass-covered atrium, in front of me, emblazoned on the wall in letters of fire was Marcus Aurelius's famous injunction: If it's not true, don't say it; if it's not right, don't do it. The head teacher saw me staring at it, and he said, "Oh, that's our school motto." On the train back to London, I couldn't get it out of my mind. I kept thinking, can it really have taken us over 2,000 years to come to terms with that simple notion as being our minimum expectation of each other? Isn't it time that we develop this concept of a duty of care and extended it to include a care for our shared but increasingly endangered democratic values? After all, the absence of a duty of care within many professions can all too easily amount to accusations of negligence, and that being the case, can we be really comfortable with the thought that we're in effect being negligent in respect of the health of our own societies and the values that necessarily underpin them? Could anyone honestly suggest, on the evidence, that the same media which Hansard so roundly condemned have taken sufficient care to avoid behaving in ways which they could reasonably have foreseen would be likely to undermine or even damage our inherently fragile democratic settlement.Now there will be those who will argue that this could all too easily drift into a form of censorship, albeit self-censorship, but I don't buy that argument. It has to be possible to balance freedom of expression with wider moral and social responsibilities.Let me explain why by taking the example from my own career as a filmmaker. Throughout that career, I never accepted that a filmmaker should set about putting their own work outside or above what he or she believed to be a decent set of values for their own life, their own family, and the future of the society in which we all live. I'd go further. A responsible filmmaker should never devalue their work to a point at which it becomes less than true to the world they themselves wish to inhabit. As I see it, filmmakers, journalists, even bloggers are all required to face up to the social expectations that come with combining the intrinsic power of their medium with their well-honed professional skills. Obviously this is not a mandated duty, but for the gifted filmmaker and the responsible journalist or even blogger, it strikes me as being utterly inescapable.We should always remember that our notion of individual freedom and its partner, creative freedom, is comparatively new in the history of Western ideas, and for that reason, it's often undervalued and can be very quickly undermined. It's a prize easily lost, and once lost, once surrendered, it can prove very, very hard to reclaim. And its first line of defense has to be our own standards, not those enforced on us by a censor or legislation, our own standards and our own integrity. Our integrity as we deal with those with whom we work and our own standards as we operate within society. And these standards of ours need to be all of a piece with a sustainable social agenda. They're part of a collective responsibility, the responsibility of the artist or the journalist to deal with the world as it really is, and this, in turn, must go hand in hand with the responsibility of those governing society to also face up to that world, and not to be tempted to misappropriate the causes of its ills. Yet, as has become strikingly clear over the last couple of years, such responsibility has to a very great extent been abrogated by large sections of the media. And as a consequence, across the Western world, the over-simplistic policies of the parties of protest and their appeal to a largely disillusioned, older demographic, along with the apathy and obsession with the trivial that typifies at least some of the young, taken together, these and other similarly contemporary aberrations are threatening to squeeze the life out of active, informed debate and engagement, and I stress active.The most ardent of libertarians might argue that Donoghue v. Stevenson should have been thrown out of court and that Stevenson would eventually have gone out of business if he'd continued to sell ginger beer with snails in it. But most of us, I think, accept some small role for the state to enforce a duty of care, and the key word here is reasonable. Judges must ask, did they take reasonable care and could they have reasonably foreseen the consequences of their actions? Politics is about choices, and within those choices, politics is about priorities. It's about reconciling conflicting preferences wherever and whenever possibly based on fact. But if the facts themselves are distorted, the resolutions are likely only to create further conflict, with all the stresses and strains on society that inevitably follow. Kennedy made two epoch-making speeches, the first on disarmament and the second on civil rights. subtitle:
WEBVTT
X-TIMESTAMP-MAP=MPEGTS:900000,LOCAL:00:00:00.000

00:00:12.830 --> 00:00:14.374
I'd like to start, if I may,

00:00:14.374 --> 00:00:17.098
with the story of the Paisley snail.

00:00:17.098 --> 00:00:20.313
On the evening of the 26th of August, 1928,

00:00:20.313 --> 00:00:22.687
May Donoghue took a train from Glasgow

00:00:22.687 --> 00:00:25.218
to the town of Paisley, seven miles east of the city,

00:00:25.218 --> 00:00:27.531
and there at the Wellmeadow Café,

00:00:27.531 --> 00:00:30.657
she had a Scots ice cream float,

00:00:30.657 --> 00:00:32.504
a mix of ice cream and ginger beer

00:00:32.504 --> 00:00:34.459
bought for her by a friend.

00:00:34.459 --> 00:00:36.860
The ginger beer came in a brown, opaque bottle

00:00:36.860 --> 00:00:40.723
labeled "D. Stevenson, Glen Lane, Paisley."

00:00:40.723 --> 00:00:42.799
She drank some of the ice cream float,

00:00:42.799 --> 00:00:44.633
but as the remaining ginger beer was poured

00:00:44.633 --> 00:00:46.029
into her tumbler,

00:00:46.029 --> 00:00:48.482
a decomposed snail

00:00:48.482 --> 00:00:51.064
floated to the surface of her glass.

00:00:51.064 --> 00:00:52.608
Three days later, she was admitted

00:00:52.608 --> 00:00:54.114
to the Glasgow Royal Infirmary

00:00:54.114 --> 00:00:56.172
and diagnosed with severe gastroenteritis

00:00:56.172 --> 00:00:58.125
and shock.

00:00:58.125 --> 00:01:01.393
The case of Donoghue vs. Stevenson that followed

00:01:01.393 --> 00:01:04.038
set a very important legal precedent:

00:01:04.038 --> 00:01:05.769
Stevenson, the manufacturer of the ginger beer,

00:01:05.769 --> 00:01:08.546
was held to have a clear duty of care

00:01:08.546 --> 00:01:09.994
towards May Donoghue,

00:01:09.994 --> 00:01:12.096
even though there was no contract between them,

00:01:12.096 --> 00:01:14.913
and, indeed, she hadn't even bought the drink.

00:01:14.913 --> 00:01:17.932
One of the judges, Lord Atkin, described it like this:

00:01:17.932 --> 00:01:20.842
You must take care to avoid acts or omissions

00:01:20.842 --> 00:01:22.910
which you can reasonably foresee

00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:26.138
would be likely to injure your neighbor.

00:01:26.138 --> 00:01:28.481
Indeed, one wonders that without a duty of care,

00:01:28.481 --> 00:01:30.227
how many people would have had to suffer

00:01:30.227 --> 00:01:33.951
from gastroenteritis before Stevenson
eventually went out of business.

00:01:33.951 --> 00:01:36.332
Now please hang on to that Paisley snail story,

00:01:36.332 --> 00:01:39.565
because it's an important principle.

00:01:39.565 --> 00:01:42.059
Last year, the Hansard Society,
a nonpartisan charity

00:01:42.059 --> 00:01:43.965
which seeks to strengthen parliamentary democracy

00:01:43.965 --> 00:01:47.202
and encourage greater public involvement in politics

00:01:47.202 --> 00:01:49.789
published, alongside their annual audit

00:01:49.789 --> 00:01:52.662
of political engagement, an additional section

00:01:52.662 --> 00:01:55.785
devoted entirely to politics and the media.

00:01:55.785 --> 00:01:58.160
Here are a couple of rather depressing observations

00:01:58.160 --> 00:02:00.168
from that survey.

00:02:00.168 --> 00:02:02.333
Tabloid newspapers do not appear

00:02:02.333 --> 00:02:05.166
to advance the political citizenship of their readers,

00:02:05.166 --> 00:02:06.739
relative even to those

00:02:06.739 --> 00:02:09.965
who read no newspapers whatsoever.

00:02:09.965 --> 00:02:12.957
Tabloid-only readers are twice as likely to agree

00:02:12.957 --> 00:02:14.808
with a negative view of politics

00:02:14.808 --> 00:02:17.383
than readers of no newspapers.

00:02:17.383 --> 00:02:19.376
They're not just less politically engaged.

00:02:19.376 --> 00:02:21.824
They are consuming media that reinforces

00:02:21.824 --> 00:02:23.786
their negative evaluation of politics,

00:02:23.786 --> 00:02:26.889
thereby contributing to a fatalistic and cynical

00:02:26.889 --> 00:02:30.224
attitude to democracy and their own role within it.

00:02:30.224 --> 00:02:32.384
Little wonder that the report concluded that

00:02:32.384 --> 00:02:35.574
in this respect, the press, particularly the tabloids,

00:02:35.574 --> 00:02:37.913
appear not to be living up to the importance

00:02:37.913 --> 00:02:40.549
of their role in our democracy.

00:02:40.549 --> 00:02:42.608
Now I doubt if anyone in this room would seriously

00:02:42.608 --> 00:02:44.055
challenge that view.

00:02:44.055 --> 00:02:46.671
But if Hansard are right, and they usually are,

00:02:46.671 --> 00:02:48.647
then we've got a very serious problem on our hands,

00:02:48.647 --> 00:02:51.282
and it's one that I'd like to spend the next 10 minutes

00:02:51.282 --> 00:02:53.311
focusing upon.

00:02:53.311 --> 00:02:54.994
Since the Paisley snail,

00:02:54.994 --> 00:02:57.458
and especially over the past decade or so,

00:02:57.458 --> 00:02:59.377
a great deal of thinking has been developed

00:02:59.377 --> 00:03:01.236
around the notion of a duty of care

00:03:01.236 --> 00:03:03.775
as it relates to a number of aspects of civil society.

00:03:03.775 --> 00:03:06.519
Generally a duty of care arises when one individual

00:03:06.519 --> 00:03:09.253
or a group of individuals undertakes an activity

00:03:09.253 --> 00:03:11.783
which has the potential to cause harm to another,

00:03:11.783 --> 00:03:14.497
either physically, mentally or economically.

00:03:14.497 --> 00:03:16.968
This is principally focused on obvious areas,

00:03:16.968 --> 00:03:20.010
such as our empathetic response
to children and young people,

00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:22.736
to our service personnel, and
to the elderly and infirm.

00:03:22.736 --> 00:03:26.929
It is seldom, if ever, extended
to equally important arguments

00:03:26.929 --> 00:03:31.179
around the fragility of our
present system of government,

00:03:31.179 --> 00:03:34.688
to the notion that honesty, accuracy and impartiality

00:03:34.688 --> 00:03:36.832
are fundamental to the process of building

00:03:36.832 --> 00:03:38.561
and embedding an informed,

00:03:38.561 --> 00:03:41.318
participatory democracy.

00:03:41.318 --> 00:03:42.739
And the more you think about it,

00:03:42.739 --> 00:03:44.570
the stranger that is.

00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:46.032
A couple of years ago, I had the pleasure

00:03:46.032 --> 00:03:47.786
of opening a brand new school

00:03:47.786 --> 00:03:49.357
in the northeast of England.

00:03:49.357 --> 00:03:52.896
It had been renamed by its pupils as Academy 360.

00:03:52.896 --> 00:03:54.748
As I walked through their impressive,

00:03:54.748 --> 00:03:56.123
glass-covered atrium,

00:03:56.123 --> 00:03:57.941
in front of me, emblazoned on the wall

00:03:57.941 --> 00:03:59.489
in letters of fire

00:03:59.489 --> 00:04:02.590
was Marcus Aurelius's famous injunction:

00:04:02.590 --> 00:04:05.445
If it's not true, don't say it;

00:04:05.445 --> 00:04:08.528
if it's not right, don't do it.

00:04:08.528 --> 00:04:10.516
The head teacher saw me staring at it,

00:04:10.516 --> 00:04:13.308
and he said, "Oh, that's our school motto."

00:04:13.308 --> 00:04:15.035
On the train back to London,

00:04:15.035 --> 00:04:16.889
I couldn't get it out of my mind.

00:04:16.889 --> 00:04:19.448
I kept thinking, can it really have taken us

00:04:19.448 --> 00:04:21.659
over 2,000 years to come to terms

00:04:21.659 --> 00:04:23.524
with that simple notion

00:04:23.524 --> 00:04:26.476
as being our minimum expectation of each other?

00:04:26.476 --> 00:04:29.084
Isn't it time that we develop this concept

00:04:29.084 --> 00:04:30.753
of a duty of care

00:04:30.753 --> 00:04:33.179
and extended it to include a care

00:04:33.179 --> 00:04:36.443
for our shared but increasingly
endangered democratic values?

00:04:36.443 --> 00:04:38.300
After all, the absence of a duty of care

00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:39.890
within many professions

00:04:39.890 --> 00:04:42.393
can all too easily amount to
accusations of negligence,

00:04:42.393 --> 00:04:45.500
and that being the case, can we be
really comfortable with the thought

00:04:45.500 --> 00:04:47.801
that we're in effect being negligent

00:04:47.801 --> 00:04:50.592
in respect of the health of our own societies

00:04:50.592 --> 00:04:53.327
and the values that necessarily underpin them?

00:04:53.327 --> 00:04:56.322
Could anyone honestly suggest, on the evidence,

00:04:56.322 --> 00:04:59.578
that the same media which
Hansard so roundly condemned

00:04:59.578 --> 00:05:02.865
have taken sufficient care to avoid behaving

00:05:02.865 --> 00:05:06.307
in ways which they could reasonably have foreseen

00:05:06.307 --> 00:05:08.408
would be likely to undermine or even damage

00:05:08.408 --> 00:05:11.242
our inherently fragile democratic settlement.

00:05:11.242 --> 00:05:13.263
Now there will be those who will argue

00:05:13.263 --> 00:05:15.036
that this could all too easily drift into a form

00:05:15.036 --> 00:05:17.043
of censorship, albeit self-censorship,

00:05:17.043 --> 00:05:18.999
but I don't buy that argument.

00:05:18.999 --> 00:05:21.058
It has to be possible

00:05:21.058 --> 00:05:23.158
to balance freedom of expression

00:05:23.158 --> 00:05:26.365
with wider moral and social responsibilities.

00:05:26.365 --> 00:05:28.216
Let me explain why by taking the example

00:05:28.216 --> 00:05:31.119
from my own career as a filmmaker.

00:05:31.119 --> 00:05:32.926
Throughout that career, I never accepted

00:05:32.926 --> 00:05:34.553
that a filmmaker should set about putting

00:05:34.553 --> 00:05:37.603
their own work outside or above what he or she

00:05:37.603 --> 00:05:39.553
believed to be a decent set of values

00:05:39.553 --> 00:05:42.902
for their own life, their own family,

00:05:42.902 --> 00:05:46.493
and the future of the society in which we all live.

00:05:46.493 --> 00:05:47.817
I'd go further.

00:05:47.817 --> 00:05:51.111
A responsible filmmaker should
never devalue their work

00:05:51.111 --> 00:05:53.155
to a point at which it becomes less than true

00:05:53.155 --> 00:05:56.595
to the world they themselves wish to inhabit.

00:05:56.595 --> 00:05:59.981
As I see it, filmmakers, journalists, even bloggers

00:05:59.981 --> 00:06:02.505
are all required to face up to the social expectations

00:06:02.505 --> 00:06:06.260
that come with combining the
intrinsic power of their medium

00:06:06.260 --> 00:06:09.634
with their well-honed professional skills.

00:06:09.634 --> 00:06:12.521
Obviously this is not a mandated duty,

00:06:12.521 --> 00:06:15.003
but for the gifted filmmaker
and the responsible journalist

00:06:15.003 --> 00:06:18.812
or even blogger, it strikes me
as being utterly inescapable.

00:06:18.823 --> 00:06:21.422
We should always remember that our notion

00:06:21.422 --> 00:06:24.313
of individual freedom and
its partner, creative freedom,

00:06:24.313 --> 00:06:26.108
is comparatively new

00:06:26.108 --> 00:06:28.370
in the history of Western ideas,

00:06:28.370 --> 00:06:30.288
and for that reason, it's often undervalued

00:06:30.288 --> 00:06:32.651
and can be very quickly undermined.

00:06:32.651 --> 00:06:34.878
It's a prize easily lost,

00:06:34.878 --> 00:06:36.641
and once lost, once surrendered,

00:06:36.641 --> 00:06:39.958
it can prove very, very hard to reclaim.

00:06:39.958 --> 00:06:41.483
And its first line of defense

00:06:41.483 --> 00:06:43.834
has to be our own standards,

00:06:43.834 --> 00:06:47.573

00:06:47.573 --> 00:06:49.396

00:06:49.396 --> 00:06:51.390

00:06:51.390 --> 00:06:52.938
with whom we work

00:06:52.938 --> 00:06:56.563
and our own standards as we operate within society.

00:06:56.563 --> 00:06:58.033

00:06:58.033 --> 00:07:01.298
need to be all of a piece with
a sustainable social agenda.

00:07:01.298 --> 00:07:03.411

00:07:03.411 --> 00:07:05.541

00:07:05.541 --> 00:07:07.915

00:07:07.915 --> 00:07:10.364

00:07:10.364 --> 00:07:12.782

00:07:12.782 --> 00:07:14.859

00:07:14.859 --> 00:07:17.219
and not to be tempted to misappropriate

00:07:17.234 --> 00:07:19.811
the causes of its ills.

00:07:19.811 --> 00:07:22.457
Yet, as has become strikingly clear

00:07:22.457 --> 00:07:24.525
over the last couple of years,

00:07:24.525 --> 00:07:26.559

00:07:26.559 --> 00:07:29.602

00:07:29.602 --> 00:07:31.542

00:07:31.542 --> 00:07:34.841

00:07:34.841 --> 00:07:37.226

00:07:40.823 --> 00:07:42.721

00:07:44.779 --> 00:07:46.860

00:07:46.860 --> 00:07:48.907

00:07:48.907 --> 00:07:52.481

00:07:52.481 --> 00:07:55.008

00:07:55.008 --> 00:07:57.285

00:07:57.285 --> 00:08:00.279

have been thrown out of court

00:08:00.279 --> 00:08:02.397

have gone out of business

00:08:02.397 --> 00:08:05.814

00:08:09.228 --> 00:08:12.306

00:09:31.254 --> 00:09:33.831
Fifty years ago this week,

00:09:33.831 --> 00:09:35.437

00:09:35.437 --> 00:09:38.934

title: Paper beats plastic? How to rethink environmental folklore
transcript: So imagine, you're in the supermarket, you're buying some groceries, and you get given the option for a plastic or a paper shopping bag. Which one do you choose if you want to do the right thing by the environment?Most people do pick the paper. Okay, let's think of why. It's brown to start with. Therefore, it must be good for the environment. It's biodegradable. It's reusable. In some cases, it's recyclable. So when people are looking at the plastic bag, it's likely they're thinking of something like this, which we all know is absolutely terrible, and we should be avoiding at all expenses these kinds of environmental damages. But people are often not thinking of something like this, which is the other end of the spectrum. When we produce materials, we need to extract them from the environment, and we need a whole bunch of environmental impacts.You see, what happens is, when we need to make complex choices, us humans like really simple solutions, and so we often ask for simple solutions. And I work in design. I advise designers and innovators around sustainability, and everyone always says to me, "Oh Leyla, I just want the eco-materials."And I say, "Well, that's very complex, and we'll have to spend four hours talking about what exactly an eco-material means, because everything at some point comes from nature, and it's how you use the material that dictates the environmental impact. So what happens is, we have to rely on some sort of intuitive framework when we make decisions. So I like to call that intuitive framework our environmental folklore. It's either the little voice at the back of your head, or it's that gut feeling you get when you've done the right thing, so when you've picked the paper bag or when you've bought a fuel-efficient car. And environmental folklore is a really important thing because we're trying to do the right thing. But how do we know if we're actually reducing the net environmental impacts that our actions as individuals and as professionals and as a society are actually having on the natural environment?So the thing about environmental folklore is it tends to be based on our experiences, the things we've heard from other people. It doesn't tend to be based on any scientific framework. And this is really hard, because we live in incredibly complex systems. We have the human systems of how we communicate and interrelate and have our whole constructed society, We have the industrial systems, which is essentially the entire economy, and then all of that has to operate within the biggest system, and, I would argue, the most important, the ecosystem. And you see, the choices that we make as an individual, but the choices that we make in every single job that we have, no matter how high or low you are in the pecking order, has an impact on all of these systems. And the thing is that we have to find ways if we're actually going to address sustainability of interlocking those complex systems and making better choices that result in net environmental gains. What we need to do is we need to learn to do more with less. We have an increasing population, and everybody likes their mobile phones, especially in this situation here. So we need to find innovative ways of solving some of these problems that we face.And that's where this process called life cycle thinking comes in. So essentially, everything that is created goes through a series of life cycle stages, and we use this scientific process called life cycle assessment, or in America, you guys say life cycle analysis, in order to have a clearer picture of how everything that we do in the technical part of those systems affects the natural environment. So we go all the way back to the extraction of raw materials, and then we look at manufacturing, we look at packaging and transportation, use, and end of life, and at every single one of these stages, the things that we do have an interaction with the natural environment, and we can monitor how that interaction is actually affecting the systems and services that make life on Earth possible. And through doing this, we've learned some absolutely fascinating things. And we've busted a bunch of myths.So to start with, there's a word that's used a lot. It's used a lot in marketing, and it's used a lot, I think, in our conversation when we're talking about sustainability, and that's the word biodegradability. Now biodegradability is a material property; it is not a definition of environmental benefits. Allow me to explain. When something natural, something that's made from a cellulose fiber like a piece of bread, even, or any food waste, or even a piece of paper, when something natural ends up in the natural environment, it degrades normally. Its little carbon molecules that it stored up as it was growing are naturally released back into the atmosphere as carbon dioxide, but this is a net situation. Most natural things don't actually end up in nature. Most of the things, the waste that  we produce, end up in landfill. Landfill is a different environment. In landfill, those same carbon molecules degrade in a different way, because a landfill is anaerobic. It's got no oxygen. It's tightly compacted and hot. Those same molecules, they become methane, and methane is a 25 times more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide. So our old lettuces and products that we have thrown out that are made out of biodegradable materials, if they end up in landfill, contribute to climate change. You see, there are facilities now that can actually capture that methane and generate power, displacing the need for fossil fuel power, but we need to be smart about this. We need to identify how we can start to leverage these types of things that are already happening and start to design systems and services that alleviate these problems. Because right now, what people do is they turn around and they say, "Let's ban plastic bags. We'll give people paper because that is better for the environment." But if you're throwing it in the bin, and your local landfill facility is just a normal one, then we're having what's called a double negative.I'm a product designer by trade. I then did social science. And so I'm absolutely fascinated by consumer goods and how the consumer goods that we have kind of become immune to that fill our lives have an impact on the natural environment. And these guys are, like, serial offenders, and I'm pretty sure everyone in this room has a refrigerator. Now America has this amazing ability to keep growing refrigerators. In the last few years, they've grown one cubic foot on average, the standard size of a refrigerator. And the problem is, they're so big now, it's easier for us to buy more food that we can't eat or find. I mean, I have things at the back of my refrigerator that have been there for years, all right? And so what happens is, we waste more food. And as I was just explaining, food waste is a problem. In fact, here in the U.S., 40 percent of food purchased for the home is wasted. Half of the world's produced food is wasted. That's the latest U.N. stats. Up to half of the food. It's insane. It's 1.3 billion tons of food per annum. And I blame it on the refrigerator, well, especially in Western cultures, because it makes it easier. I mean, there's a lot of complex systems going on here. I don't want to make it so simplistic.But the refrigerator is a serious contributor to this, and one of the features of it is the crisper drawer. You all got crisper drawers? The drawer that you put your lettuces in? Lettuces have a habit of going soggy in the crisper drawers, don't they? Yeah? Soggy lettuces? In the U.K., this is such a problem that there was a government report a few years ago that actually said the second biggest offender of wasted food in the U.K. is the soggy lettuce. It was called the Soggy Lettuce Report. Okay? So this is a problem, people. These poor little lettuces are getting thrown out left, right and center because the crisper drawers are not designed to actually keep things crisp. Okay. You need a tight environment. You need, like, an airless environment to prevent the degrading that would happen naturally. But the crisper drawers, they're just a drawer with a slightly better seal. Anyway, I'm clearly obsessed. Don't ever invite me over because I'll just start going through your refrigerator and looking at all sorts of things like that. But essentially, this is a big problem. Because when we lose something like the lettuce from the system, not only do we have that impact  I just explained at the end of life, but we actually have had to grow that lettuce. The life cycle impact of that lettuce is astronomical. We've had to clear land. We've had to plant seeds, phosphorus, fertilizers, nutrients, water, sunlight. All of the embodied impacts in that lettuce get lost from the system, which makes it a far bigger environmental impact than the loss of the energy from the fridge. So we need to design things like this far better if we're going to start addressing serious environmental problems. We could start with the crisper drawer and the size. For those of you in the room who do design fridges, that would be great.The problem is, imagine if we actually started to reconsider  how we designed things. So I look at the refrigerator as a sign of modernity, but we actually haven't really changed the design of them that much since the 1950s. A little bit, but essentially they're still big boxes, cold boxes that we store stuff in. So imagine if we actually really started to identify these problems and use that as the foundation for finding innovative and elegant design solutions that will solve those problems. This is design-led system change, design dictating the way in which the system can be far more sustainable. Forty percent food waste is a major problem. Imagine if we designed fridges that halved that.Another item that I find fascinating is the electric tea kettle, which I found out that you don't do tea kettles in this country, really, do you? But that's really big in the U.K. Ninety-seven percent of households in the United Kingdom own an electric tea kettle. So they're very popular. And, I mean, if I were to work with a design firm or a designer, and they were designing one of these, and they wanted to do it eco, they'd usually ask me two things. They'd say, "Leyla, how do I make it technically efficient?" Because obviously energy's a problem with this product. Or, "How do I make it green materials? How do I make the materials green in the manufacturing?" Would you ask me those questions? They seem logical, right? Yeah. Well I'd say, "You're looking at the wrong problems." Because the problem is with use. It's with how people use the product. Sixty-five percent of Brits admit to over-filling their kettle when they only need one cup of tea. All of this extra water that's being boiled requires energy, and it's been calculated that in one day of extra energy use from boiling kettles is enough to light all of the streetlights in England for a night.But this is the thing. This is what I call a product-person failure. But we've got a product-system failure going on with these little guys, and they're so ubiquitous, you  don't even notice they're there. And this guy over here, though, he does. He's named Simon. Simon works for the national electricity company in the U.K. He has a very important job of monitoring all of the electricity coming into the system to make sure there is enough so it powers everybody's homes. He's also watching television. The reason is because there's a unique phenomenon that happens in the U.K. the moment that very popular TV shows end. The minute the ad break comes on, this man has to rush to buy nuclear power from France, because everybody turns their kettles on at the same time. (Laughter) 1.5 million kettles, seriously problematic. So imagine if you designed kettles, you actually found a way to solve these system failures, because this is a huge amount of pressure on the system, just because the product hasn't thought about the problem that it's going to have when it exists in the world. Now, I looked at a number of kettles available on the market, and found the minimum fill lines, so the little piece of information that tells you how much you need to put in there, was between two and a five-and-a-half cups of water just to make one cup of tea. So this kettle here is an example of one where it actually has two reservoirs. One's a boiling chamber, and one's the water holder. The user actually has to push that button to get their hot water boiled, which means, because we're all lazy, you only fill exactly what you need. And this is what I call behavior-changing products: products, systems or services that intervene and solve these problems up front.Now, this is a technology arena, so obviously these things are quite popular, but I think if we're going to keep designing, buying and using and throwing out these kinds of products at the rate we currently do, which is astronomically high, there are seven billion people who live in the world right now. There are six billion mobile phone subscriptions as of last year. Every single year, 1.5 billion mobile phones roll off production lines, and some companies report their production rate as being greater than the human birth rate. One hundred fifty-two million phones  were thrown out in the U.S. last year; only 11 percent were recycled. I'm from Australia. We have a population of 22 million — don't laugh — and it's been reported that 22 million phones are in people's drawers. We need to find ways of solving the problems around this, because these things are so complicated. They have so much locked up inside them. Gold! Did you know that it's actually cheaper now to get gold out of a ton of old mobile phones than it is out of a ton of gold ore? There's a number of highly complex and valuable materials embodied inside these things, so we need to find ways of encouraging disassembly, because this is otherwise what happens. This is a community in Ghana, and e-waste is reported, or electronic waste is reported by the U.N. as being up to 50 million tons trafficked. This is how they get the gold and the other valuable materials out. They burn the electronic waste in open spaces. These are communities, and this is happening all over the world. And because we don't see the ramifications of the choices that we make as designers, as businesspeople, as consumers, then these kinds of externalities happen, and these are people's lives. So we need to find smarter, more systems-based, innovative solutions to these problems, if we're going to start to live sustainably within this world.So imagine if, when you bought your mobile phone, your new one because you replaced your old one — after 15 to 18 months is the average time that people replace their phones, by the way — so if we're going to keep this kind of expedient mobile phone replacing, then we should be looking at closing the loop on these systems. The people who produce these phones, and some of which I'm sure are in the room right now, could potentially look at doing what we call closed-loop systems, or product system services, so identifying that there is a market demand and that market demand's not going to go anywhere, so you design the product to solve the problem. Design for disassembly, design for light-weighting. We heard some of those kinds of strategies being used in the Tesla Motors car today. These kinds of approaches are not hard, but understanding the system and then looking for viable, market-driven consumer demand alternatives is how we can start radically altering the sustainability agenda, because I hate to break it to you all: Consumption is the biggest problem. But design is one of the best solutions.These kinds of products are everywhere. By identifying alternative ways of doing things, we can actually start to innovate, and I say actually start to innovate. I'm sure everyone in this room is very innovative. But in the regards to using sustainability as a parameter, as a criteria for fueling systems-based solutions, because as I've just demonstrated with these simple products, they're participating in these major problems. So we need to look across the entire life of the things that we do.If you just had paper or plastic — obviously reusable is far more beneficial — then the paper is worse, and the paper is worse because it weighs four to 10 times more than the plastic, and when we actually compare, from a life cycle perspective, a kilo of plastic and a kilo of paper, the paper is far better, but the functionality of a plastic or a paper bag to carry your groceries home is not  done with a kilo of each material. It's done with a very small amount of plastic and quite a lot more paper. Because functionality defines environmental impact, and I said earlier that the designers always ask me for the eco-materials. I say, there's only a few materials that you should completely avoid. The rest of them, it's all about application, and at the end of the day, everything we design and produce in the economy or buy as consumers is done so for function. We want something, therefore we buy it. So breaking things back down and delivering smartly, elegantly, sophisticated solutions that take into consideration the entire system and the entire life of the thing, everything, all the way back to the extraction through to the end of life, we can start to actually find really innovative solutions.And I'll just leave you with one very quick thing that a designer said to me recently  who I work with, a senior designer. I said, "How come you're not doing  sustainability? I know you know this." And he said, "Well, recently I pitched a sustainability project to a client, and turned and he said to me, 'I know it's going to cost less, I know it's going to sell more, but we're not pioneers, because pioneers have arrows in their backs.'"I think we've got a roomful of pioneers, and I hope there are far more pioneers out there, because we need to solve these problems.Thank you.(Applause)

00:00:52.397 --> 00:00:54.415

of environmental impacts.

00:01:33.102 --> 00:01:35.197

00:01:35.197 --> 00:01:38.238
that dictates the environmental impact.

00:01:38.238 --> 00:01:40.027
So what happens is, we have to rely

00:01:40.027 --> 00:01:42.085

00:01:42.085 --> 00:01:43.660

00:04:21.521 --> 00:04:26.509
So to start with, there's a word that's used a lot.

00:04:28.242 --> 00:04:30.242

is just a normal one,

00:06:14.082 --> 00:06:18.988
then we're having what's called a double negative.

00:06:18.988 --> 00:06:22.152
I'm a product designer by trade.

00:06:22.152 --> 00:06:23.344
I then did social science.

00:06:23.344 --> 00:06:24.761
And so I'm absolutely fascinated

00:06:24.761 --> 00:06:26.760
by consumer goods and how the consumer goods

00:06:26.760 --> 00:06:28.882
that we have kind of become immune to

00:06:28.882 --> 00:06:30.120
that fill our lives

00:06:30.120 --> 00:06:31.928
have an impact on the natural environment.

00:06:31.928 --> 00:06:34.541
And these guys are, like, serial offenders,

00:06:34.541 --> 00:06:36.404
and I'm pretty sure everyone in this room

00:06:36.404 --> 00:06:38.034
has a refrigerator.

00:06:38.034 --> 00:06:39.666
Now America has this amazing ability

00:06:39.666 --> 00:06:41.675
to keep growing refrigerators.

00:06:41.675 --> 00:06:43.653
In the last few years, they've grown one cubic foot

00:06:43.653 --> 00:06:45.501
on average, the standard size

00:06:45.501 --> 00:06:47.130
of a refrigerator.

00:06:47.130 --> 00:06:49.589
And the problem is, they're so big now,

00:06:49.589 --> 00:06:51.783
it's easier for us to buy more food

00:06:51.783 --> 00:06:53.774
that we can't eat or find.

00:06:53.774 --> 00:06:55.400
I mean, I have things at the back of my refrigerator

00:06:55.400 --> 00:06:57.610
that have been there for years, all right?

00:06:57.610 --> 00:07:00.246
And so what happens is, we waste more food.

00:07:00.246 --> 00:07:03.591
And as I was just explaining,
food waste is a problem.

00:07:03.591 --> 00:07:06.953
In fact, here in the U.S., 40 percent

00:07:06.953 --> 00:07:09.528
of food purchased for the home is wasted.

00:07:09.528 --> 00:07:13.863
Half of the world's produced food is wasted.

00:07:13.863 --> 00:07:16.516
That's the latest U.N. stats. Up to half of the food.

00:07:16.516 --> 00:07:21.053
It's insane. It's 1.3 billion tons of food per annum.

00:07:21.053 --> 00:07:23.057
And I blame it on the refrigerator,

00:07:23.057 --> 00:07:24.585
well, especially in Western cultures,

00:07:24.585 --> 00:07:26.435
because it makes it easier.

00:07:26.435 --> 00:07:28.827
I mean, there's a lot of complex
systems going on here.

00:07:28.827 --> 00:07:30.765
I don't want to make it so simplistic.

00:07:30.765 --> 00:07:33.715
But the refrigerator is a serious contributor to this,

00:07:33.715 --> 00:07:35.573
and one of the features of it

00:07:35.573 --> 00:07:37.535
is the crisper drawer.

00:07:37.535 --> 00:07:39.036
You all got crisper drawers?

00:07:39.036 --> 00:07:40.971
The drawer that you put your lettuces in?

00:07:40.971 --> 00:07:42.891
Lettuces have a habit of going soggy

00:07:42.891 --> 00:07:44.687
in the crisper drawers, don't they?

00:07:44.687 --> 00:07:46.097
Yeah? Soggy lettuces?

00:07:46.097 --> 00:07:48.097
In the U.K., this is such a problem

00:07:48.097 --> 00:07:49.795
that there was a government report a few years ago

00:07:49.795 --> 00:07:52.815
that actually said the second biggest offender

00:07:52.815 --> 00:07:55.232
of wasted food in the U.K. is the soggy lettuce.

00:07:55.232 --> 00:07:57.650
It was called the Soggy Lettuce Report.

00:07:57.650 --> 00:07:59.863
Okay? So this is a problem, people.

00:07:59.863 --> 00:08:01.973
These poor little lettuces are getting thrown out

00:08:01.973 --> 00:08:03.845
left, right and center because the crisper drawers

00:08:03.845 --> 00:08:06.604
are not designed to actually keep things crisp.

00:08:06.604 --> 00:08:08.813
Okay. You need a tight environment.

00:08:08.813 --> 00:08:10.943
You need, like, an airless environment

00:08:10.943 --> 00:08:13.668
to prevent the degrading that
would happen naturally.

00:08:13.668 --> 00:08:15.620
But the crisper drawers, they're just a drawer

00:08:15.620 --> 00:08:17.328
with a slightly better seal.

00:08:17.328 --> 00:08:19.415
Anyway, I'm clearly obsessed.

00:08:19.415 --> 00:08:22.140
Don't ever invite me over because I'll just
start going through your refrigerator

00:08:22.140 --> 00:08:23.658
and looking at all sorts of things like that.

00:08:23.658 --> 00:08:25.577
But essentially, this is a big problem.

00:08:25.577 --> 00:08:28.536
Because when we lose something
like the lettuce from the system,

00:08:28.536 --> 00:08:32.072
not only do we have that impact 
I just explained at the end of life,

00:08:32.072 --> 00:08:34.728
but we actually have had to grow that lettuce.

00:08:34.728 --> 00:08:37.999
The life cycle impact of that lettuce is astronomical.

00:08:37.999 --> 00:08:39.417
We've had to clear land.

00:08:39.417 --> 00:08:41.574
We've had to plant seeds, phosphorus,

00:08:41.574 --> 00:08:43.698
fertilizers, nutrients, water, sunlight.

00:08:43.698 --> 00:08:45.786
All of the embodied impacts in that lettuce

00:08:45.786 --> 00:08:47.498
get lost from the system,

00:08:47.498 --> 00:08:50.109
which makes it a far bigger environmental impact

00:08:50.109 --> 00:08:53.793
than the loss of the energy from the fridge.

00:08:53.793 --> 00:08:57.058
So we need to design things like this far better

00:08:57.058 --> 00:09:00.239
if we're going to start addressing
serious environmental problems.

00:09:00.239 --> 00:09:01.890
We could start with the crisper drawer and the size.

00:09:01.890 --> 00:09:03.642
For those of you in the room who do design fridges,

00:09:03.642 --> 00:09:05.135
that would be great.

00:09:05.135 --> 00:09:08.233
The problem is, imagine if we

00:09:08.233 --> 00:09:10.883
actually started to reconsider 
how we designed things.

00:09:10.883 --> 00:09:14.490
So I look at the refrigerator as a sign of modernity,

00:09:14.490 --> 00:09:16.588
but we actually haven't really changed the design

00:09:16.588 --> 00:09:19.259
of them that much since the 1950s.

00:09:19.259 --> 00:09:22.484
A little bit, but essentially they're still big boxes,

00:09:22.484 --> 00:09:24.406
cold boxes that we store stuff in.

00:09:24.406 --> 00:09:26.226
So imagine if we actually really started

00:09:26.226 --> 00:09:28.971
to identify these problems and use that

00:09:28.971 --> 00:09:32.908
as the foundation for finding innovative and elegant

00:09:32.908 --> 00:09:36.261
design solutions that will solve those problems.

00:09:36.261 --> 00:09:38.486
This is design-led system change,

00:09:38.486 --> 00:09:42.196
design dictating the way in which the system

00:09:42.196 --> 00:09:44.961
can be far more sustainable.

00:09:44.961 --> 00:09:47.055
Forty percent food waste is a major problem.

00:09:47.055 --> 00:09:51.120
Imagine if we designed fridges that halved that.

00:09:51.120 --> 00:09:53.471
Another item that I find fascinating

00:09:53.471 --> 00:09:54.724
is the electric tea kettle,

00:09:54.724 --> 00:09:56.117
which I found out that

00:09:56.117 --> 00:09:59.368
you don't do tea kettles in
this country, really, do you?

00:09:59.368 --> 00:10:01.456
But that's really big in the U.K.

00:10:01.456 --> 00:10:03.689
Ninety-seven percent of households

00:10:03.689 --> 00:10:06.621
in the United Kingdom own an electric tea kettle.

00:10:06.621 --> 00:10:08.228
So they're very popular.

00:10:08.228 --> 00:10:11.028
And, I mean, if I were to work with a design firm

00:10:11.028 --> 00:10:13.280
or a designer, and they were designing one of these,

00:10:13.280 --> 00:10:14.519
and they wanted to do it eco,

00:10:14.519 --> 00:10:16.437
they'd usually ask me two things.

00:10:16.437 --> 00:10:19.481
They'd say, "Leyla, how do I
make it technically efficient?"

00:10:19.481 --> 00:10:22.769
Because obviously energy's
a problem with this product.

00:10:22.769 --> 00:10:25.834
Or, "How do I make it green materials?

00:10:25.834 --> 00:10:28.744
How do I make the materials green

00:10:28.744 --> 00:10:30.566
in the manufacturing?"

00:10:30.566 --> 00:10:32.369
Would you ask me those questions?

00:10:32.369 --> 00:10:35.168
They seem logical, right? Yeah.

00:10:35.168 --> 00:10:37.727
Well I'd say, "You're looking at the wrong problems."

00:10:37.727 --> 00:10:39.885
Because the problem is with use.

00:10:39.885 --> 00:10:42.560
It's with how people use the product.

00:10:42.560 --> 00:10:44.395
Sixty-five percent of Brits

00:10:44.395 --> 00:10:46.739
admit to over-filling their kettle

00:10:46.739 --> 00:10:49.325
when they only need one cup of tea.

00:10:49.325 --> 00:10:52.068
All of this extra water that's being boiled

00:10:52.068 --> 00:10:56.036
requires energy, and it's been calculated

00:10:56.036 --> 00:10:59.074
that in one day of extra energy use

00:10:59.074 --> 00:11:00.617
from boiling kettles

00:11:00.617 --> 00:11:03.259
is enough to light all of the streetlights

00:11:03.259 --> 00:11:05.882
in England for a night.

00:11:05.882 --> 00:11:08.000
But this is the thing.

00:11:08.000 --> 00:11:09.914
This is what I call a product-person failure.

00:11:09.914 --> 00:11:12.660
But we've got a product-system failure
going on with these little guys,

00:11:12.660 --> 00:11:15.570
and they're so ubiquitous, you 
don't even notice they're there.

00:11:15.570 --> 00:11:18.783
And this guy over here, though, he does.
He's named Simon.

00:11:18.783 --> 00:11:22.090
Simon works for the national
electricity company in the U.K.

00:11:22.090 --> 00:11:24.232
He has a very important job of monitoring

00:11:24.232 --> 00:11:26.671
all of the electricity coming into the system

00:11:26.671 --> 00:11:28.084
to make sure there is enough

00:11:28.084 --> 00:11:30.012
so it powers everybody's homes.

00:11:30.012 --> 00:11:32.116
He's also watching television.

00:11:32.116 --> 00:11:34.089
The reason is because there's a unique

00:11:34.089 --> 00:11:35.907
phenomenon that happens in the U.K.

00:11:35.907 --> 00:11:39.945
the moment that very popular TV shows end.

00:11:39.945 --> 00:11:42.183
The minute the ad break comes on,

00:11:42.183 --> 00:11:44.020
this man has to rush

00:11:44.020 --> 00:11:47.076
to buy nuclear power from France,

00:11:47.076 --> 00:11:49.965
because everybody turns their kettles on

00:11:49.965 --> 00:11:52.030
at the same time.

00:11:52.030 --> 00:11:54.276
(Laughter)

00:11:54.276 --> 00:12:00.261
1.5 million kettles, seriously problematic.

00:12:00.261 --> 00:12:03.830
So imagine if you designed kettles,

00:12:03.830 --> 00:12:06.570
you actually found a way to
solve these system failures,

00:12:06.570 --> 00:12:09.235
because this is a huge amount of pressure

00:12:09.235 --> 00:12:10.626
on the system,

00:12:10.626 --> 00:12:14.062
just because the product hasn't
thought about the problem

00:12:14.062 --> 00:12:15.925
that it's going to have when it exists in the world.

00:12:15.925 --> 00:12:18.593
Now, I looked at a number of
kettles available on the market,

00:12:18.593 --> 00:12:20.615
and found the minimum fill lines,

00:12:20.615 --> 00:12:22.381
so the little piece of information that tells you

00:12:22.381 --> 00:12:23.938
how much you need to put in there,

00:12:23.938 --> 00:12:26.857
was between two and a five-and-a-half cups of water

00:12:26.857 --> 00:12:30.290
just to make one cup of tea.

00:12:30.290 --> 00:12:32.575
So this kettle here is an example of one where

00:12:32.575 --> 00:12:35.111
it actually has two reservoirs.

00:12:35.113 --> 00:12:37.298
One's a boiling chamber, and one's the water holder.

00:12:37.298 --> 00:12:39.623
The user actually has to push that button

00:12:39.623 --> 00:12:41.191
to get their hot water boiled,

00:12:41.191 --> 00:12:42.957
which means, because we're all lazy,

00:12:42.957 --> 00:12:44.799
you only fill exactly what you need.

00:12:44.799 --> 00:12:47.123
And this is what I call behavior-changing products:

00:12:47.123 --> 00:12:49.235
products, systems or services

00:12:49.235 --> 00:12:53.094
that intervene and solve these problems up front.

00:12:53.094 --> 00:12:55.744
Now, this is a technology arena,

00:12:55.744 --> 00:12:57.805
so obviously these things are quite popular,

00:12:57.805 --> 00:12:59.773
but I think if we're going to keep

00:12:59.773 --> 00:13:02.359
designing, buying and using and throwing out

00:13:02.359 --> 00:13:04.271
these kinds of products at the rate we currently do,

00:13:04.271 --> 00:13:06.520
which is astronomically high,

00:13:06.520 --> 00:13:08.354
there are seven billion people

00:13:08.354 --> 00:13:09.764
who live in the world right now.

00:13:09.764 --> 00:13:11.951
There are six billion mobile phone subscriptions

00:13:11.951 --> 00:13:15.617
as of last year.

00:13:15.617 --> 00:13:19.139
Every single year, 1.5 billion mobile phones

00:13:19.139 --> 00:13:20.392
roll off production lines,

00:13:20.392 --> 00:13:22.463
and some companies report their production rate

00:13:22.463 --> 00:13:24.813
as being greater than the human birth rate.

00:13:24.813 --> 00:13:27.943
One hundred fifty-two million phones 
were thrown out in the U.S. last year;

00:13:27.943 --> 00:13:29.827
only 11 percent were recycled.

00:13:29.827 --> 00:13:33.185
I'm from Australia. We have a
population of 22 million -- don't laugh --

00:13:33.185 --> 00:13:36.258
and it's been reported that 22 million phones

00:13:36.258 --> 00:13:38.865
are in people's drawers.

00:13:38.865 --> 00:13:42.586
We need to find ways of solving
the problems around this,

00:13:42.586 --> 00:13:45.483
because these things are so complicated.

00:13:45.483 --> 00:13:48.789
They have so much locked up inside them.

00:13:48.789 --> 00:13:52.552
Gold! Did you know that it's actually cheaper now

00:13:52.552 --> 00:13:56.169
to get gold out of a ton of old mobile phones

00:13:56.169 --> 00:13:59.397
than it is out of a ton of gold ore?

00:13:59.397 --> 00:14:01.787
There's a number of highly complex and valuable

00:14:01.787 --> 00:14:03.388
materials embodied inside these things,

00:14:03.388 --> 00:14:05.846
so we need to find ways of encouraging disassembly,

00:14:05.846 --> 00:14:08.010
because this is otherwise what happens.

00:14:08.010 --> 00:14:09.684
This is a community in Ghana,

00:14:09.684 --> 00:14:11.942
and e-waste is reported, or electronic waste

00:14:11.942 --> 00:14:13.918
is reported by the U.N.

00:14:13.918 --> 00:14:16.950
as being up to 50 million tons trafficked.

00:14:16.950 --> 00:14:18.264
This is how they get the gold

00:14:18.264 --> 00:14:19.798
and the other valuable materials out.

00:14:19.798 --> 00:14:21.736
They burn the electronic waste

00:14:21.736 --> 00:14:23.767
in open spaces.

00:14:23.767 --> 00:14:26.902
These are communities, and this
is happening all over the world.

00:14:26.902 --> 00:14:29.449
And because we don't see the ramifications

00:14:29.449 --> 00:14:31.278
of the choices that we make as designers,

00:14:31.278 --> 00:14:33.748
as businesspeople, as consumers,

00:14:33.748 --> 00:14:35.361
then these kinds of externalities happen,

00:14:35.361 --> 00:14:37.663
and these are people's lives.

00:14:37.663 --> 00:14:42.111
So we need to find smarter, more systems-based,

00:14:42.111 --> 00:14:45.027
innovative solutions to these problems,

00:14:45.027 --> 00:14:48.803
if we're going to start to live
sustainably within this world.

00:14:48.803 --> 00:14:52.776
So imagine if, when you bought your mobile phone,

00:14:52.776 --> 00:14:54.466
your new one because you replaced your old one --

00:14:54.466 --> 00:14:56.841
after 15 to 18 months is the average time

00:14:56.841 --> 00:14:58.945
that people replace their phones, by the way —

00:14:58.945 --> 00:15:01.930
so if we're going to keep this kind of expedient

00:15:01.930 --> 00:15:04.168
mobile phone replacing, then we should

00:15:04.168 --> 00:15:06.217
be looking at closing the loop on these systems.

00:15:06.217 --> 00:15:08.128
The people who produce these phones,

00:15:08.128 --> 00:15:09.957
and some of which I'm sure
are in the room right now,

00:15:09.957 --> 00:15:12.635
could potentially look at doing what
we call closed-loop systems,

00:15:12.635 --> 00:15:14.203
or product system services,

00:15:14.203 --> 00:15:16.465
so identifying that there is a market demand

00:15:16.465 --> 00:15:18.282
and that market demand's not going to go anywhere,

00:15:18.282 --> 00:15:21.335
so you design the product to solve the problem.

00:15:21.335 --> 00:15:23.674
Design for disassembly, design for light-weighting.

00:15:23.674 --> 00:15:26.040
We heard some of those kinds of strategies

00:15:26.040 --> 00:15:28.899
being used in the Tesla Motors car today.

00:15:28.899 --> 00:15:31.011
These kinds of approaches are not hard,

00:15:31.011 --> 00:15:32.869
but understanding the system

00:15:32.869 --> 00:15:36.400
and then looking for viable, market-driven

00:15:36.400 --> 00:15:38.383
consumer demand alternatives

00:15:38.383 --> 00:15:40.934
is how we can start radically altering

00:15:40.934 --> 00:15:42.741
the sustainability agenda,

00:15:42.741 --> 00:15:44.612
because I hate to break it to you all:

00:15:44.612 --> 00:15:47.415
Consumption is the biggest problem.

00:15:47.415 --> 00:15:52.677
But design is one of the best solutions.

00:15:52.677 --> 00:15:54.861
These kinds of products are everywhere.

00:15:54.861 --> 00:15:57.529
By identifying alternative ways of doing things,

00:15:57.529 --> 00:15:59.124
we can actually start to innovate,

00:15:59.124 --> 00:16:00.517
and I say actually start to innovate.

00:16:00.517 --> 00:16:03.002
I'm sure everyone in this room is very innovative.

00:16:03.002 --> 00:16:05.356
But in the regards to using sustainability

00:16:05.356 --> 00:16:08.043
as a parameter, as a criteria

00:16:08.043 --> 00:16:12.260
for fueling systems-based solutions,

00:16:12.260 --> 00:16:15.165
because as I've just demonstrated
with these simple products,

00:16:15.165 --> 00:16:18.556
they're participating in these major problems.

00:16:18.556 --> 00:16:20.711
So we need to look across the entire life

00:16:20.711 --> 00:16:22.333
of the things that we do.

00:16:22.333 --> 00:16:24.048
If you just had paper or plastic --

00:16:24.048 --> 00:16:26.812
obviously reusable is far more beneficial --

00:16:26.812 --> 00:16:30.283
then the paper is worse,

00:16:30.283 --> 00:16:32.329
and the paper is worse because it weighs

00:16:32.329 --> 00:16:34.433
four to 10 times more than the plastic,

00:16:34.433 --> 00:16:36.800
and when we actually compare,
from a life cycle perspective,

00:16:36.800 --> 00:16:39.490
a kilo of plastic and a kilo of paper,

00:16:39.490 --> 00:16:41.136
the paper is far better,

00:16:41.136 --> 00:16:43.676
but the functionality of a plastic or a paper bag

00:16:43.676 --> 00:16:47.291
to carry your groceries home is not 
done with a kilo of each material.

00:16:47.291 --> 00:16:49.260
It's done with a very small amount of plastic

00:16:49.260 --> 00:16:50.953
and quite a lot more paper.

00:16:50.953 --> 00:16:53.911
Because functionality defines environmental impact,

00:16:53.911 --> 00:16:56.744
and I said earlier that the designers
always ask me for the eco-materials.

00:16:56.744 --> 00:16:59.768
I say, there's only a few materials
that you should completely avoid.

00:16:59.789 --> 00:17:01.688
The rest of them, it's all about application,

00:17:01.688 --> 00:17:04.707
and at the end of the day, everything
we design and produce in the economy

00:17:04.707 --> 00:17:07.047
or buy as consumers is done so for function.

00:17:07.047 --> 00:17:09.164
We want something, therefore we buy it.

00:17:09.164 --> 00:17:12.320
So breaking things back down and delivering

00:17:12.320 --> 00:17:16.319
smartly, elegantly, sophisticated solutions

00:17:16.319 --> 00:17:19.116
that take into consideration the entire system

00:17:19.116 --> 00:17:22.211
and the entire life of the thing, everything,

00:17:22.211 --> 00:17:25.047
all the way back to the extraction
through to the end of life,

00:17:25.047 --> 00:17:27.849
we can start to actually find
really innovative solutions.

00:17:27.849 --> 00:17:29.919
And I'll just leave you with one very quick thing

00:17:29.919 --> 00:17:33.776
that a designer said to me recently 
who I work with, a senior designer.

00:17:33.776 --> 00:17:36.874
I said, "How come you're not doing 
sustainability? I know you know this."

00:17:36.874 --> 00:17:40.886
And he said, "Well, recently I pitched
a sustainability project to a client,

00:17:40.886 --> 00:17:42.827
and turned and he said to me,

00:17:42.827 --> 00:17:44.592
'I know it's going to cost less,

00:17:44.592 --> 00:17:46.210
I know it's going to sell more,

00:17:46.210 --> 00:17:50.683
but we're not pioneers, because
pioneers have arrows in their backs.'"

00:17:50.683 --> 00:17:52.900
I think we've got a roomful of pioneers,
